DEBATE.TITLE: REPRESENTATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that on 29 January 1988 I received a letter from Senator the Hon. Susan Maree Ryan resigning her place as a senator for the Australian Capital Territory. In accordance with the provisions of section 44 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, I have notified His Excellency the Governor-General that a vacancy has happened in the representation of the Australian Capital Territory.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I table an instrument by His Excellency the Governor-General convening a Joint Sitting of the members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives for the purpose of choosing a person to hold the place in the Senate formerly held by the Hon. Susan Maree Ryan.

INTERJECT.PARA: Place and Time of Meeting
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans)-by leave-agreed to:

(1) That, pursuant to the Instrument by His Excellency the Governor-General, acting with the advice of the Federal Executive Council and pursuant to subsection 44 (1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, convening a Joint Sitting of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives at Parliament House, Canberra, in the Australian Capital Territory, at 8 o'clock in the evening on 16 February 1988, the place of the Joint Sitting within Parliament House be the Senate Chamber.
(2) That the foregoing Resolution be communicated by Message to the House of Representatives for its concurrence.
Rules for Conduct of Business
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans)-by leave-agreed to:

That the following rules be adopted for the conduct of a Joint Sitting of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives to choose a Senator pursuant to section 44 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918:
Matter to be considered at Joint Sitting

1. The purpose of a Joint Sitting being to choose a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate pursuant to section 44 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, no other shall be considered at a Joint Sitting.
General rule for conduct of business
2. In any matter of procedure not provided for in the following rules, the Standing Orders of the Senate, in force for the time being, shall be followed as far as they can be applied.
Chairman of Joint Sitting
3. The President of the Senate or, in the absence of the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, shall be the Chairman of a Joint Sitting.
Clerks of Joint Sitting

4. The Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives shall act as Joint Clerks of a Joint Sitting and either of them may exercise a function expressed to be exercisable by the Clerk.
Minutes of proceedings
5. Proceedings of a Joint Sitting shall be recorded by the Joint Clerks, and such records shall constitute the minutes of proceedings of a Joint Sitting and shall be signed by the Joint Clerks.
Time limit on speeches
6. No Senator or Member of the House of Representatives may speak for more than five minutes on any proposal or question before a Joint Sitting.
Objection to rulings of Chair

7. If any objection is taken to any ruling of the Chairman, such objection must be taken at once, and a motion of dissent, to be submitted in writing, moved, which, if seconded, shall be proposed to the Joint Sitting, and debate thereon shall proceed forthwith.
Entitlement to vote
8. On any question arising in a Joint Sitting each Senator and Member of the House of Representatives, including the Chairman, shall have one vote.
Voting

9. Questions arising in a Joint Sitting shall be decided by a simple majority of the Senators and Members of the House of Representatives present and voting and, if the votes are equal, the question shall be resolved in the negative.
Choice of a person to hold vacant place in the Senate

10. (a) A Senator or Member of the House of Representatives, addressing the Chair, shall propose a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate and such proposal shall be seconded. When any person is so proposed the proposer shall state that that person is willing to hold the vacant place if chosen.

(b) In proposing a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate, the proposer shall declare that that person is eligible to be chosen for the Senate and that the nomination is in accordance with the provisions of subsection 44 (3) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

(c) If only one person is proposed and seconded, the Chairman shall put the question that that person shall be the person to hold the place of the Senator for the Australian Capital Territory whose place has become vacant.
(d) If the question is passed, the Chairman shall declare that the person has been chosen to hold the place of the Senator for the Australian Capital Territory whose place has become vacant.
(e) If more than one person is proposed and seconded, the person to hold the vacant place shall be chosen by ballot. Before the ballot proceeds the bells shall be rung for three minutes.

(f) Before giving directions to proceed with the ballot, the Chairman shall ask if any Senator or Member of the House of Representatives desires to propose any other person to hold the vacant place, and no other person shall be proposed after the ballot is commenced.

(g) Each Senator and Member of the House of Representatives present shall be provided with a ballot-paper certified by one of the Joint Clerks, and shall vote by writing thereon the name of one of the persons duly proposed, and shall place the ballot-paper in the ballot-box.

(h) The Chairman shall appoint a person from each House to be a scrutineer. The scrutineers, with the Joint Clerks, shall ascertain the number of votes for each of the persons duly proposed, and the scrutineers shall report the result to the Chairman.
(i) No informal vote shall be taken into account.

(j) If on the first ballot no person receives an absolute majority of the votes cast, the name of the person who receives the fewest votes at the first ballot shall be excluded, and a second ballot shall be taken; but if at the first ballot the names of only two persons are submitted and the number of votes for each such person is equal, the scrutineers shall by drawing lots determine which of such persons shall be chosen to hold the vacant place, and the person whose name shall be first drawn shall be deemed to have been duly chosen.

(k) Until one of the persons proposed obtains an absolute majority of the votes cast, or (as the case may be) is chosen by lot to hold the vacant place, successive ballots shall be taken, and at each such ballot the name of the person who receives the fewest votes at the preceding ballot shall be excluded.

(l) If on any ballot it is necessary to decide which of two or more persons is to be excluded from a subsequent ballot because of the number of votes for such persons being equal, a special ballot shall be taken at which the names of only those persons shall be submitted, and the name of the person having the fewest votes at such special ballot shall be excluded; but if on any special ballot it shall be necessary to decide which of two or more persons is to be excluded from a subsequent ballot because of the number of votes for such persons being equal, the scrutineers shall by drawing lots determine which of such persons shall be excluded, and the name of the person last drawn shall be excluded.

(m) If at any ballot, other than the first ballot or a special ballot, the names of only two persons are submitted and the number of votes for such persons is equal, the scrutineers shall by drawing lots determine which of those persons shall be chosen to hold the vacant place, and the person whose name is first drawn shall be deemed to have been duly chosen.

(n) As soon as any person obtains an absolute majority of the votes cast, or (as the case may be) is chosen by lot to hold the vacant place, the Chairman shall declare that such person has been chosen to hold the place of the Senator for the Australian Capital Territory whose place has become vacant.
(o) The ballot-papers shall be retained by the Clerk of the Senate, who shall be the custodian thereof.
Conclusion of Joint Sitting

11. Upon the declaration of the person chosen to fill the vacant place in the Senate, the Chairman shall announce that the President of the Senate will certify the choice to His Excellency the Governor-General, and shall then declare the Joint Sitting closed.
Message
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans)-by leave-agreed to:
That a message be sent to the House of Representatives informing the House of the rules adopted by the Senate.

—I present to the Senate a letter I have received from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs relating to Senator Wood's application for citizenship. I also present a copy of a letter I have received from Senator Wood. Copies of the letters will be distributed to all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, pursuant to section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Senate refers to the Court of Disputed Returns the following questions-
(a) whether there is a vacancy in the representation of New South Wales in the Senate for the place for which Senator Wood was returned;
(b) if so, whether such vacancy may be filled by the further counting or recounting of ballot papers cast for candidates for election for senators for New South Wales at the election;
(c) alternatively, whether in the circumstances there is a casual vacancy for one senator for the State of New South Wales within the meaning of section 15 of the Constitution.

Mr President, the letters that you have tabled raise some fairly complex issues for the Senate to resolve. I must first of all correct some impressions given in the media last night, especially by Senator Chaney, as to the position of the Australian Labor Party in this matter. I would like to quote what he said, if I may be allowed that indulgence. Senator Chaney said:

Well this Government has made quite an art of passing legislation about our electoral system. They passed legislation relating to the disclosure of campaign donations and we've seen as this recent fiasco in New South Wales over that. They've passed a law which says-and I happen to agree with this law-that to be elected to the Commonwealth Parliament you should be an Australian citizen.

I have to inform Senator Chaney that this Government did not pass that law; the Government of which he was a Minister passed that law. It passed that law in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act in 1981. It also put a rider on that that it did not want it to be proclaimed until Australia Day 1984. So this rather cheap and opportunistic method Senator Chaney adopted last night to try to link the Australian Labor Party with this or that abuse of the electoral law will come back to haunt him.

I might say that I do not think anyone would disagree with that amendment. The Opposition and the Government would acknowledge that there was a distinction to be drawn, and it was drawn in that Act, between an ability to be on the roll and an ability to stand as a candidate for Parliament: for at that time it was thought by the past Government that it would be unfair to disenfranchise many electors who were on the roll and take them off the roll. So, if you like, that Government grandfathered it in and up to a certain point-Australia Day 1984-if one was a British subject with six months residence in Australia one was entitled to be on the electoral roll for as long as one liked. Subsequent to that date, such a person had to take out Australian citizenship to be on the roll. However, with regard to candidature for this Parliament, it was specified in that Act that one had to be an Australian citizen.

In my view there can be no question of Senator Wood being in deliberate error on this matter. Two similar cases came to the attention of the Australian Electoral Commission in 1987-one relating to citizenship and the other to an office of profit under the Crown. In the case of the lack of Australian citizenship, the Australian Government Solicitor was consulted on the question of whether the candidate had committed any offence. The advice received by the Commission was that the candidate had not knowingly made an incorrect declaration, that a prosecution would therefore fail and that the Commonwealth Electoral Act did not specify an offence of making an incorrect declaration on the nomination form. At a later point I will return to make some suggestions of how lack of citizenship problems can be avoided in future. I think the first port of call in this particular case has to be the Constitution. In section 47 it is stated:

Until the Parliament otherwise provides, any question respecting the qualification of a senator or of a member of the House of Representatives, or respecting a vacancy in either House of the Parliament, and any question of a disputed election to either House, shall be determined by the House in which the question arises.

Whilst the Senate may have some residual powers in this matter, the Parliament has made other provisions, especially in the Electoral Act. These come under two distinct powers emanating from the Electoral Act. Part XXII of the Commonwealth Electoral Act refers to the Court of Disputed Returns. For dealing with challenges to elections, division 1 covers that contingency. Section 355, however, amongst other prerequisites for a challenge to an election, allows for a challenge within 40 days after the return of the writ. Clearly in this case, division 1 of part XXII of the Electoral Act is exhausted and cannot now apply. One crucial section of division 1, however, should be alluded to and that is section 353 (1). I quote:
The validity of any election or return may be disputed by petition addressed to the Court of Disputed Returns and not otherwise.

There is a very strong implication in that section of the Act that no part of an election, other than by way of a petition to the Court of Disputed Returns, can be challenged. On the question of qualifications and vacancies, one must look to division 2 of part XXII of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The relevant section is 376, which says:

Any question respecting the qualifications of a Senator or of a Member of the House of Representatives or respecting a vacancy in either House of the Parliament may be referred by resolution to the Court of Disputed Returns by the House in which the question arises and the Court of Disputed Returns shall thereupon have jurisdiction to hear and to determine the question.

Sections 377 to 381 set the parameters for such hearings. What are the facts in the Wood case? There is no disputing that, at the time of his election, he was not an Australian citizen. Section 162 of the Electoral Act states:
No person shall be capable of being elected as a Senator or a Member of the House of Representatives unless duly nominated.

Section 163 (b) states that, amongst other qualifications, he must be an Australian citizen. I understand that subsequently Senator Wood has taken out Australian citizenship. There is little doubt in my mind that he always regarded himself as an Australian citizen. I guess that there is a very simple test of that. I ask Senator Wood: In the recent bicentennial test match did he support Australia or England? If the answer is Australia, quite clearly he regards himself as an Australian citizen. If the answer is England, be gone and good riddance! If, Mr President, he cannot make up his mind, I suggest that we force him to join the Australian Democrats.

Obviously, this mistake was not picked up because Senator Wood was on the roll, meeting the requirements of section 93 (1) (b) (ii) which, in effect, allows British subjects prior to the proclamation of the Statute Law Amendment Act 1981 to remain on the roll. I add that, along with the office of profit under the Crown, these are the two areas in which someone may slip through. A variety of politicians could have been affected by and caught under this provision. From my research-and I do not say that it is fully exhaustive-at least 10 members of the Labor Party and three members of the Liberal Party who are members of this Parliament could have been caught out by this provision. It would surprise no-one to know that after exhaustive research it appears to have been established that none of those people were capable of being disqualified at the last election. I must, of course, at this stage congratulate Senator-designate Bob McMullan from my side of politics who as National Secretary wrote to every Labor candidate prior to the 1984 election pointing out the provision of the necessity to be an Australian citizen in order to run. One hopes, and probably suggests, that Mr Eggleton and the others did exactly the same thing. I say to Senator Wood that I guess that is one of the advantages of being part of a larger political machine.

Whilst I have indicated that the Senate may have a residual power on this particular matter, it is clearly more desirable to send the matter to the High Court so as to constitute a Court of Disputed Returns under division 2, part XXII of the Electoral Act. Of course, there has been much speculation as to what the consequences would be if the Court of Disputed Returns were to find Senator Wood to have not been qualified as a senator. As always, there are a variety of legal views on this matter. Various alternatives have been suggested. Firstly, if he were disqualified a vacancy under section 15 of the Constitution would be created; secondly, there would need to be a by-election for a single vacancy for the State of New South Wales; or, thirdly, there would be a need for a general election for the 12 senators for New South Wales. Those who argue for a by-election or a general election must confront one major difficulty-that is, section 353 of the Electoral Act, which provides a course for challenging an election and provides that it shall not be challenged in any other way.

I turn to what, in my view, would be the consequences of a general election. Taking into account all factors in terms of government policy, the expenditure would be over $10m. That does not include money raised by political parties through either the front door or the back door. The Senate-and this is a more serious objection-would be deprived of the services of 12 senators for a long period. I guess there are not only down sides! On the other hand, it seems to me that the disruption to legislation, the Ministry, the presidency and the shadow Ministry, through no fault of any of the people who have caused these matters, would be most unfair. Of course, we can all speculate on the result of a general election. I have never known anyone to speculate accurately on the result of a Senate election. But even in the current climate, in which members of the Liberal Party are the May Premiers-they will never make it to September, of course-the break-up is likely to be five, five, one and one, because the quota to return a mere five senators is 38.5 per cent. So there will not be a particularly changed environment if we do have a general election.

The only time a Court of Disputed Returns has ruled on a similar matter-although it should be noted that this would have been taken under division 1 of part XXII of the Electoral Act-it ruled for a by-election and not a re-election of all senators. In this case, Vardon v. O'Loghlin, the court ruled in favour of a by-election but not in favour of a casual vacancy. As a precedent it is possible that this case may be overturned by the court on several bases. First, after the 1977 amendments there is no longer the same collision between section 15 of the Constitution and the fundamental directive that the Senate is to be chosen by the people of the State in section 7. Secondly, the High Court, in Vardon v. O'Loghlin, may not have given sufficient weight to the arguments that, whereas the Constitution specifically provided for by-elections for the House of Representatives in section 33, it made no specific provision for separate Senate by-elections and indicated, via section 15, a general desire to avoid by-elections.

The difficulty with using section 15 to resolve a vacancy in this matter hinges on the fact that Senator Wood may not have ever been validly elected as a senator and, therefore, cannot vacate a seat that he has never held. One legal case that has bearing on this is Hickey v. Tuxworth, in 1987, involving elections for the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory. In this case His Honour held the election void because an unsuccessful candidate was unqualified because in the special circumstances of the election it could not be said that the result would have been different if the unqualified candidate had not taken part. I suppose that, to distil that, what they were saying was that if this candidate had not run in such a close result the election could arguably have been different. One must note, however, that this case involved an ordinary election petition similar to division 1, part XXII of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

With the best will in the world it is going to be hard to argue in a State as large as New South Wales, no matter how brilliant a candidate, that any candidate affected the end result rather than purely party loyalties. Nevertheless, I would assert that if it can be proved that Senator Wood's lack of citizenship had any effect on the election in 1987, the use of section 15 of the Constitution would more clearly represent the will of the people than a by-election. Any such by-election would be either first past the post or preferential and thus be contrary to the express will of the Senate to use proportional representation in these matters. If a by-election for a single vacancy were to be ordered, it may be necessary to amend the Electoral Act to accommodate such a proposition.

One further possibility may appeal to the court-it is a long bow-that bearing in mind the will of the people it could exercise the following power of the Court of Disputed Returns, section 360 (1) (vi), to declare any candidate duly elected who was not returned as elected. In other words, if Senator Wood was not elected it might seek to confirm him now bearing in mind the will of the people. I have no doubt that if the motion I am putting to the Senate is carried the Senate would grant Senator Wood a leave of absence in similar terms to that granted to Senator Webster in 1975. Senator Wood, if declared not validly elected, may be required to return to the Crown all salaries and emoluments granted to him thus far. The Government would have to give consideration, depending on the circumstances, to an ex gratia payment to cover this liability by Senator Wood. On the surface it would seem unfair to impoverish Senator Wood to the point of bankruptcy and thereby inhibit his return to this place in any way.

Two further points may need to be addressed. Was the Electoral Commission at fault in accepting Senator Wood's nomination? At elections up to and including that of 1983, it was not unusual for it to be put to divisional returning officers that a particular candidate's nomination should not be accepted because the candidate did not meet some qualification prescribed by the Constitution or the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Such a situation was not only contrary to the common law of elections but also clearly unsatisfactory. It was well recognised that returning officers had neither the qualifications nor the authority to pronounce on the complex legal questions which from time to time arose, or for that matter to reach proper conclusions on any alleged or disputed facts-particularly in the short time available.

The 1983 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which we are responsible for, addressed the problem directly and gave statutory effect to the common law. There was inserted in part XIV a new provision, section 172 (1), which explicitly states that a nomination can be rejected only if the formal requirements for its validity have not been substantially complied with. This precludes the divisional returning officer from giving any consideration to the question of whether a candidate is qualified to stand for parliament. The amendment did not, however, resolve the question of what action should be taken if facts possibly pointing to a candidate's disqualification came to light after the close of nominations. In light of this, the Act must be reviewed.

In terms of citizenship requirements, we could make the candidate's declaration more explicit and also put greater emphasis on this requirement in electoral forms and literature. In terms of the office of profit under the Crown, this cannot be watered down by Parliament as it is constitutional rather than statutory. Further, we may need to review section 339 (1) (k) of the Act so as to make prosecutions for contravention a bit more feasible. Finally, provisions could be inserted in part XXII of the Commonwealth Electoral Act enabling the Court of Disputed Returns to impose costs on a disqualified candidate where his or her candidacy was a factor in overturning an election result. What we may have in mind there is requiring someone who nominates invalidly to pay not only the costs of the court case and the election but also the other political parties' costs. That should prove to be a sufficient deterrent. I think only the death penalty would manage to be more severe.

In summary, in this particular case the Government and, I hope, the whole Senate would argue that once this matter was drawn to the attention of the Senate it could not be ignored. The Senate is not the appropriate body to sit as a tribunal to rule on this matter. It should go to the High Court under the powers conferred on it by the Electoral Act. We have asked the High Court to make some rulings. I make this point very clear: We cannot suggest to the High Court what the remedies are. It will read the Electoral Act. It will know the full powers available to it and it will draw the appropriate conclusions from that.

The final thing I would say is that I think it is in the interests of everyone in this chamber to see whether this matter can be dealt with speedily. I remember the nervous tension in this chamber of New South Wales senators when it last arose in December. Half of them actually went to the High Court and missed Question Time to hear the result of that particular challenge when in fact they were fairly confident of the result. Honourable senators may think this chamber is going to hot up with the New South Wales election in the next few weeks, whenever it is, but this matter will be a far more tense and serious one for at least those 12 individuals concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by Senator Robert Ray on behalf of the Government. Indeed, the Opposition has considered this matter over recent days and yesterday it released a statement to the media which said, if I may quote part of it:

SPEECH.PARA: The President of the Senate and the government have a responsibility to ensure that the requirements of Commonwealth electoral legislation are fulfilled as regards the status of persons elected to Federal Parliament.
Accordingly, we believe that they are obliged to seek a ruling in the case of Senator Robert Wood who has admitted not being an Australian citizen at the time of his election last year.
The High Court should be asked to make that judgment, acting as a Court of Disputed Returns.
If there is no move from the government to ensure that its own legislation is being properly applied, the Opposition will have to further consider how the issue can best be resolved.
But there is clearly a primary obligation on the government to take some action and that is what should happen.
I therefore welcome the statement today by Senator Ray on behalf of the Government and the content of the motion that he has moved.

I was very interested to hear Senator Ray say that it is a matter for the court to decide because I agree completely with that view. It was therefore quite fascinating to listen to Senator Ray give a dissertation on what the court should decide. Our view is quite clearly that it is a matter for the High Court, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, to decide. We would not wish to influence the court in its judgment. Therefore I will make no other comment on the comments that Senator Ray made, other than to say that I took it from what he said-and I would seek his confirmation on this-that he has in fact given this chamber an assurance that the motion he has brought forward is wide enough to deal with all relevant issues that might arise from the High Court's consideration of this matter. I notice Senator Ray acknowledging assent to that.

Because there have been some references in the Press and some statements made that might suggest the contrary, I want to make it clear that in no way is the Opposition's support of the Government's referral of this matter to the High Court to be seen by Senator Wood or anyone else as an attack on Senator Wood. What we are saying is that there are laws in this country that the Parliament has laid down and that in any civilised and democratic society the laws must be obeyed. If there is a question at issue about whether particular laws have been obeyed, then it is a matter for the judiciary to clarify that position. That is the view that has dictated completely the Opposition's attitude to this case because if we, as parliamentarians, do not adopt an approach such as that, then how on earth can we expect the society on whose behalf we legislate and make the laws of this land to accept the primacy of the rule of law? In my view that is what this matter is all about.

We do not, in any way, impute to Senator Wood any deliberate wrongdoing in terms of his Australian citizenship. I, for one, would certainly believe that Senator Wood believed that he was an Australian citizen. A lot of confusion has been generated over recent years because of the changes to the Australian Citizenship Act requirements and to the electoral laws and they have got themselves out of kilter. There are anomalies, to which Senator Ray has already referred. I, too, believe that those anomalies should be looked at by this Parliament at the appropriate time, perhaps through reference of some of those issues to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. But certainly they are issues that, in some shape or form, should be looked at.

The Opposition agrees with the technical situation that Senator Ray has outlined. We believe that the course that is being pursued is the correct course not only on Senator Wood's behalf, but on behalf of the whole Parliament and through it the Australian community. Section 377 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act states:

When any question is referred to the Court of Disputed Returns under this Part, the President . . . shall transmit to the Court of Disputed Returns a statement of the question upon which the determination of the Court is desired, together with any proceedings, papers, reports, or documents relating to the question in the possession of the House in which the question arises.

Therefore I assume that under that provision the debate that occurs here today, along with other relevant papers, will be transmitted to the Court for its consideration. I also note that section 378 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act states:

The Court of Disputed Returns may allow any person who in the opinion of the Court is interested in the determination of any question referred to it under this Part to be heard on the hearing of the reference, or may direct notice of the reference to be served on any person, and any person so allowed to be heard or so directed to be served shall be deemed to be a party to the reference.

I think those provisions, taken in the totality of the other aspects of this matter, do give a wide range of opportunity for all interested parties to appear before the Court or to give some evidence to the Court, if necessary, and that seems to be an entirely proper state of affairs in a democratic determination of this matter. On behalf of the Opposition, I just reiterate that we welcome the Government's action. It was timely. As I say, we called on the Government yesterday to take the action that it has and we welcome its response to that request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a most unfortunate situation. I think that those of us who attended the High Court of Australia last year in the case concerning Senator Wood's eligibility to sit in the Senate thought that the issue had been resolved once and for all. It would not come as a surprise to all that many people in the Senate that the Australian Democrats have some affinity with Senator Wood, the positions he holds and the policies he fights for. Hence, to us, it is of more than passing interest that Senator Wood finds himself in this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth while pointing out that the deficiency in the technical ability of Senator Wood to stand in no way went to the heart of the democratic process. Under the proportional representation system, Senator Wood was elected and that deficiency in no way affected that election. The democratic will of the people certainly was expressed unlike, for example, in a case not too many years ago in Tasmania where some members were found by the court to have infringed the rule regarding the expenditure of amounts of money and hence a whole fresh election was called in a lower House seat. One could say that the expenditure of that additional amount of money would have had an effect on the outcome of the election. In Senator Wood's case there was certainly no effect on the--

TALK.START.PARA: —In one case.

—Yes, in one case, but in Senator Wood's case there could be no effect since Senator Wood did not know of the position and nobody else knew of it. It could not then have had any effect whatsoever on the way people cast their votes. We are dealing, therefore, with a technical deficiency which, I believe, the Government's motion rightly puts back to the High Court for determination.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking on this matter I have more than just a political interest; I also have a personal interest, because I found myself in a somewhat similar circumstance. I came to this country as a migrant at the age of four and having turned 21, and being able to vote, I proceeded to do that and to carry out all the other normal duties of a citizen-and I believed I was a citizen. It was not until I was teaching at the University of Queensland and applied for an overseas scholarship-which I won-that I discovered I was ineligible for the scholarship as I was not an Australian citizen. So I can well understand Senator Wood's circumstance. In the community of migrants from Britain that Senator Wood and I were in, there was a great deal of misunderstanding and false information floating around. That misunderstanding is probably still out there. I remember, when I was growing up, a great deal of reference to an Act which was passed in 1948 which automatically-so-called-made all these people Australian citizens. Since then I have inquired as to the circumstances of that Act and have discovered that that was not the case. But it was a firmly held belief among thousands of people migrating from Britain at that time, post-war, that when they came here they automatically became Australian citizens.

This is an unfortunate circumstance. When we were inquiring into this citizenship problem on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, we took a great deal of notice of and had a great deal of discussion on this item that only Australian citizens should be on the roll, as is indicated in our first report. At that stage it was rightly pointed out, and there was unanimous agreement in the Committee at the time, that people who had been on the roll until then should remain on the roll. That, essentially, is still compounding this problem in many ways because when people go on the roll the Australian Electoral Commission quite rightly accepts them as candidates because they are on the roll. Then we have the type of circumstance with which we are confronted today. It is not anyone's fault. It is an accident of our history and of a number of matters. I welcome the statement of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) that he and the Government will have another look at this matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is one of those nice touches of irony that all of us came back today to find that our seats were missing; we are sitting on chairs instead. TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what you are suggesting-to backdate it?
—That may be a solution. It has been done before. The Western Australian Government did it.

I am not suggesting that that necessarily should be the case. All I am suggesting is that there should be one class of voter and that if one is qualified to select who shall be in office, one should also be qualified to stand for that office. If one is not qualified to stand for that office, one should not be eligible to vote for that office. That is the anomaly, as I see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would take the vote away from the bankrupts, would you?

—I am not talking about bankruptcy; I am talking about citizenship. That may be another anomaly; I do not know. Bankruptcy was another provison which was dealt with in the report Constitutional Qualifications of Members of Parliament-a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1981. There is a whole series of anomalies in that document, one of which is the suggestion that if one is entitled to dual citizenship-not necessarily that one is a dual citizen but even by virtue of being entitled to citizenship of another country-that prohibits one and disqualifies one from office. That anomaly exists, but I do not see the Opposition rushing off to the High Court to find out whether there are any members or senators in the Parliament who may be, through no fault of their own, entitled to dual citizenship in Italy, Greece, Czechoslovakia and a number of other countries which have that provision for their nationals.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter that I am putting to Parliament is that it is a question for legislation. Senator Short today tried to assure me that this was not an attack on me. Senator Chaney also tried to assure me of that yesterday. When I came to this place, I did not expect it to be a kindergarten. I did not expect everybody to be a bunch of nice guys. TALK.START.PARA: —You flatter yourself.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, immediately the Opposition had completed its shadow Cabinet meeting, it issued Press releases to the media without the courtesy of informing me about what it had done. Opposition members have their tails in the air; they are feeling very frisky after the Adelaide by-election and they are thinking that this may be an opportunity to get a by-election in New South Wales for a single senator, which would be a wonderful contest between the two parties. SPEECH.PARA: To my mind, the appropriate thing to do would be to take a sensible and rational approach-which is probably a forlorn hope in this place-and send it to a select committee. That has been done in other cases in recent times. Such a Senate select committee could look into the Act and any anomalies and suggest a course of action. If such an inquiry resulted in a request to the High Court to look at the matter, so be it. What offends me is that it is rush to judgment and this matter is being used as a political football.

I will try not to keep the Senate too much longer, but I do want to point out another possible problem with the approach being taken. Section 376 of the Act refers to the qualifications required by a person sitting as a senator. It does not refer to overturning an election. How would this place ask the High Court to rule on whether or not my election was valid when section 355 requires a petition to be lodged within 40 days? My qualifications to sit are clear. I am now a citizen and I meet all the other qualifications necessary to continue sitting as a senator. The only possible disqualification would be if my election were declared invalid. For my election to be declared invalid, under section 355 the High Court would have to look at it, and section 355 also clearly requires a petition to be lodged within 40 days. I do not believe that there is any provision within that section for anyone in any other way to have the election looked at. I would be quite happy if the Court came back and said, in reply to the first question, that there is no vacancy. It raises the Keystone Cops prospect of my coming back here to replace myself in the Senate.

At lunchtime today Fred Daly was the only person who would sit with me in the dining room. He said, `Senator Wood, you look like me in the days of my factional brawls with the ALP. My Party issued a statement today saying that it would reappoint me if the matter came to that. I have the numbers. I am assured that I have the numbers. I have the support rather than the numbers, and that is more important than the numbers, I feel. I hope I get the numbers in the High Court of Australia too and I hope Senator Walsh is overruled. I hope he does not have the numbers when the question of an ex gratia payment comes up.

I conclude by saying that I felt, and I have always believed, that I was an Australian citizen. I felt no different as a person after I took my affirmation of allegiance on 3 February when I formally became an Australian citizen because I felt no more patriotic then than I did before. The testimony to that is that, apart from supporting the Australian team in the Bicentenary Test, I had never sought to leave the country until recently and I was happy to be here, to be a citizen of this country and to be conscripted, although I chose to go to prison rather than go to war. I was conscripted and voted and I would have thought that were I not an Australian I should have been deported rather than sent to prison. Nowhere along the line was there any suggestion that I somehow or other may not be what I thought I was, and that was an Australian citizen. I hope the Government is sincere in its intention to look at these anomalies. I hope the Opposition will support moves to change these anomalies. It has not in the past; I hope it does in the future so that we do not have two classes of citizen and that those who are capable of being electors are capable of standing for office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I speak briefly as the third British migrant in a row to address this particular matter in the chamber today. I do so only because of comments which Senator Wood made about the attitude of the Opposition to this particular matter. The Senate has been faced, if one follows through what Senator Wood has said, with two alternative approaches to this matter: to make some retrospective changes to the law, which essentially would be to advantage members of parliament in terms of correcting an alleged anomaly in the law, or to seek a determination from the High Court of Australia as to whether in fact there has been a breach of the law, and if there has been a breach of the law for the High Court to advise what the consequences of that are, by declaring that a new election be held, by making a declaration as to who is the senator elected for the position to which Senator Wood was previously returned or by making some other declaration.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray has clearly outlined some of the alternatives which are available to the Court. Undoubtedly, in terms of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, when the debate is transmitted, together with the President's letter, to the Court, Senator Ray will have achieved his objective of having drawn the attention of the justices of the High Court-whoever will sit as the Court of Disputed Returns-to the consequences of any of the decisions which they might make, bearing in mind the public interest and their responsibilities as high judicial officers. Undoubtedly the Court will weigh those suggestions appropriately.

It is also true, as Senator Wood has said, that the amendments made to the Electoral Act in 1983 have created two classes, not of citizens, but of electors-that is, those electors who were entitled to remain on the electoral roll and those electors who were also entitled to seek election to the Parliament. It should not be thought that that is the only situation in which that is the case. Persons whom the Constitution debars from being selected, such as people who are bankrupt, are nevertheless entitled to continue as electors. People who are in prison are entitled under the Electoral Act to continue as electors but are not entitled to seek election. So Senator Wood's position is not the only alleged anomaly which exists in this regard.

I draw attention to the comment made by Senator Wood that the Opposition has used this debate as an attack on him, has sought to turn him into a political football, has sought to create a climate of disruption or discord, or has sought to put the Government on the back foot about this matter-something that should not have been necessary since the Government has a clear obligation in the matter which it has discharged in the correct fashion by the motion which Senator Robert Ray has moved today. It prompts me, therefore, simply to deny that that is the case and to explain to the Senate my own involvement in this matter, which goes back over a number of days.

Senator Wood came to my office on Friday last week, seeking my advice on this matter. I spent a considerable amount of time with him, going through the legislation. While he was there I made a call to a senior officer of the Australian Electoral Commission and sought advice. I spent some time on this matter with Senator Wood in the office on Saturday. If Senator Wood wants to make accusations about this matter, his own degree of concern about it was such that when I asked him for a copy of the Electoral Act so that we could go through it together, there was not even a copy available in his office.

I raised the matter with you, Mr President, on Sunday at a function we attended-again at Senator Wood's request. I attempted to contact him that evening, using the various telephone numbers he had given me, as he had requested that I report what procedures were likely to take place in this chamber following the conversation that you and I had, Mr President, at lunch time on Sunday. I do not think that he is entitled, as a result of the amount of assistance which I attempted to render him in this matter, to claim in this chamber that the Opposition-and only the Opposition-has sought to make some political capital out of the issue. It is a salutary lesson, which I will certainly take to heart, about the extent to which one renders assistance on that sort of basis in order to have it flung back in one's face across the chamber in this fashion. I certainly will be sufficiently chastened by that experience to bear it well in mind as far as Senator Wood is concerned.

The motion which is now before us seems to the Opposition to be the only proper way in which this matter should be resolved-that is, by taking advantage of the express provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to have the matter determined by the court. I believe that that is also the most advantageous method from Senator Wood's point of view. Unless there were to be retrospective legislation, which I think would raise some very serious questions around this place about validating an act which may be determined by the Court to have been improperly undertaken in the first place, Senator Wood would perhaps be subject to the problems which could arise under the Common Informers (Parliamentary Disqualifications) Act of 1975 in terms of having any person paid out of the public revenue a fee for drawing attention to Senator Wood's possible invalid election to this place.

Referring this matter to the High Court of Australia, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, protects Senator Wood's interests. It protects the interests of the Parliament. It protects the interests and integrity of the electoral system. It is entirely the correct way to proceed and has not been influenced by considerations of attempting to get at Senator Wood or to destabilise the political process. I say that bearing in mind that there are as many senators sitting on this side of the chamber who potentially are at risk from what the High Court could decide in this matter as there are on the Government side of the chamber. You, Mr President, would be as acutely aware of that problem as I am. If the intention had been to protect ourselves in that regard, perhaps we would have been attracted to the proposition of some sort of retrospective attempt to fix this problem. We reject that because the integrity of the electoral system is such that this matter should be referred to the courts. That is why that provision is in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It is why we believe the Government has done the right thing in moving the motion it has and it is why we will be supporting the motion which Senator Ray has put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only very briefly because of the excellent exposition undertaken by my colleague Senator Ray of the proper role of the chamber in relation to these matters and his exposition of the law. I wish to comment on one or two matters raised by Senator Wood, but before I do so I make it absolutely clear that the Government, in bringing this motion before the chamber, was in no way acting at the prompting or the behest of the Opposition, as may have been suggested by reading some of the media, listening to some of the radio or watching some of the television reports over the last 24 hours. Quite independently the Government arrived at the decision that this was the best course to follow. It did not require, as I say, any prompting from the other side for us to act in the way which is now before the chamber to decide whether to resolve, to transmit the various questions to the High Court sitting with its jurisdiction as a court of disputed returns.

SPEECH.PARA: To deal with one or two matters raised by Senator Wood, Senator Wood seems to think that because there is a provision in the law to allow for a petition to query the validity of an election and that that petition must be lodged within 40 days of the return of the writs, that somehow exhausts the processes available to challenge the validity of his being elected as a senator to this place. That is not the case. The Constitution recognises that each chamber, in the end, has a role and a duty in relation to the question of the constitutional propriety of those who sit in this place to participate in its votes and, in particular, to pass laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth of Australia. It may be said in passing, Mr President, that on some occasion you might care to inform the Senate as to the propriety and validity of votes undertaken in which Senator Wood has participated. I do not think anyone has actually challenged the propriety of any votes that have been undertaken with Senator Wood's participation.

The Constitution, and the Commonwealth Electoral Act derived from the Constitution and passed in reliance on it, recognises, quite apart from the petitioning process-which is exhausted after 40 days-a quite different process. In section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, one reads:

Any question respecting the qualifications of a Senator or of a Member of the House of Representatives or respecting a vacancy in either House of the Parliament may be referred by resolution to the Court of Disputed Returns by the House in which the question arises and the Court of Disputed Returns shall thereupon have jurisdiction to hear and determine the question.

So it is quite clear, Mr President, that, as one would expect, there is no way in which this chamber can be prevented by the mere expiration or lapse of 40 days after the return of the writ from dealing with an apparent disqualification of a person who has been returned but who may not have been properly elected by the people of the State whom he purports to represent. I thought I would make it clear that we are acting absolutely in accordance with the Constitution and, of course, the statute.

Senator Wood also seemed to suggest-I do not think he made it absolutely explicit-that we should perhaps countenance the idea of passing a law which retrospectively remedies his particular situation. I did not understand him to be saying that there was anything improper, wrong or untoward in the idea that in order to be elected as a member of the House of Representatives or of the Senate, in order to pass laws for the peace, order and government of the Commonwealth, one should be a citizen. If he was not disputing that as being a good, wise and appropriate provision in our law, he seemed to be asking that somehow this chamber retrospectively alter the law to remedy his particular predicament. I think that would be extremely improper and unfortunate. The fact is that the electors of New South Wales, in going to the polls, understood in a notional sense no doubt the general structure of the laws relating to those who were to come before them as candidates, and the qualifications and the remedies available if they were found to be disqualified for one reason or another. To change retrospectively the rules according to which those votes were cast by the electors of New South Wales would, I think, not only be quite wrong but also would lead to a situation where quite properly the public would claim that this chamber is protecting its own, that it was somehow favouring one of its members in a way which would not really be available to others. To that extent, when Senator Wood spoke of two classes of persons, I cannot think of any clearer case of creating two classes of persons than if this chamber were to pass a particular piece of legislation to remedy his predicament.

I say in addition to some comments made by Senator Puplick that it is quite clear in other democracies that occasionally there is a different qualification for the holders of elected public office than there is for the electorate as a whole. The clearest and most well known case is perhaps that of the President of the United States of America, who is required to be born in the United States, but as far as I know electors in that country, and indeed the holders of some of the highest offices-I remember Dr Kissinger for example-need not be born in the United States. But one has to be to hold the office of President.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an age qualification in the different chambers.

—Is that right? That is just another example. It is not always the case therefore, and it is no iron rule of democracy, that the qualification for those who are to be elected representatives of the people be exactly the same as the qualification for those who are to elect them.

SPEECH.PARA: I entirely agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Robert Ray, that this is a matter more properly determined by the High Court sitting in its jurisdiction as the Court of Disputed Returns. I think the questions are framed in a way which will permit that tribunal-I am sure it would do so anyway-to canvass absolutely all of the possibilities under the Constitution to remedy this situation. That, of course, does not preclude the Government from appearing-no doubt this will be done by the Solicitor- General-before the High Court to assist it in its understanding of the Constitution, and no doubt we will be seeking to do that. It will then be for it, in answer to our transmitting of this matter to it, to make the necessary declarations and orders.

SPEECH.PARA: The precedent was set by Justice Isaacs, who found in the case of Vardon v. O'Loghlin that, even though someone had served as a senator, the acts of that person as a senator prior to the declaration were unaffected. I do not know what weight anyone else would give to that decision, which must now be 81 years old, but that is the precedent and I think any legislation or any decision of the Senate would rely on that particular argument. I took Senator Wood, before I heard his personal explanation, to be arguing in favour of retrospective legislation, but he assures the Senate that that is not the case, so I shall not respond to that particular point.

People have referred to anomalies in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I make it clear that when the Act was amended by the Fraser Government in 1981 those two provisions were inserted with the support of basically everyone in this chamber. It is not unusual to have different qualifications for electors as opposed to people who can be elected. What we would like, and what we almost assumed, is a fail-safe mechanism within the nomination procedure so that if someone is on the roll that person ought, almost automatically, to be assumed to be qualified to run for this Parliament. It is not so much a weakness in the Act, but a weakness in the advertising of the Act and in the declaration form. Instead of having it as point 20 in small print, the provision should be highlighted along with the provision relating to office of profit under the Crown, to stress its importance to candidates because, as I read from advice previously, it is almost impossible to prosecute people unless they nominate knowingly in breach of those provisions. It is clear in this case that Senator Wood did not do that.

Senator Wood also made the point that we are relying on legislation even though its power is conferred on us by the Constitution. He asked why the Senate cannot amend the legislation. By asking that question Senator Wood almost automatically admits that he has a case to answer. That has not been established. The motion requires that someone make a judgment. The Government takes the view that the Senate as a whole should not make that judgment, that it cannot sit as a tribunal and that, in terms of natural justice, it should not set a precedent for the future, especially if its decision were not unanimous in resolving whether someone should remain in the Senate. Therefore, we have a filtering mechanism that is recognised in the Electoral Act to refer matters to the High Court. That is as it should be. The High Court of Australia will make a judgment on whether Senator Wood is qualified to be a senator and will decide what the remedy is. Some people have thought that I may have tried to influence the High Court position. In many ways I have made no public statement on all the ramifications. I must say that a few of my colleagues on the other side have jumped the gun, so I thought it was only fair at least to put my views on the possible alternatives that could be canvassed in this matter. Far be it from me ever to suggest to the High Court what should happen.

I did not understand Senator Stone's contribution. He referred to Mr Young not being able to stand the pressure. I thought he went a little more gracefully than being barricaded on the ninth floor of the State parliamentary building. He went with far more grace than Senator Stone's old mentor anyway. This matter gives no joy to anyone. It is necessary to ask the High Court to rule on the matter and we can only hope that the ruling is fair and prompt.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 19 citizens), Gareth Evans (from 178 citizens) and Jones (from 86 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petitions of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa respectfully showeth that:

Any proposal to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all country people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problems facing rural women according to the ``Survey of Rural Women'' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will add to this problem, not decrease it.
Your petitioners humble pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the proposed Australia Card is an intrusion into the rights of the individual in a free and democratic country.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government not proceed with this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing: North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of the Aboriginal community of Wujal Wujal respectfully show: Whereas your petitioners of the people of Wujal Wujal were granted their land in perpetuity on 17th December and whereas your petitioners affirm their right to self management of their lands, and whereas your petitioners earnestly hope that the Daintree-Cape Tribulation-Wujal Wujal road remain open, and whereas eighty-four per cent of the lands of the people of Wujal Wujal are proposed to be included in the world heritage listing of the wet tropical rain forest of north-east Queensland, your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Senate and the Government totally reject any proposal to list the wet tropical rainforests of North East Queensland.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Medicare Agency: Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Council, Burnie, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners wish to retain the Medicare Agency operated by A.P.P.M. Council, thereby reversing the decision of the Health Insurance Commission to close the agency on March 31, 1988. We further wish you to know that the loss of the agency will cause us severe inconvenience and that we believe that our agency is efficient and offers a high standard of service in processing Medicare claims.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the government to hold a referendum to amend the Constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to State and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, the Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Grants: Northern Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the granting of certain areas of land in connection with the Jawoyn (Katherine Area) land claim. Specifically, petitioners request that the following lands not be granted.
(a) That part of the Katherine Gorge National Park comprising the Katherine Gorge system and adjacent developed areas and all areas to the north thereof, including Edith Falls;
(b) The whole catchment areas of those sites under consideration for utilisation as future water supply for the Katherine township and, in particular, the catchments of McAddens and Dorothy Creeks.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs does not make a land grant, under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, as recommended by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in his report of 6th October 1987, but that he heeds the desire of the undersigned citizens of Australia, thereby excluding from grant, the areas defined above.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Charge
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the imposition of the $250.00 administrative charge will:
(1) Prove a disincentive for all students-particularly part-time and mature-age students-from continuing their tertiary studies.
(2) Lead to higher levels of youth unemployment as fewer students will now enrol in tertiary studies.
(3) Impose economic hardship upon the student population at large.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Vote to reject the imposition of the administrative charge, or, at the very least, vote to impose a lower fee on students who are not full-time.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should
(1) block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
(2) ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
(3) ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X-ray etc.)
(4) ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that the current social obligations and responsibilities of Telecom Australia be protected. We call on the Federal Government to:
(a) Maintain Telecom as a wholly Government owned statutory authority.
(b) Maintain unqualified commitment to the principle of universal service and cross subsidy and recognise the importance of the `natural monopoly' in telecommunications.

(c) Ensure that all citizens and particularly rural subscribers are not disadvantaged in terms of cost or service in the provision and availability of telecommunications facilities in Australia current and future.
(d) Reduce the percentage of Telecom's `profit' being paid to the Government.
(e) Increase Telecom's borrowing capacity.
(f) Increase the use of Telecom's regulatory powers to protect the integrity of Australia's communications and prevent its fragmentation.
(g) Establish a firm manufacturing base in telecommunications via Telecom and locally based private industry.
(h) Increase spending on Telecom's research and development.
(i) Integrate the use of AUSSAT, Telecom and OTC and eventually establish a single telecommunications authority in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore do humbly pray that the Federal Government takes the appropriate steps to reject the current deregulation and/or privatisation threats to Telecom Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament the petition of the undersigned residents or persons employed in the Australian Capital Territory points out to Honourable Senators that:
It is appropriate that State and local government policy and administrative functions should be managed by persons accountable to ACT residents,
And that all Australian residents would agree that there should be no taxation without representation,
And that the Commonwealth Parliament should give just and equitable consideration to redressing the wrongs afflicting the ACT.

Your petitioners therefore request urgently that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should agree to provide the ACT with an elected form of self government which will be responsible for all the functions of the ACT Office of Administration and, in addition, for those of local law enforcement and the administration of justice.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
