QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO THE AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice as the Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police. Has the Minister received or called for any interim report from the Australian Federal Police into the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd undisclosed donation to the Australian Labor Party? Which officials of the Australian Labor Party, or present or former Ministers, or other members of parliament, have been to date interviewed by the Australian Federal Police in relation to this matter? Finally, will any and all reports on this subject from the Australian Federal Police be made public, on this occasion in full?

—I have not received any Australian Federal Police report, either interim or final, on the matter to do with the company concerned. As to whether certain categories of persons have been interviewed by the Federal Police, I have no information as to that but I would regard it as an operational matter and one which ought not to be disclosed. It is not for ordinary citizens or this Parliament to know exactly who has been interviewed by police in the course of their investigations. As to whether that report will be tabled or made public, as I understand it the course of events would be that the report would be made available to the Australian Electoral Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions. I will take further advice on it but I do not think the report even comes to me for decision as to whether or not it ought to be made public.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHRISTMAS ISLAND CASINO: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST MINISTER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to media reports of allegations against the Minister. How does the Minister respond to allegations by the honourable member for Dawson and the honourable member for Flinders, reported in the media on 3 February 1988, that he misled the Parliament in answering a question from Senator Tambling on 14 December 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am aware of the allegations which have been made, and I would like to take this opportunity to give some sort of reply to Senator Jones, and thence to the chamber. Allegations were made that I had misled the Parliament in answer to a question from Senator Tambling which I gave to the Senate on 14 December 1987. I think honourable senators will already have received a copy of my media release of 3 February. Before I continue, I table that release. When I answered Senator Tambling's questions on 14 December I had two written briefs, dated 14 September and 30 November, and an oral briefing of 10 December to draw on. The brief of 14 September contained four paragraphs, which were the substantial advice to me concerning Federal Hotels Ltd's suitability to hold a licence in relation to the Christmas Island casino. I read those paragraphs to the Senate. Then followed two paragraphs inviting me to note certain matters concerning Dr Ho's association with TAL Holdings Ltd.

ANSWER.PARA: At all stages, and most emphatically by the Australian Federal Police officer who briefed me orally on 10 December, I was advised not to release those paragraphs which the Australian Federal Police regarded as confidential. I accepted that advice, as have other Ministers when provided with certain information by law enforcement agencies. I therefore refrained from reading those paragraphs verbatim. Nevertheless, I drew on those paragraphs, both in my general answers of no to Senator Tambling's questions and specifically to inform the Senate of Ho's relationship to TAL Holdings as at 14 September. This relationship had been superseded by further disposition of his shares-the subject of the oral briefing on 10 December. I informed the Senate of this sequence. By the end of the answer, I had given as succinct, full and up to date account of Dr Ho's position as was consistent with maintaining the recommended confidentiality as to certain details in the two paragraphs.

It was always my intention to give the fullest possible information to the chamber. I table the brief given to me on 30 November, as returned by me to the AFP, with a side notation which indicates I was anxious to quote as much as possible from the brief of September 14. It reads:
Urgent that I have more for Parliamentary reply: surely most of the memo of 14/9 could be used.

It was in response to this notation and the new situation on the share register which led the AFP officer, Chief Superintendent Whiddett, to call on me on 10 December for an oral briefing. Chief Superintendent Whiddett, in consultation with my Senior Private Secretary, Daryl Smeaton, composed a summary of the latter part of the brief of 14 September and advised that I should use those words as they were consistent with the substance of the brief and yet did no damage to reputation. I table that summary. Those words, drafted as a substitute for those portions of the brief of 14 September I did not read out verbatim, are the exact words to be found in my reply to Senator Tambling. That was why I was confident that I had given Senator Tambling the fullest possible answer drawing on the written and oral briefs to me and it was that which I had intended to assert in answer to his supplementary question.

In so far as my words conveyed the impression that I had quoted every word from every part of the briefs of 14 September and 30 November, I regret that choice of words and apologise to Senator Tambling and the Senate if that impression was conveyed. I emphasise that those paragraphs, upon which I drew but did not directly quote in whole, do not contain anything which undermines or contradicts any part of the answer given by me to Senator Tambling. I most certainly did not mislead the Senate as to Dr Ho's relationship with TAL Holdings Ltd and the AFP's assessment of its significance to the application by Federal Hotels for the Christmas Island casino licence. I stand by the answer no to each of Senator Tambling's questions, which were:

Was the clearance by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) of Federal Hotels Ltd for the Christmas Island casino licence conditional on Dr Stanley Ho divesting himself of his interests in Tal Holdings Ltd, Federal's owners? Has the Australian Federal Police ever had reservations about Dr Ho's involvement with Federal Hotels? Given that Dr Ho's shares were still on Tal's register on 18 November, will the Minister recommend new inquiries to ensure that there is no continuing connection between Dr Ho and Federal Hotels?

It is well known to honourable senators that I provided the full briefs of 14 September and 30 November to the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Reith, on a confidential basis, but without prejudice to Mr Braithwaite's pursuing of such freedom of information (FOI) rights as he may possess. I completely reject Mr Reith's assertion that those paragraphs reveal that I misled the Senate as to the substance of my answer. It would be easy, and personally satisfying, to authorise the release of those two paragraphs. I could overrule both the earlier advice of the AFP to me and also the AFP's own absolutely independent judgment that these paragraphs not be disclosed in response to an FOI request. I have been invited by the media to do so ever since this story broke. However, it would be quite improper for me to release those paragraphs for my own political reasons. This is the invidious position I find myself in, but I rely on this chamber's acceptance of the longstanding practice of Ministers with responsibility for law enforcement not to publish allegations which, being without foundation after investigation, could nevertheless harm the reputation of an individual who is the subject of the allegation. I intend to abide by that longstanding practice.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Lewis-Mr President, I seek leave to move that the Senate, firstly, takes note of the answer of the Minister for Justice to a question asked by Senator Jones; secondly, censures the Minister for Justice for knowingly misleading the Senate in his answer to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling on 14 December 1987; and, thirdly, calls on the Minister for Justice to resign.

Senator Lewis-It could be debated after Question Time. With respect, may I suggest it is up to the Government as to whether it wishes to have this debate today. If it does, after Question Time it could set aside Standing Orders to enable me to introduce the debate.
Senator Button-Have it now. Leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) takes note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice to a question asked by Senator Jones this day;
(b) censures the Minister for Justice for knowingly misleading the Senate in his answer to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling on 14 December 1987; and
(c) calls on the Minister for Justice to resign.

Firstly, may I say that Senator Tate came to this Senate with the reputation of being an upright and honest man with a deep Christian commitment and his qualifications for that reputation certainly are impeccable. He is a Bachelor of Laws of the University of Tasmania, a Master of Arts of Oxford University and a former lecturer in law at the University of Tasmania and he was a dean of that faculty in 1977. In addition, he is a former legal adviser to the Tasmanian Government and was a delegate to Australian Constitutional Conventions from 1973 to 1977. Senator Tate served this Senate as a member of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for nearly five years in opposition and as Chairman in government until he became a Minister. In addition, he was Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge and Chairman of the Senate Select Committee into Allegations Concerning a Judge. Senator Tate was a member of the Catholic Committee for Justice and Peace for six years and has been President of the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship since 1985. He has a reputation as an excellent wordsmith. I repeat that Senator Tate has a reputation as an excellent wordsmith and with his experience he should have a deep understanding of the relationship between the Parliament and the Ministry.

They are his qualifications: one then looks at the responsibilities which he has undertaken as a Minister. I wish to refer to something said by my illustrious predecessor, the late Senator Greenwood, on 13 May 1975 when the Senate was debating a motion of censure of the then Minister for Foreign Affairs. I adopt the words of Senator Greenwood when he said:

At the heart of our system of responsible government is the accountability of the Executive to the Parliament. Ministers are members of the Parliament. They are responsible to the Parliament for the discharge of their ministerial duties. Ministers are stewards of a trust and in the Parliament they may be asked questions as to how they have discharged that stewardship. It is of the very essence of the system under which this country is governed that when questions are asked of Ministers honest answers are given. The Parliament ought not to be misled. The Parliament ought not to be lied to. The Parliament ought not to be denied that knowledge which is essential to the proper government of the country. There are ministerial tactics by which an evasion of a question may be attempted . . .
I will stop quoting there because Senator Greenwood then made some comments about the then Minister for Foreign Affairs which are not relevant. Senator Greenwood went on to say:

There are the occasional slips of the tongue. There are the occasional mistakes. This motion takes no account of those incidents. What we are concerned with is the conduct of the Minister for Foreign Affairs when, in answers to questions on a matter of public moment, he misled the Parliament and misled the Senate, knowing that the answers he was giving were inconsistent with the facts which he had told the Senate were known to him.

I adopt those words of the late Senator Greenwood in relation to the action of the Minister for Justice in his answer to Senator Tambling. Notwithstanding those very high qualifications which Senator Tate brought to the Senate when he became a Minister, we were concerned back on 20 October of last year with an answer which he gave to the Senate in response to a question from Senator Crowley about a decision of Justice K. Murray in the Family Court of South Australia when Senator Tate, without waiting to read a copy of the judgment of that Justice, stigmatised the judgment as `extraordinary and even bizarre'. Senator Tate thereby encouraged ill-informed, widespread and inaccurate publicity for the judgment which ultimately resulted in the identification of the parents and their children contrary to the prohibition of the Family Law Act. The Opposition noted that answer with some considerable concern. We endeavoured over a period of days to give Senator Tate the opportunity to retract and withdraw. He refused to take that opportunity. We noted the answer with considerable concern but forgave the action of a man of his calibre, of his integrity and honesty and history as perhaps some aberration.

Now we come to the events that led to this censure motion, the answer of Senator Tate on 14 December 1987. Senator Tambling asked Senator Tate in his capacity as Minister for Justice questions about the Australian Federal Police investigations into the application by Federal Hotels Ltd for the Christmas Island casino licence and a certain Dr Stanley Ho. Senator Tate in answer, as he indicated today, said:
The question asked was in three parts and the answer to each of them is no.

I stop at this point to reiterate that Senator Tate has told the Senate that the answer to each of the three parts of the question was no and he has repeated that today. I do not know whether by that answer he has in any way misled the Senate. I do not allege that in that answer by saying no he has misled the Senate. That is not where the Senate was misled on the knowledge which we have. Senator Tate has it within his own knowledge and his own conscience, and his Prime Minister could also have it within his own knowledge, as to whether or not he in fact misled the Senate in any way by his answer of no. My colleague in the other place, Mr Peter Reith, also has that within his knowledge but he is treating it confidentially-as he should. So I am not able to make that allegation. But Senator Tate was not satisfied to give that answer or to qualify it in any way. He wanted to gild the lily. He went on:
But I think the Senate deserves a fuller answer. It just so happens that I have a fairly extensive brief to fill out those simple `no' answers to the three parts of the question.
I could do no better than to read from the brief. On 14 September 1987 the Federal Police provided me with the following advice-
one should note those words `the following advice'-
on its investigations into Federal Hotels Ltd-that is in relation to its proposed development of a casino on Christmas Island. I quote directly from the advice:
Senator Tate went on to quote from the advice. I have not had a chance to look at it but I presume it may be part of the material tabled here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Senator Tate advises me across the chamber that it is not. Nevertheless, it is set out in the response to the freedom of information application obtained by Mr Braithwaite and I will come to that in due course. At the end of that quotation Senator Tate said:

SPEECH.PARA: That is the end of the advice to me on 14 September.

That is simply not true; there is no question about it. I now turn to the material provided to a member of parliament, Mr Ray Braithwaite, under the Freedom of Information Act. There is a briefing document from an officer on behalf of the Commissioner of Police in which the issue is set out and which contains the four paragraphs that Senator Tate read into the Hansard. On the second page there is a blank space, and written across that blank space are the following words: `Deleted section concerning Dr Ho'. So Senator Tate apparently had before him two or three paragraphs, about half a page of information, concerning Dr Ho. That was what the question was all about. But he told the Senate:
That is the end of the advice to me on 14 September.
I seek leave to table this document which is dated 14 September 1987, signed by R. Farmer, Deputy Commissioner, Operations, for R. A. Grey, Commissioner of Police.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and table the document. Senator Tate continued:

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 November the Federal Police provided me with further advice following allegations in Parliament on 27 October regarding a director of Federal Hotels Ltd and his association with persons and companies of alleged ill-repute. The AFP informed me that as a result of these allegations a number of Federal Hotels directors were re-interviewed. Those inquiries did not, however, alter the findings of the earlier advice given to me.

At that stage all senators present believed that Senator Tate had picked up his brief and read to us from it. Senator Tate added some more words to his answer, but in due course Senator Tambling asked Senator Tate to table the paper from which he was reading. In response Senator Tate said:
No, I will not table those reports.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —again, misleading the Parliament-then said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief, which is directly, and without any modification or deletion by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September and 30 November.

There can be no doubt that that was a deliberate misleading of the Senate. Senator Tate quite deliberately had not quoted from part of the report. He said that that was for a very good reason. That may very well be so, but the fact is that he did not quote from it, yet he told the Senate:
I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief, which is directly, and without any modification or deletion by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September and 30 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is clearly untrue.

—As my colleague Senator Chaney says, that is clearly untrue. There can be no doubt about it. Truth is the one simple basis on which this Parliament exists. With the knowledge we have today, it is clear that the answer was not true and that the Minister deliberately misled the Senate. That occurred on 14 December. The Senate rose on 18 December. So the Minister had four days in which he could have come back and said, `In that answer I really did not make it clear that I did have some more information which I had been told to keep confidential, so I really did not give a full answer. There was some additional information in my brief about which I did not tell the Senate'. He had four days-during which time his officers must have drawn his attention to what he said-in which to consider the matter and tell the Senate that he had made a mistake, that he did not mean to do it, that there was some explanation as to why he did it in that way, and that he did not really mean to mislead the Senate. But no; Senator Tate did not take that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: What did he do? In due course he discovered that Ray Braithwaite, a member of the House of Representatives, was not satisfied and that he had made an application under the freedom of information legislation for disclosure of this report. Faced with that application, Senator Tate knew that the truth must then come out. With the clear knowledge that he was about to be found out, Senator Tate offered to tell us the truth, or some part of the truth. On 3 February he issued a media release which restated the misleading advice that he had given to the Senate. It reads:
By the end of the answer I had given as succinct, full and up-to-date account of Dr Ho's position-
Senator Tate finally qualified his answer by adding-
as was consistent with maintaining the recommended confidentiality as to certain details in the two paragraphs.

So he finally exposed the fact that he did have some confidential information which he was not prepared to reveal to the Senate and which may have been relevant to the answer which he gave to the Senate. It is a great pity that Senator Tate did not say that in his answer to the Senate, but the truth of the matter is that he misled the Senate. But he did say in that media release-and I presume he went on to say it in the documents he tabled earlier today:
In so far as my words conveyed the impression that I had quoted every word from every part of the briefs of 14 September and 30 November, I regret that choice of words . . .

He quite simply acknowledged that he had not quoted every word of the brief, but that he had conveyed the impression that he had quoted every word of it. I turn to some supporting information. At the same time, in an endeavour to cover his tracks, Senator Tate offered my colleague in the other place, Mr Peter Reith, the opportunity to view the brief. Senator Tate believed that that would clear him. Mr Reith has made a statutory declaration about that. It sets out the history of how this information happened to be provided to him. Paragraph 7 of the statutory declaration states:
Senator Tate has claimed that the two paragraphs-
that is how I know that there are two paragraphs; earlier I had not appreciated how I knew that-
which have remained confidential support his explicit answer to the question in the Senate.
Paragraph 8 states:

After I received the document from Senator Tate I came to the conclusion that it did not support his claim that he had not misled the Parliament. As I was concerned about the matter, I rang the Senator to discuss it with him and to tell him that I could not in all honesty accept his claim. I said to him that any reasonable person reading the document would have to agree that my interpretation was not unreasonable. About half an hour or thereabouts after that first phone call the Senator rang me back to say that he had, since our last conversation, had further discussions with the Australian Federal Police to confirm his interpretation of the document. I responded that the fact that the Minister had felt a need to ring the Australian Federal police only confirmed in my mind that the alternative interpretation that I had put to the Minister was obviously open on any reasonable reading of the document.
Paragraph 9 states:
In my view the Minister has misled the Senate.
I seek leave to table a copy of the statutory declaration of Peter Keaston Reith.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the document.
—It is quite clear he misled the Senate twice in the one answer.

—As Senator Chaney is saying across the table to Senator Button, it is quite clear that the Minister misled the Senate twice in one answer. For all we know he may have misled the Senate thrice and misled us again today. Having read the report by Mr Farmer of the Federal Police, the two paragraphs deleted and the words `deleted section concerning Dr Ho', I have great difficulty in believing the honour- able senator's answer to the question, `Have the Australian Federal Police ever had reservations about Dr Ho's involvement with Federal Hotels?' which is no. I am not accusing him. But on the basis of the simple, intellectual application of fundamental principles, it is very strange to have those two paragraphs deleted and for Senator Tate to say that the answer to the question `Have the Australian Federal Police ever had reservations about Dr Ho's involvement with Federal Hotels?' is no.
—Why is that?

—I do not know. It is entirely within Senator Tate's knowledge. He is keeping it to himself. I am making my allegations in relation to the matters where we have on the record clear evidence that he misled the Senate twice in the one answer. This is a matter not of semantics but of substance. The Minister's answers were misleading and misled the Parliament. On his own admission today, on the documents he has tabled and on his answer to the question, he misled the Parliament. He acknowledges that he misled the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about the fundamental responsibility of a Minister not to lie to or mislead the Parliament. Let me remind the Senate of what Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said in his letter to the Governor-General when he recommended the dismissal of the late Mr Rex Connor:

I took this course in order to uphold a precise and fundamental principle of parliamentary government. The principle is that the Parliament must be able to accept assurances given to it by a Minister and if those assurances prove to be misleading the Minister concerned must be held responsible.

That was a former Labor Prime Minister. I can recall Australian Labor Party senators, when they were on this side of the chamber, calling for the resignation of the then Attorney-General Senator Peter Durack for something which had happened in a remote branch office of his department, of which he had no direct knowledge and over which he had no direct control. But those subtleties about ministerial responsibility seem to have escaped members of the Australian Labor Party now that they are in office. Here is a deliberate act by the Minister, with the brief in front of him. It was not some mere oversight, not something he failed to remember in the hurly-burly of Question Time. He had the brief in front of him and he quite deliberately misled the Parliament.

Even the Australian Labor Party has acknowledged from time to time the fundamental principal of ministerial responsibility. I have quoted what Mr Whitlam said when he wrote to the Governor-General, but let me also quote something else Mr Whitlam said when he was dealing with Mr Cairns. I quote from page 356 of a book called A Certain Grandeur by Graham Freudenberg:
In a letter to Whitlam on 2 July Cairns wrote:

I answered the question in Parliament on June 4th, 1975, consistently with my recollection of these events. I answered the question as I did, believing that I spoke the truth. I have no recollection at all of having signed the letter quoted in your press statement, and I have a clear recollection that I rejected it because I found it unacceptable.
I do not intend to resign from any position I hold because I answered the question in Parliament in the clear and sincere belief that what I said was true.
Here is a case where a Minister believed what he said was true. What did Mr Whitlam do? He replied immediately, saying:
I do not regard these documents as satisfactory explanations of the two issues which I put to you.
Since you write that you do not intend to resign from any position you hold, I must advise the Governor-General to terminate your commission. He will receive me at 8 o'clock this evening.

The same book, A Certain Grandeur by Graham Freudenberg, deals with the dismissal of Mr Connor. Honourable senators will recall that what had happened was that Mr Connor was continuing to be in communication with Mr Khemlani after he should have stopped being in communication with Mr Khemlani. Freudenberg writes:

. . . these things had become plain: Connor had not complied with Whitlam's repeated and insistent requests, rising to demands, for all relevant information; he had obviously failed to inform Khemlani that his authority to raise a loan had been revoked; his public denial could not be sustained; and, most important of all; he had let Whitlam make a statement, on record in Hansard, which was untrue.
Freudenberg goes on to quote Mr Whitlam's statement of 14 October in which he said:

I wish to make it absolutely clear that the reason for my decision rests solely and wholly on the matter of the answer I was led to give last Thursday. It is a precise, clearly defined issue. I have made it clear throughout the life of this Government that there is the one standard which, once departed from, must carry the heaviest penalty. It is a principle on which the integrity of Parliament itself depends.

There was, I believe, a departure caused, from that principle. The principle and my insistence upon it was made amply clear, tragically clear, only three months ago in the case of the honourable member for Lalor.
That is, Cairns. The statement continues:

In that case and in this, there was and is, no reflection whatsoever on the personal integrity of the Minister involved. The error of judgment in both cases was the same; the consequences of that error of judgment, the same. But let me emphasize, those consequences spring not from misconduct, but from standards in relation to a narrow, precise but fundamentally important principle which this Government and I as head of this Government must insist upon.

That is what Mr Whitlam said. Compare that with what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said when he came to the defence of Senator Tate-`He is a man of integrity'. That is not relevant. That is not being dealt with in any way. Mr Hawke said:
I am totally satisfied that Senator Tate has not acted in bad faith.

That is not relevant. He went on to say that he could not believe that there was any question of Senator Tate's integrity. That is not relevant. It is not the question. It is a question not of whether Senator Tate acted in bad faith but of whether he deliberately misled the Senate. It is not a question of whether he is a nice bloke, whether we are sorry for him, whether we have some sympathy for him or whether we could all fall into the same trap. It is a question of whether he deliberately misled the Senate. On his own admission and on the papers here he deliberately misled the Senate, not once, but twice. He should have resigned. He should have tendered his resignation. It may be that the Prime Minister, the way he is going at present, might not have accepted it, but Senator Tate should have tendered his resignation. Even Mr Brown resigned. Mr Brown claimed that he did not mislead Parliament deliberately. I cannot find very quickly Mr Brown's words. In any event, Mr Brown claimed that he had misled the Parliament but did not mean to do so. But he still resigned. I say that Senator Tate, with the brief in front of him, deliberately misled the Senate, and that if the former Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam, was still here he would have sacked the Minister. Senator Tate's failure to resign leaves his reputation and his integrity as a Minister in tatters and brings into question the whole concept of ministerial responsibility under this Government. I feel sorry for him, but he will have to live with it. He will have to live with his own conscience if he does not take the honourable course and resign.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear that Senator Lewis is reading a book called A Certain Grandeur. I commend it. It is probably being remaindered now, but it is a very good book for somebody such as Senator Lewis to read, because if there is one thing that we can say about this motion it is that there is not a whiff of a sense of grandeur about it. It is a petty, grubby exercise by an opposition party which, as its President said quite recently, was not fit to govern at the last election and it is still not fit to govern. Today, when there are big issues confronting this country, it comes in here with this silly little exercise. I remind Senator Lewis that he is not prosecuting drunks in the Warrnambool police courts with this sort of motion. It is not sufficient for him to come in here and say, `My rah rah boys think Senator Tate misled the Parliament', and for Senator Chaney to interject, `Yes, he misled the Parliament'. Peter Reith, for goodness sake, filed a statutory declaration saying that the Minister misled the Parliament. I would think what Peter Reith thinks about this issue would be very persuasive evidence before an impartial tribunal! Who in this Parliament had heard of Peter Reith before this statutory declaration was filed? I understand he is the shadow Attorney-General, for goodness sake. Who has ever heard of him and who ever will, apart from through his statutory declaration?

SPEECH.PARA: The structure of Senator Lewis's speech-and I congratulate him; it had a structure-began by his setting out of Senator Tate's qualifications. They are very good qualifications, excellent qualifications. Senator Lewis was mesmerised by them and devoted a lot of time to Senator Tate's qualifications. He went on, with respect-and I do not mean this in any personal sense-to reveal his own lack of qualifications in prosecuting this case which he is trying to put. He finished his speech with some recitation of high authority from the oracles of the past-various Prime Ministers of Labor persuasion, as I recall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does your Government not accept that telling the truth in Parliament is a requirement?
—Yes, and on television, such as last night.
—Do you accept that?
—Yes, we accept that, and that Leaders of the Opposition in the Senate should not mislead the people of Australia on television, as the honourable senator did last night.
—Don't talk nonsense.

—It is exactly the same sort of quibble-like little issue, Senator. The issue is contained in page 2981 of the Hansard of 14 December 1987. Senator Lewis can bring in photocopied documents and brandish them around or do what he likes, but the issue is contained in that page of the Hansard. Senator Tate was asked three questions--
—And he lied twice.
—Senator Archer's opinion is always useful in these matters. Senator Tate was asked three questions and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the answer to each of them is no.

If I have any criticism of Senator Tate, I would think that that is all the answer the question deserved-no, no, no. It is not alleged by Senator Lewis for a moment that `no, no, no' is a wrong answer. He floated some suspicions about what the Australian Federal Police might think of Dr Ho, or something like that, but it is not alleged by Senator Lewis that `no, no, no' is not a correct answer. Senator Tate went on to say:
. . . I think the Senate deserves a fuller answer.

If we follow down the first column of the Hansard of that day we see that Senator Tate sets out in smaller print the answer which he gave, quoting directly, he says, from advice. At the end of that quotation he said:
That is the end of the advice to me on 14 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it wasn't.
—Senator, get out the Hansard and look at it.
—I've got it in front of me.
—I am talking to Senator Walters. I know the honourable senator has to supplement her intellect at every possible time, but I am referring to Senator Walters at the moment. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 November the Federal Police provided me with further advice following allegations in Parliament on 27 October . . .

In the second column of that page of the Hansard he dealt with the issues which the Federal Police had advised him were matters which were confidential and should not be mentioned in the Parliament. I think that is a very important principle for a Minister to follow. It is very important that he should do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't he tell the Senate that? It is a simple thing he could have done.
—Senator Tate will be--
—Instead he said, `That is all my advice'.

—No, the honourable senator is misreading it already. `That is the end of the advice to me' is the end of the advice which is quoted in smaller print. He went on to put the thing in chronological perspective, which relates to later advice on 30 November and the advice of 14 September which was given to him in confidence. He was saying, `That is the end of my brief. I also want to tell you, in the interests of doing all I can in respect of revealing information to the Parliament, that the matter of Dr Ho's relationship with Federal Hotels Ltd and so on has been raised'. In that second column on page 2981 he says as much as he can, having consulted with the Federal Police about what it thinks is appropriate and what is appropriately confidential.

SPEECH.PARA: The next bit which Senator Lewis takes exception to-and I concede it is an important bit-is when Senator Tambling asks a supplementary question and asks Senator Tate to table the AFP reports on Federal Hotels and Senator Tate says, `No, I will not table those reports'. I believe that to be a totally appropriate answer. Senator Tate said:
I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief-
that is the answer which is given in smaller print in the first column on page 2981 and the supplement which he gave in relation to the confidential matters-
which is directly, and without any modification or deletion by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September and 30 November.
Deletion by whom is the issue. Senator Lewis has tabled a document which shows-

—I understand that. That is a deletion; it was not by him.
