SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a censure motion about Senator Michael Tate, a man from whom we expect so much more. His qualifications and experience have been well outlined. They have been put before us. With those qualifications and experiences he is a man from whom we expect a lot. He is a man who has demonstrated high principles, honesty and morals. But the pristine character of Senator Tate has been damaged and flawed by his deliberate actions that took place in this chamber on 14 December. But it is not just Senator Tate that we are talking about. A minute ago Senator Button was saying that the issue was being trivialised. It is not a trivial matter when we are talking about censuring the Justice Minister of the country, one of the highest law officers that we have. He has a very special ministerial role with very special responsibilities demanding special integrity. Obviously, Senator Tate was appointed because he was seen to have those qualifications. But the 14 December has meant that the community can no longer ably and confidently rely on the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or the Justice Minister to tell the truth and the whole truth. He has got to be accountable for the day to day organisation and administration of the law departments. They are important, prestigious government organisations. Also in Senator Tate's kitbag of ministerial responsibility is a particular responsibility for the residents of Christmas Island and this particular issue has relevance to Christmas Island. How can people rely on a Justice Minister who is responsible for criminal proceedings to the higher courts when they are to be prosecuted? History is often a very good teacher. Let us look back, firstly, to the seventeenth century to a couple of quotes from William Penn. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . governments rather depend upon men than men upon governments.
Secondly, he stated:
If men be good, government cannot be bad.
In the nineteenth century, Henry Clay said:
Government is a trust, and the officers of the government are trustees; and both the trust and the trustees are created for the benefit of the people.
Perhaps a little bit more up to date and a little bit more relevant, speaking on justice, is the quote made by Lord Justice Ackner, who stated:
Convenience and justice are often not on speaking terms.

Very obviously on 14 December convenience and justice were not on speaking terms because they did not line up. If we look at the list of failed Ministers of the Hawke regime-there has now been a number of them-it points up the weaknesses in the ministerial control of the Hawke Government. Uren and Gietzelt have now joined the geriatric faction of the Labor Party of Australia; Grimes and Hurford have opted out and taken lucrative diplomatic postings; Cohen is playing the domino game and has been dumped ingloriously. Under the pretext of `It's time to go' what were Ryan and Young doing? They were chickening out before the Titanic sank. I am sure that in the next few months in the Estimates committees and in the debates in this Parliament we will see a number of their mistakes become apparent. They have, very obviously, contributed to the loss of status of the Hawke Government. But what disappoints me more with Mr Hawke is that he has obviously lost control of his Ministry and of where he is going, even on this particular issue. Today in a question in the House of Representatives Mr Hawke was asked whether he was fully au fait with the actions of Senator Tate. He said:
Senator Tate did not give incorrect information to the Parliament . . . Senator Tate was required for reasons of confidentiality to summarise part of that advice.

If we look through the full statement made by Mr Hawke, it shows that he has not got a grasp on what happened on 14 December or on 3 February. In two questions today Mr Howard asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) whether he had read the documents made available by Senator Tate to his opposite number on the front bench, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). What was Hawke's reply? It was, `Madam Speaker, I haven't seen the document'. The document has been in front of him, particularly in this month of February, because of the controversy it has created.

Mr Brown, the other failed ministerial member of the Australian Labor Party, pulled out late last year in circumstances which were very questionable. What did he say when he claimed that he had misled the Parliament in good faith? He said that `inadvertently, honestly, innocently, technically' he misled it. But he resigned. Senator Tate untruthfully misled this Parliament. Let us look at some of the facts. Let us look carefully at the Hansard of 14 December. Senator Tate, in answering the three questions I first put to him, said:
The question asked was in three parts and the answer to each of them is no.
I am not yet convinced with regard to the second question. I have read the files, the Hansard and the Minister's Press statements. I will read that second question:
Have the Australian Federal Police ever had reservations about Dr Ho's involvement with Federal Hotels?

From reading everything the Minister summarised in his answer, let alone the quote from the Australian Federal Police (AFP), I am not yet convinced that that question has been answered. It is even more confusing to look further down the Hansard report where the Minister says:
I understand that on 14 May 1987 his fellow directors of Federal Hotels Ltd voted Dr Ho off the board. At the time of AFP advice on 14 September, Dr Ho had resigned as a director . . .

What is the difference between the dates? When did Dr Ho resign and when was this pulled up? What is the sin of Senator Tate in this instance? I will quote directly from him. After reading the AFP advice, he says:
That is the end of the advice to me on 14 September.
Further down, where Senator Tate analysed more of the information, he said:
. . . and without any modification or deletion by me . . .

I am quoting what the Minister said. That is totally untrue. The Minister made an apology to me and the Senate in a Press release on 3 February. I believe that that was a very weak and ineffectual answer. He was hiding behind the skirts of the Australian Federal Police. It leads me to wonder further, because I cannot get satisfaction on these answers, what else is being covered up? There have been allegations by people in the House of Representatives with regard to the casino on Christmas Island. Freedom of information legislation has allowed information to come through on links between Federal Hotels Ltd, Ansett and the Prime Minister. Let me quote a couple of points provided through freedom of information, from a memo between departmental officers:
The operator (Federal Hotels) is run by a friend of P.M.-Mr Haddad.
Further down it is stated:
I have no problem with `entry/exit' interviews with Haddad provided they are just that-interviews.
In the same document, two paragraphs apart, there is a link between Federal Hotels and the PM.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that an FOI document?
—Yes.
—He means the Prime Minister?

—I can only presume that is so if this matter is between government policemen. The Press coverage at the time indicated a supposed link between Federal Hotels and Ansett International. It was reported in the Daily Commercial News of 25 January that Federal Hotels purchased the operation of the Ansett International Hotel in Perth. And so it goes on. Allegations with regard to these issues have been made in the other place. There is a link between a number of people. Are they in any way included in the two paragraphs that have been withheld? Are there any implications? I am afraid that my suspicion is aroused because of the way the document has been put together.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that question 2 of 14 December has been answered. I have read the statutory declaration by the shadow Attorney-General, who has read those two paragraphs. That was the document tabled by Senator Lewis. I will read point 8 of that statutory declaration. Mr Reith says:

I responded that the fact that the Minister had felt a need to ring the Australian Federal Police only confirmed in my mind that the alternative interpretation that I had put to the Minister was obviously open on any reasonable reading of the document.
After the Minister had spoken to Mr Reith, he had to discuss the matter again with the Australian Federal Police. Point 9 of Mr Reith's statutory declaration is very damning:
In my view, the Minister has misled the Senate.
Why should not the two paragraphs have been made public?
It is quite obvious that Mr Haddad of Federal Hotels some time ago distributed a document to most members of parliament. I will quote from that document written after the matter first came up:

Federal Hotels understands that it is not the usual practice for a Government to table reports of police investigations but it has not the slightest objection to the tabling of the report on the investigation of the company its directors and its operations by the Australian Federal Police.
So what is being hidden?

What were the Press reactions in February? Very often they reflect the expectations and the standards expected of a Minister. Let me read some of them: `Tate admits answer on casino was wrong'. `Tate ``misled Parliament twice'' on casino'. `Tate faces sacking call over casino document'. `Tate refuses to release police advice on casino'. `Minister ``misled the House on the casino'' '. `Tate sorry for choice of words'. I do not believe that a Minister can hide behind saying that it was a choice of words. It is not good enough. We are talking about Senator Michael Tate, not Jim Hacker. Let me close with a quote from the scripts of Yes Minister which best sums up this whole situation. Hacker said:
A good political speech is not one in which you can prove that the man is telling the truth-it is one where no one else can prove he is lying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long. We are discussing a proposed censure motion of Senator Tate with regard to an answer given to the Senate on 14 December. On reading the answer given by Senator Tate, if one were trying to take an objective view, one would be struck by two things. First, one wonders why he did not stop at no. Possibly he is also now wondering why he did not stop at no. I hope the Senate would not wish Ministers to provide us with less than full answers.

SPEECH.PARA: In reviewing, as I have done, the answers Senator Tate has given since he became a Minister, compared with the answers given by many other Ministers, one is struck by the fact that Senator Tate's answers, by and large, give information. One could think of some other Ministers-and I am thinking of one in particular from the previous Ministry-who are very adept at spending enormous amounts of time in giving no information. Senator Messner is looking quizzical, but he was involved directly as shadow Minister, so he can probably work out who the Minister was. It is important, when one looks at these items, to try to take a balanced view with regard to the Minister who is under attack about a particular answer. I hope that, regardless of what happens as a result of this censure motion, Senator Tate will not take it that the best way to survive as a Minister during Question Time is to give no information at all because that way you cannot get into trouble. I believe that could be the natural type of inclination one would have as a result of this particular exercise.

That said, if one goes on to look at the answer given by Senator Tate and the subsequent material that he has tabled today, one sees that a considerable amount of material has been provided in answer to the question that Senator Tambling asked. Senator Tambling made the point that he considers that some of those answers may not be correct, and that is a perfectly reasonable proposition for a member of the Opposition to put. I imagine that, from time to time, this issue will be joined yet again as to whether the answers are correct, not as to whether they are truthful or untruthful. That is a matter of political debate and requires an estimate of the information that has been provided.

I do not wish to go into that particular item and, as I understand it, the Opposition's case does not hinge on the correctness or otherwise of the answers given. The point hinges, as I understand the case, on the last answers Senator Tate gave. I must admit, on reading those answers, that Senator Tate, up to that point, had given a nice, fair answer and then he stepped right into it. He later apologised if, in terms of his answer, he gave a misrepresentation or in any way gave the Senate to understand something other than what he was intending when he said:

I will not table those reports. I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief, which is directly, and without any modification or deletions by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September and 30 November.
At first blush, one would think that that could not be more directly opposed to what Senator Tate has now told the Senate is the case.

Senator Button has made some glosses on that and, not being a lawyer, I think that what he said might stand up in court. It would be up to the judge to decide. The substance of what Senator Button said is that modifications and deletions were the responsibility of the AFP, or at least were urged by the AFP and, in a sense, Senator Tate was saying that the answers he gave were the full answers without any modifications, other than those which the AFP urged on him. If he had said that, there would not have been any problem, but he did not say that and that is the difficulty. Senator Tate essentially said that the deletions and modifications presented were deletions that he made. Despite the fact that the deletions were urged by the AFP and accepted, quite rightly, by Senator Tate in a responsible manner it is fair to say that the deletions were technically made by the Minister, not by the AFP.

It is probably at that point that I finally reached a decision with regard to all of the items. Other items which have certainly influenced me in recent times in various committee hearings in which I have been involved and which have given me reason to pause are the problems of crime in this country and the other problems with which Senator Tate has been dealing, as the responsible Minister. Quite frankly, they are far more important than the matter with which the Senate is dealing today. These, the problems of crime, go to the guts of our community. Senator Lewis spoke to us about the motion he intended to move.

We were not able to respond to his inquiries prior to debate on the motion because, essentially, the debate came forward sooner than the Australian Democrats realised it would. We were under the impression that the matter would have been dealt with after Question Time and, hence, we have not been able to respond to a reasonable inquiry from Senator Lewis. I apologise that we were not able to do so. The motion calls on the Senate to take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice to a question asked by Senator Jones and to censure the Minister for knowingly misleading the Senate in an answer to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling on 14 December; and it calls on the Minister for Justice to resign.

The Australian Democrats have two problems in accepting the motion. One problem is-and this is another matter for judgment-whether or not Senator Tate knowingly misled the Senate. On balance, and from our discussions, we do not think that Senator Tate knowingly misled the Senate although he undoubtedly did so or made statements to the Senate that the Senate took to be other than what Senator Tate presumably knew. The Australian Democrats have difficulty in accepting the part of the motion that claims Senator Tate knowingly misled the Senate.

The Australian Democrats have made that decision on the balance of what we know Senator Tate to be and on how he has operated in the Senate and on the basis of the type of answers he has given. Unlike some other Ministers, he has been willing to give answers that are as full as one could ask for and require. In many ways his answers have provided a model for the answers that one would hope all Ministers would give to questions senators ask at Question Time or to questions they have put on notice. Honourable senators will be aware that I have put down a notice of motion today on the latter area.

The problem the Australian Democrats have with the third part of the motion is that, having decided that we do not believe that the Minister for Justice knowingly misled the Senate, we would not wish to call on him to resign. We would have been happier if the Minister had given fuller recognition in his statement of the fact that the words he used would almost inevitably have meant that the Senate would take a view other than what he knew the case to be. I again make the qualification that there is a great deal of difference between the hard words as they appear on paper and in the answers that are given orally across the chamber. Every senator has had the experience on reading Hansard of wondering whether he or she has said what is recorded in Hansard. Generally, the Hansard staff have managed to take out many of the sentence constructions that come across in the oral presentation of a case which would not necessarily come across if they appeared in black and white.

On the basis of those problems-I again apologise to Senator Lewis that we were not able to get back to him before because I understand that he was willing to make adjustments with regard to any problems we had-we are not able to support the motion to censure Senator Tate. We do not think he has knowingly misled the Senate and, hence, we do not believe he has a case to answer. Therefore, we do not believe he should resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering the censure motion against me I shall draw on much of the material I made available to the Senate during Question Time. I do not think that in many instances I can go far beyond that material. I need to remind the Senate of the situation I was in. I was presented with a brief by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) on 14 September. It did not relate to any impending events as far as I know. It was one of those matters that come across my desk. I read it and thought it was not something that had been prepared for Question Time. It was not one of those parliamentary question briefs that one receives. It was simply a brief from the Office of the Commissioner of Police. Then on 30 November I received a further memorandum, or brief, as we have deigned to call it, from the Office of the Commissioner of Police, headed `Confidential'. The `issue' was:

SPEECH.PARA: The possibility that an attempt will be made to have the AFP report on its investigation of Federal Hotels Ltd tabled in Parliament.
I tabled this document in Question Time. It states:
Background
You were briefed on the AFP's investigation and its findings on 14 September 1987. A copy is attached.

We have received advice from a representative of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) that their Minister has been briefed on the possibility that the Australian Democrats may call for the AFP report on this matter to be tabled in Parliament. This follows a recent newspaper article quoting Mr K. J. Aldred, MP, who made allegations in Parliament on 27 October 1987 regarding a Director of Federal Hotels Ltd and his association with persons and companies of alleged ill-repute. As a result of these allegations the AFP re-interviewed a number of Federal Hotel Directors. These enquiries have not, however altered the findings of the original report.

Therefore, the conclusion of the AFP about the suitability and propriety of Federal Hotels to hold the casino licence at Christmas Island was not changed. That had been, on 14 September in the brief to me, to this effect:
. . . the inquiry did not reveal any matter-
which, of course, involves all investigations into directors and major shareholders and persons associated with Federal Hotels-
which would cause the AFP to recommend against the company being granted a casino licence.
The memorandum of 30 November went on:
DASETT has advised its Minister that the question of whether the report should be tabled is a matter for you to determine-
that is, it was for me-
The AFP believes that the report should not be tabled.
It is a confidential police report which makes observations about persons and could be open to misinterpretation by the press and public.
RECOMMENDATION
That you note the preceding information.
It is signed P. J. Lamb, Assistant Commissioner (Investigations).

Having been presented with that, and therefore being somewhat on notice that a question might be coming up, I wondered what I would reply to a reasonably framed question. Clearly, I was being advised that I should regard the police report as confidential. So I wrote as a notation on the side column:
Urgent that I have more for parliamentary reply. Surely most of the memo of 14 September could be used.
I signed it `M. Tate, 7 December'-which apparently must have been the date that I saw it.

My intention at all times was to try to convey to the chamber, if I was asked a question, as much as was possible. It was on that basis that Chief Superintendent Whiddett, in response to my side notation dated by me on 7 December, came to see me on 10 December with the intention of providing me with the fullest possible answer for the Senate consistent with the confidentiality which they recommended in relation to the AFP report, and also to advise me that since they had briefed me on 14 September and 30 November, they were now aware that Dr Ho was no longer a shareholder at all in Federal Hotels or in TAL Holdings.

That being the case, I knew that if I had simply read the situation as at the 14 September brief, which dealt with Dr Ho's shareholding then, I would not have been giving the full, up-to-date, complete picture that should have been given of Dr Ho's relationship with TAL Holdings and Federal Hotels.

I recall Chief Superintendent Whiddett quite explicitly saying that in relation to the brief of 14 September, which I wanted to convey to the Senate, or as much of it as possible, although the first four paragraphs were suitable and conveyed the full result of the investigation of the propriety and suitability of Federal Hotels to hold the casino licence on Christmas Island, the next two paragraphs, which were couched by way of advice to me about Dr Ho's relationship with Federal Hotels, ought not to be conveyed to the Senate as they were because, as he put it-and unfortunately in having to say this I am conveying in some way what was in those paragraphs-the allegations were unfounded, and it would be `quite improper'-those were his words-to use those paragraphs in the Senate chamber by way of reply.

I was dissatisfied. I felt I could not stop after those first four paragraphs. Therefore, Chief Superintendent Whiddett and my Senior Private Secretary, Mr Daryl Smeaton, on my instructions, got together to try to find a way to precis as much of those final two paragraphs as was possible to convey information to the Senate without conveying anything to do with unfounded allegations.

It was apparently with this suggested form of words, on pieces of paper that I have now tabled, that I came into the chamber, together with the brief of 14 September and the brief, which we are now calling it, of 30 November. I gave an answer, probably near the end of Question Time, to Senator Tambling. He asked a question in three parts and I jotted them down as quickly as I could. From my reading of the brief of 14 September and 30 November, and drawing on that oral briefing, I felt that I could answer `No, no, no' in relation to those three questions.

Senator Button and Senator Macklin are quite right: I think I should have sat down. But we all know that if a Minister says `No, no, no', it is regarded as rather half-smart, and it does not convey information. So I read the four paragraphs in the brief of 14 September and, quite frankly, I think I misled myself. Perhaps I should read the last paragraph:
On the basis of information available, the inquiry did not reveal any matter which would cause the AFP to recommend against the company being granted a casino licence.
Then there follows just a counsel of prudence:

Should the company's application proceed, however, and persons not currently connected with the application become directly involved in the casino establishment, the AFP would need to be advised so that this advice can be reviewed.
I then said:
That is the end of the advice to me on 14 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying you were reading from this document, which you tabled today?
—Of 14 September.
—Were you reading from the 14 September document or the 8 December document?
—At that time, in the Senate chamber, I cannot recall.
—At Question Time.
—I cannot recall. But the four paragraphs finish in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the AFP would need to be advised so that this advice can be reviewed.

That was the end of the advice to me on 14 September. Clearly, what happened was that on 30 November the Federal Police provided me with further information. I therefore followed that up and gave it to the Senate chamber in the form of words advised to me by Chief Superintendent Whiddett and Mr Smeaton-although I take full responsibility, of course, for putting it in that form of words in the Senate.

In the next paragraph, to put this matter into chronological perspective a little further, I think they are my words, but I am not sure-it may be in the back of the honourable senator's mind-I then went on to give some sequence of events in relation to Dr Ho's holdings in TAL Holdings, which was the parent company of Federal Hotels. I then made the final statement:
I was advised late last week that Dr Ho has since sold all his shares and no longer holds any interest in Tal Holdings or Federal Hotels.

So it was in relation to trying to convey to the Senate as much as possible by way of factual information that I adopted those words and did not quote verbatim from the two paragraphs remaining in the brief of 14 September. Then, when Senator Tambling asked whether I, as Minister, would table the AFP report on Federal Hotels, I said:

No, I will not table those reports. I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief, which is directly, and without any modification or deletion by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September and 30 November.

At the first opportunity following that answer at Question Time I apologised for those words because quite clearly they conveyed the impression that I had quoted every word from every part of the briefs of 14 September and 30 November. That choice of words was unfortunate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The honourable senator can scoff, but it was Question Time and I was trying to convey as much information as possible. I had in my mind the fact that I had drawn on those briefs of 14 September and 30 November and the oral briefing of 10 December, and I wanted to convey as much as possible to the Senate out of those briefs. I believe that I did not try to mislead the Senate by not conveying anything which would have gone against those short answers, no, no and no, by way of response to Senator Tambling's questions in the first instance.

SPEECH.PARA: I have apologised to the Senate for my use of those words, and I made that apology as soon as I became aware of their significance. Senator Lewis suggested that I had simply put out a Press statement because, although I had had many opportunities, I had to be drawn into making a public apology. To be absolutely honest, I thought no more about my answer between 14 December and I think the evening of 2 February when Mike Steketee, of the Sydney Morning Herald, contacted my office and then contacted me personally that same evening. I had had no reason to think that anything was untoward in the answer. It just had not occurred to me. I certainly had not tried to cover up in the interim period, and certainly had not tried to cover up anything in light of a freedom of information (FOI) request. I think the FOI request came to my office first and I conveyed it to the AFP some time in mid-December, following which I gave it no more thought. That was never a matter of concern to me. Indeed, it is interesting that in relation to FOI requests and quite independently of the decision that I had made on advice from the AFP, the AFP, using the criteria laid down by the Freedom of Information Act, itself came to the conclusion that those two paragraphs should be deleted.

So, as I say, I had no thought in my mind between 14 December and 2 February that anything was gravely amiss in the answer that I had given. Yet I now see that those words did convey the wrong impression that I had quoted verbatim every jot and tittle of that particular brief of 14 September when in fact what I had done, accepting the advice of the AFP, was to give a precis which to my mind was a substitute for those two paragraphs of the brief of 14 September. But it was a substitute and not in any way a modification which led to the wrong impression being given to Senator Tambling as to the relationship between Dr Ho and Federal Hotels so far as it bore on the propriety of Federal Hotels as a potential licence holder for the casino on Christmas Island. There was nothing in the summary I offered to the Senate which covered up or tried to hide or mislead the chamber in any way about the information that was given to me by the AFP in those two paragraphs of the brief of 14 September as supplemented by the brief of 30 November and the oral advice from Chief Superintendent Whiddett on 10 December.

I made a few notes as honourable senators spoke, but I think I have covered most of the matters raised. I reiterate that I find myself in a difficult position in that the two paragraphs I did make available to Mr Peter Reith on a confidential basis have apparently been read by him in a way which has led him to the conclusion that I misled the Senate as to whether the Federal Police had reservations about Dr Ho's relationship with Federal Hotels insofar as that would affect the propriety and capacity of Federal Hotels to be the licence holder for the casino on Christmas Island. I assure the Senate that it would be comforting for me to release those two paragraphs but, as I say, I did not originally think they ought to be released, and the AFP's own independent judgment in relation to the FOI request has more or less confirmed that position. My releasing the two paragraphs just because I am in some political difficulty would undermine not only my argument but also the whole stance of a Minister who at times receives confidential information which he ought not make available publicly for fear of damaging the reputation of those against whom allegations of impropriety are made but which are found not to have any substance. It is clear I do not think I should make these paragraphs available simply for my own political interests. I do apologise, as I say-I do not know whether I can do any more-to the Senate for that choice of words. I have tried to explain how it came about that I believed I had given to the Senate as full and as substantial a factual account of what was available to me on the day that I rose to give the answer as it was possible to give without making those confidential paragraphs available. That is what I meant to say, what I meant to convey, and insofar as my words conveyed a different impression I do apologise. Although it was said that I will have to live with my conscience because I have misled the Senate, I am quite confident in my own mind that I did not mislead the Senate as to the questions raised by Senator Tambling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate but I now do so because of the contribution of Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in this place, which manifestly failed to deal with the matters raised by the Opposition. Whereas Senator Tate has tried to answer the charges against him, we heard from the Leader of the Government in the Senate nothing but bluster. I believe an attempt to confuse the argument is a mark of a lawyer who knows that he has a very poor case. There is a good deal of common ground in this debate and I note that Senator Tate on at least four occasions has apologised for the fact that the words he used conveyed an impression to other people which he apparently did not intend. So even the Minister who is under attack has found it necessary both outside this place and in the chamber to proffer an apology. Senator Michael Macklin, who spoke on behalf of the Australian Democrats, indicated that his conclusion was that Senator Tate had indeed misled the Senate, and that his difference of opinion with the Opposition in putting forward this motion was that he did not accept that the Minister had knowingly misled the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern with the Government's response to this motion brought forward on our behalf by Senator Lewis is that nowhere in Senator Button's speech, that I can recall, was there an acknowledgment of a rule which all governments have accepted to this point-that there is an obligation upon Ministers not to mislead this or indeed the other chamber. That obligation applies even in circumstances where the Minister, as Minister Tate has claimed to be, is under an honest misapprehension. Senator Tate has put the view that for various reasons-the complexities that involved his briefing and reading and seeking further information-he felt that what he was saying would not mislead the Senate. The reality is that on a plain reading of the words the Senate in a material particular was misled. It is not critical to the judgment which is made by the Opposition that the misleading of the Parliament must be knowing. Senator Austin Lewis, when he brought forward this debate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Careful.

—I will deal with it a little further, Senator Collins, because I understand the risks to all of us in this point. Let me remind Senator Collins of what Senator Lewis reminded the Senator of in opening this debate; that was the plea from then Treasurer Cairns when he was in the position of having said that he had not signed a letter which it transpired he had signed. The eloquent plea from Dr Cairns, quoted by Senator Lewis, was in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I answered the question in Parliament on June 4th, 1975, consistently with my recollection of these events. I answered the question as I did, believing that I spoke the truth.

I do not think I need to quote any more than that, Mr President. The reality is that Dr Cairns was held by the Prime Minister of the day as not being able to continue in his important role in government, in his role as a Minister in the Whitlam Government, not because he had knowingly misled the House of Representatives but because he had, on his claim, innocently misled the House.

There is a much more recent example of the standards which are imposed. The recent example is, of course, ex-Minister Brown. We can all recall that a matter of less than a couple of months ago we were debating the issue relating to ex-Minister Brown in this chamber. We all know that on the production of the documents which showed that Minister Brown's answer was inconsistent with documentary material it became evident that Minister Brown had to go. I know of no statement by the Government that Minister Brown had to go because he knowingly misled the Parliament. Indeed, we had ex-Minister Brown's categorical assurance that he believed that what he was saying to the Parliament was true.

We have a lot of very silly debates, silly in the sense that there is never any possible sensible conclusion on questions of ministerial responsibility. One can poke fun at great length at Senator Gareth Evans, who posed when he was in opposition the most impossible standards of ministerial responsibility. The speeches are there for all of us to read. We have all sat and listened to him recant and impose a quite different standard when he is in government. It is possible to shift one's ground on those difficult questions-again, Senator Lewis dealt with this-which go to the precise responsibility of a Minister who is responsible for perhaps tens of thousands of public servants beavering away-some in the national interest, some not. The Minister is in some theoretical sense responsible for their errors and omissions. But quite clearly within our Parliament, as in the British Parliament, there is a limited requirement that a Minister accept the full responsibility for every act of his subordinates, when those acts are so often outside his knowledge and control. Whereas a Minister such as the then Foreign Affairs Minister in Great Britain might resign over a major blunder in his department-as I think Lord Carrington did-the generality of situation has been that Ministers who suffer mistakes made by their public servants which are not their direct responsibility and fault are given absolution by their Prime Minister, by their party and in the ultimate by the Parliament.

What we have had is the preservation of one simple and very important rule. It is that we are entitled to require of people in this place that they give us the truth and that they do not mislead us. One of the most simple and most widely understood rules in parliamentary life and the Westminster system is that one goes if one misleads the Parliament. Is that not why Profumo went? It was not for what he did but for the fact that the Parliament was misled. We are engaging in a debate which, as Senator Button pointed out, involves a very unusual censure motion. Senator Lewis, on behalf of the Opposition, spent some time talking about the respected qualities of the Minister who is under attack today. In no sense do I resile from that catalogue of reasons why we think that the Minister has much to commend him. But that is not the point of this debate and Senator Tate, as that list of achievements indicates, is peculiarly able to understand the principle under which we are bringing this matter forward. An appeal was made to his conscience. I might vary that a bit. My appeal would be to his understanding of the constitutional principle which underpins the operation of this Parliament.

I have been a Minister representing half a dozen Ministers in this place and I fully understand the sort of reservation that Senator Collins indicated when he half interjected when I talked about the weight of responsibility which is on a Minister. We all know that on occasions Ministers come into this place and say, `I am sorry, I have inadvertently misinformed this chamber. Here are the facts'. Nobody turns a hair. Nobody gets up and proposes a motion of censure; that is true. I do not have a specific recollection but I am sure that I had to correct something in my period as a Minister and I was not picked on for it. I am sure that my colleagues and Labor Ministers have been in the same situation. But that demonstrates what is so different about this case. What Senator Tate has told us rests on the fact that he was quoting from his brief. The simple charge against him does not relate to the complexities that are raised by the statutory declaration of Mr Peter Reith, the shadow Attorney-General; that really just touches on the issue of whether or not those missing paragraphs in some way indicate that the no, no, no answers or some other part of the answer should have been different. That is really at one edge of the case. The problem for the Minister at the moment is that on the face of the documents that he has given us and on the face of what is in Hansard there are two statements which are clearly wrong. The first it might have been argued could mean something else. But at the end of those four paragraphs which have been quoted by Senator Lewis, requoted by Senator Tate, the documents in which they appeared, produced and reproduced, what Senator Tate said on 14 December was, `That is the end of the advice to me'. On the face of the documents it is quite clear that there were several other paragraphs of advice. When Senator Tambling asked a supplementary question he got again what might be regarded as an overgenerous response. But Senator Tate went back to the point. He was not pressed on this point; he chose to make this gratuitous comment:
I have given a very full answer, as was contained in my brief, which is directly, and without any modification or deletion by me, what the AFP presented to me on 14 September . . .

That is clearly wrong, Mr President. There was a modification and deletion. It was done by the Minister for reasons that nobody in the Opposition is suggesting were not proper. What we are saying is improper was the Minister misrepresenting the fact of a deletion. A deletion did occur and if he had said that there were parts of the brief which he was not giving for reasons which go to character or investigation-one of those answers that a Minister has to give-no more would have been heard about this matter.

I express concern that the Australian Democrats out of deference to and respect for Senator Tate and his willingness to try to provide proper answers-I share their appreciation of that-are letting a very important principle slip by because the reality is that we cannot work in this place unless that principle does apply. We are not saying to Senator Tate, `You must be so perfect as not to make mistakes'. We are not saying to Ministers, `You must be so all-seeing in your administration that you must be able to oversee every single public servant at every single moment'. But we are saying that Senator Tate has a duty to this chamber to tell the literal truth. There can be no failure-whether it is a wilful failure or a failure caused by inadvertence, error or tiredness-to do so. In Senator Tate's case I would have to say that it would not be caused by a hangover, as it might have been once or twice in my case. But the reality is that we are putting forward a motion based on what I regard as accepted constitutional principle for Australia, inherited from the United Kingdom-an inheritance which I believe is important to be maintained.

In my view, however morally innocent Senator Tate might be-and this censure motion has not imputed any other sort of wrongdoing on the part of a Minister-I believe that the Opposition's case is utterly sound. The attempt by Senator Button to describe these things as semantics is rather contemptible. Truth or falsity can always be turned aside as being a matter of semantics. Of course it is a matter of words; it is a matter of what these words mean. It is quite clear that the words used by Senator Tate did not mean what they appeared to mean. In other words, they were not true. So I believe that whatever one thinks of Senator Tate, the reality is that he has breached the standards which are required of a Minister in this place. Therefore, I believe he warrants censure; indeed, I think that his proper course is to resign.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Reid did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Ryan.)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is there any validity in recent claims by the Australian Wilderness Society that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd Coronation Hill joint venture has been operating illegally in the Kakadu conservation zone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues to be resolved-work on the BHP leases and work outside them. In respect of the first issue, honourable senators will recall, in the last week or so, some considerable publicity by the Wilderness Society, whose members are occupying the site at Coronation Hill and are proceeding to halt all activity there. They have made a number of claims about the legality of the original leases. But on the basis of advice which is currently at hand, the Government does not accept the claims by the Wilderness Society as to the legality of the existing leases at Coronation Hill. However, to clarify the matter the Government will move immediately to issue an access authority under the Lands Acquisition Act to remove any doubt in anyone's mind as to the rights of BHP to continue activities at Coronation Hill.

ANSWER.PARA: As I informed the Senate last year in response to a question from Senator Wood-I still call him Senator Wood-the BHP joint venture has undertaken some engineering and environmental studies outside the existing leases. These activities have centred on the proposed mine project area and are required to enable the completion of a feasibility study and a mine plan and, most importantly, the preparation of an environmental impact statement, which is being completed within the guidelines set down by my Department. Completion of these documents is essential if the Government is to make an informed decision on whether to allow the mine to proceed.

Activities outside the existing leases have been undertaken with the knowledge and concurrence of the relevant Commonwealth and Northern Territory agencies. The Minister for Administrative Services will soon issue an access authority to cover further engineering and environmental studies outside the existing leases required to complete the mine plan and the environmental impact statement. It is also proposed to issue an access authority to approve some exploration drilling immediately adjacent to the existing leases to delineate the extent of the ore body. My Department, in consultation with the Supervising Scientist and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, has prepared strict environmental conditions which will be attached to those authorities. The Department of Administrative Services has sought an assurance from BHP that no work will be undertaken outside existing leases in the conservation zone until an appropriate authority incorporating strict environmental conditions has been issued.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. It follows from that asked previously of Senator Tate by my colleague Senator Stone concerning what has rapidly become known as the Young-Loosley cover-up. I refer the Minister to the sudden recollection on 4 February by the New South Wales Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Stephen Loosley-a recollection, by the way, totally contrary to his recollection of only two days previously-that he had received both the $10,000 cheque from Harris-Daishowa and the company's covering letter to Mr M. J. Young. I also refer the Minister to his own subsequent statement that Mr Young had thereby been totally exonerated from any wrongdoing in the matter. I ask the Minister: Firstly, on what advice did he base his statement; secondly, from whom was this advice received; thirdly, had he received any preliminary report from the Australian Federal Police; and, fourthly, if he had not received such a report, how could he have so categorically stated that Mr Young had been exonerated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short asks firstly how I could have made the comment that I regarded Mr Young as having been exonerated. Let me make a couple of points very clearly. It was on my own advice and on no one else's advice. In that period we acted quite properly in this matter. That is, we took a hands off attitude to any investigation and potential prosecution. It is general policy in running a relationship with the Electoral Commission that in matters that will go to possible court action we take a hands off attitude. The Electoral Commission is given a free hand to determine which matters it believes should be investigated by the Australian Federal Police and which matters should not be.

ANSWER.PARA: This is not the first case relating to the Electoral Act recently that the Federal Police have had to investigate. I instance one other for the moment-the case of a false enrolment form by Mr Hinton, MLA in Queensland. Again, right throughout that procedure the ministry that I control has a hands off attitude. That is, it is up to the Electoral Commission to put any matter in the hands of the police and take it through to a conclusion without reference to the Minister. That is also true in this case. I have not sought-nor would I ever contemplate seeking-to direct the Electoral Commission or have any contact with the Electoral Commission other than the normal factual things about the timing of the matter and when the police report would be expected.

Senator Short asked me how I could possibly clear Mr Young with the same grace, the same speed, as Senator Short and the rest of his colleagues rushed to find him guilty, screaming through a variety of Press releases, about which he knows well, to the effect that Mr Young was automatically guilty. My expertise in this area is not the best in Australia but it is by no means the worst. I sat on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform from 1983 to 1984. I chaired if from 1985 to 1987. As such, we investigated, introduced and recommended disclosure provisions. I was closely associated with the drawing up of the legislation. Any reading of the Electoral Act that Senator Short can come forward with-I note that he does not cite any section of the Act-that can implicate Mr Young I would be very interested to hear.

The disclosure provisions are quite clear. The responsibility for disclosing donations over a certain sum lies with the party agent and no one else. In this case Mr Young was not the party agent. Mr Young passed on the donation with a letter which designated things. I will not go into the rights and wrongs of that because I am sure that at this stage we do not want to prejudge that case. We will await the police report. Mr Young had fulfilled any obligations. By my reading of the Electoral Act-I said that it was in my opinion that he was exonerated-he had breached no section of the Electoral Act because he was not a party agent. There was no requirement on him to take the matter any further. I would have been reluctant in most circumstances even to go as far as I did. But honourable senators will recall that at that time a Federal Minister was being accused of being guilty before the police report was in the hands of the Government, and before the Director of Public Prosecutions would have had a chance to consider it. So if Senator Short believes that I have been a little hasty, I was probably provoked by him and other members of the Liberal Party.

Senator Short goes on to ask a more factual question, which would probably be of interest to us all. He asks whether I have received the Federal Police report. It will not come to me. The procedure will be, I think, that the police report will go to the Chief Electoral Commissioner, Mr Hughes. He in turn will consult with Mr Temby, the Director of Public Prosecutions. I think the final decision rests with Mr Temby, maybe in consultation with the Chief Electoral Commissioner. That process will go on without any political interference, without any knowledge to me. Eventually I will be informed of what they propose to do. I will then inform the Parliament. But there will be a hands off attitude to that procedure. That is the way it has been done in the past. That is the way it must be done in the future.

I do not know for sure when the police report will be produced. I imagine that it will be towards the end of this week, but I cannot guarantee it. It is a matter for the Australian Federal Police. As soon as I am informed of that I will be happy to share that information with Senator Short as shadow Minister and the rest of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. Do I take it from his answer that he is assuming that the Harris-Daishowa letter of 11 June to Mr Young and the accompanying cheque for $10,000 were transmitted together from Mr Young to Mr Loosley? If that is what he is saying, could he advise the Senate what evidence he has to this effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go directly to that point I will correct a misapprehension that is around that the Federal Police are investigating, or were ever investigating, Mr Young. What the Federal Police were investigating was an allegation that a donation was not properly disclosed. It was not an investigation into Mr Young at all, let me make that quite clear; but that is the way it got the run in the media, possibly, but maybe not, prompted by members of the Opposition. That clearly is what also, if you like, gave it the legs to get a really big run, and I am not criticising that or complaining about it. But the automatic assumption that the Federal Police were investigating Mr Young is not necessarily correct. He may have been a material witness or someone they needed to check with on some of those details. Let me put that on the record.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asks how I know whether the cheque and the letter were handed over at the same time. I do not think it would be necessary in terms of Mr Young's position that they were. The point is that at some stage-and I assume they were handed over together; I concede that-both were passed on to the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party, to the possession of the Party agent. The exact circumstances of that no doubt will be elucidated by the police report, and with a variety of explanations provided by the Opposition and the New South Wales branch as to how it was not disclosed. I have no further information to add to that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of reports that the Chrysler Motor Corporation in the United States of America is now fitting air bags into some of its new models to provide greater passenger protection in car accidents?
—There is a whole new career ahead of you.

—This is a very serious question and it is very relevant. In view of the very serious loss of life on Australian roads and the injuries from car accidents in this country, together with the horrifying financial cost to the community of collisions, are there any proposals at present for the introduction of such devices in Australian manufactured cars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report in the Adelaide Advertiser about Chrysler's plans to fit safety air bags to some of its new models. I could mention, for the benefit of those honourable senators not familiar with the notion of an air bag as distinct from the two legged variety that prowl these corridors, that air bags are devices installed in the dashboards of some cars which are designed to inflate very quickly in a crash to provide an all enveloping kind of cushion to help protect the occupants. Air bags and other automatic restraints are the American response to the difficulties that that country has been having in persuading people to wear seat belts. Many States in the United States have been reluctant to introduce compulsory seat belt wearing laws, with the result that only 30 to 40 per cent of American drivers and passengers use seat belts. These automatic restraints are intended to give some protection where people will not wear seat belts. When people are wearing seat belts, which has now become almost universally the case in Australia, air bags are thought to provide only at most 5 per cent extra protection and are really effective only in a frontal crash. I understand that the American federal regulations requiring these devices could lapse if a majority of States in fact introduce laws, as may occur, requiring seat belts to be worn. The position in Australia, as will be implicit in what I have said, is quite different. We have compulsory seat belt laws and surveys carried out by the Federal Office of Road Safety in my Department of Transport and Communications indicate that the great majority of Australians use their seat belts. The 1987 Australian road toll, while still far too high at 2,751 fatalities, was down 4.7 per cent on the previous year and was in fact the lowest number of fatalities since 1963. That is despite a national population increase of 48 per cent over that period and a 185 per cent increase in vehicle numbers over that same period.

ANSWER.PARA: Be that as it may, we obviously cannot afford to rest on our laurels and there is a continuing program of investigation by the Federal Office of Road Safety to see where the present package of Australian design rules might be able to be enhanced. It will look in its current review at a wide range of such issues, including the international standards, to make sure that we have the best that can reasonably be achieved. At this stage I have to say that it does appear doubtful whether the small additional benefit would warrant the use of air bags in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, and it follows on the answer by the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories concerning the Kakadu National Park leases. My first question is: Has Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd ever applied to the Commonwealth Government for leases to explore the environmentally sensitive Coronation Hill areas of Kakadu National Park? If so, when? Secondly, will the Minister table in the Senate a copy of any Commonwealth or Northern Territory leases? Thirdly, as the Government now states that the Wilderness Society is wrong in its claim that the leases were illegal, does the Government intend to take any action against conservationists now protesting on the site?

—Unfortunately I was absent from the chamber during Senator Richardson's answer as to some of the legalities surrounding the question of BHP's involvement in exploration activities at Coronation Hill. I believe in any case that the question would be better directed to him. I do not think the honourable senator was in the chamber either.
—Yes I was, but--

—I cannot give an answer. I will take the question on notice but I suspect that it has little, if anything, to do with my portfolio or that of the Attorney-General and that it really ought to be directed to my colleague Senator Richardson. If I can get an answer, I will.

—My question is to my esteemed colleague and former back bench partner Senator Cook, the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister seen recent advertisements by the Esso company warning of the adverse effects of the Government's taxes on the oil industry? What is the Minister's opinion of these advertisements? Does the Minister intend to take action to rectify the problems identified by Esso?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the advertisements that have appeared in various newspapers on behalf of Esso. As a new Minister for Resources I rather expected that Esso would contact me about the content of those advertisements, to discuss with me what it was campaigning about in public through the Press. But Esso did not contact me and as a consequence I took the initiative to contact it. My office yesterday contacted a Mr Glasson, the Manager of Corporate Relations and Planning of Esso. Therefore there is nothing that I will say in answer to this question that will come as a surprise to Esso. I regret that Esso has chosen to spend its money on incomplete and inaccurate presentations of its case rather than on exploration and development which would benefit all Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: I should note that substantial excise concessions were granted last year to Esso and the other major petroleum companies. Those of us in the Senate will recall, and the oil industry is of course aware, that this Government has exempted from excise the first 30 million barrels of production from on-shore oil fields and new projects in off-shore areas still subject to excise and we have introduced the resource rent tax for the vast majority of new exploration and development ventures off-shore. The Government gave these concessions in return for undertakings of increased oil production, on development of new fields and on future exploration activity. That was a sensible deal which benefited both the industry and the consumer. Esso and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd have agreed that the next review of tax arrangements should be held in 1990. Despite the tax burden claimed by Esso, the company was able to repatriate the whole of its 1986 after tax profit, that is $350m, to its overseas shareholders. Esso is now trying to jump the gun and to pre-empt the result of the next review. There has been no significant change in the industry since last year which would warrant bringing the review forward. Oil prices have declined only marginally. The market for crude oil has already been deregulated. We have been encouraging the producers to explore for new fields, and have been giving them financial incentives to do so through the current excise taxation arrangements. What we can do as a government is obviously affected by considerations beyond our control, especially by the international price of oil. But we have been taking steps wherever we can. I remind the Senate of the most recent such step, the relaxation of foreign investment regulation of new petroleum projects, which is designed to boost investment in the industry. That is the general picture.

Let me turn to Esso more specifically in terms of the question put to me by Senator Beahan. There is no guarantee that Esso would use any further excise concessions to increase exploration activity. Esso could simply declare higher profits or invest money in other countries. As I have said, last year Esso repatriated 100 per cent of its 1986 profits overseas. Our system of taxation and incentives is designed to give the petroleum companies the opportunity they need for further exploration and development. That system is clear and firm. The Australian people will see the dividends from our investments, which have resulted in the industry's own recent estimate that, this year, the number of on-shore exploration wells will reach a record level and strong levels of off-shore exploration are expected. These are policies which are geared to best reduce our dependence on imported oil. We will not overturn that policy in response to a couple of advertisements that have appeared in the Press.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the paper from which he so amply quoted.
—Gladly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice in his capacity as Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police and follows that just asked of the Minister for Home Affairs by Senator Short. I note that Senator Robert Ray said that the Government had a hands-off attitude to police investigations. I ask: Does the Minister not agree that it is grossly improper for Ministers to make statements such as were made by the Minister for Home Affairs and the Prime Minister purporting to exonerate the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, given that a police inquiry was, and indeed is, still under way? What action has the Minister taken to protect the police investigating this matter in the apparent attempt to apply political pressure with respect to the outcome of the investigation?

—I know of nothing in any statement made by the Prime Minister or by Senator Robert Ray which would suggest for one moment that they are attempting to bring undue influence to bear on investigators within the Australian Federal Police. For that reason I certainly will not be following the matter up any further. But I am quite confident that the Australian Federal Police report will, in the hands of the Australian Electoral Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions, be absolutely consistent with its investigations and its assessment of the facts and will not, in any way, be influenced in any case by any outside comment by whomsoever made it.

—I ask a supplementary question: Is the Minister denying knowledge of statements by his colleagues, Senator Ray and the Prime Minister, claiming, following Mr Loosley's statements, that Mr Young has been exonerated? Is he saying that he is not aware of those statements? Is he saying that as Minister for Justice he does not regard that as a matter of concern, given that police, according to his colleague Senator Ray a few minutes ago, are still investigating these matters which may well involve breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and, indeed, may well involve breaches of the criminal law in other respects; for example, criminal law of conspiracy? I ask him whether, as Minister for Justice, he has any concern at senior political figures making comments about whether individuals are exonerated before the police investigation is concluded.

—If I thought for one moment that anybody was trying to influence the police in their investigations, then I would be concerned. I have already said that I do not believe that to be the case, but it still remains the fact that my first answer is correct. I have not seen these remarks in print, though I have some general understanding of the sorts of remarks the honourable senator attributes to the Prime Minister and Senator Ray. Unless I saw their exact words I would not be able to form the sort of opinion that the honourable senator is asking me to form. But I was not aware of the sorts of overtones that the honourable senator is attributing to any remarks made by either the Prime Minister or Senator Ray.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a transcript of an interview with the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, on the AM program on 11 February this year? Has the Government noted the Liberal Party's support for the New Zealand tax package and Mr Howard's contention that it validates the tax policy put forward by his Party at the last Federal election? Following the Government's review of corporate taxation, will it be moving to replicate the New Zealand corporate tax structure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript in question; I saw it last week, in fact. In that AM interview, Mr Howard generally endorsed the New Zealand package. It is worth drawing the attention of the Senate to some of the components of that package which Mr Howard endorsed, including the cancellation of deductibility on personal income tax for donations made to charities; taxing the income received by charities from their own investment; imposing a 24 per cent tax on employer contributions to superannuation funds and a 25 per cent tax on the earnings of those funds. All of these propositions were endorsed by Mr Howard in his general welcoming of the New Zealand tax package. There are also the questions of tougher substantiation rules in New Zealand and those applying in Australia. I thought a while ago that Mr Howard was supposed to be opposed to the substantiation rules which are applying here. He now endorses very much tougher substantiation rules in another country. Last and most importantly of all, Mr Howard has endorsed a 10 per cent consumption tax.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice as Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police (AFP). I ask: Which Ministers, other than himself, have given either instructions or directions or have received information from the Australian Federal Police or have had access to information deriving from the AFP in relation to their current investigations into the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd undisclosed financial donation to the Australian Labor Party?
—I will take that question on notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Australian on 28 January under the heading `Comment' by Senator John Stone. In that article it was stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . and the Commonwealth Government has decided that Australians can afford to borrow even more from foreign lenders in order to increase the level of foreign aid we are already uselessly providing to certain black African countries so that they can go on attacking South Africa with Mr Hayden's covert blessing.
Is this assessment of Australian aid to African states correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even summoning up all the spirit of charity that I can muster towards Senator Stone--
—Try harder.

—It would have to be very hard. His comment in the Australian of 28 January about Australia's aid to certain black African countries is a complete distortion of the objectives of the Government's aid program. Mr Hayden's announcement on 15 September last year states quite clearly that the renewed aid program is to support the African countries which face military and economic destabilisation by the South African Government. Our aid is directed mainly to such sectors as food security and transport, which are prime development goals for these countries. Our humanitarian concern for victims of apartheid is also an important justification.

ANSWER.PARA: No black African country has attacked South Africa militarily but there are plenty of examples of South African attacks on Botswana, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. The black southern African countries' campaign against South Africa is a diplomatic and political effort to reverse the policy of apartheid. It is one that we feel morally obliged to support and we do so with conviction and as much resource allocation as we possibly can. The Government and the predecessor coalition Government have pursued, despite being subjected to periodic strains, a bipartisan policy against apartheid. The Government's aid program demonstrates our practical, as well as political, commitment to resisting apartheid.

On the question of foreign borrowings, the aid program is funded as part of the overall government Budget. The Budget this financial year is expected to be in surplus rather than deficit, removing the need for the Commonwealth to be a net borrower this year. Despite the recent announcement of an expanded aid program for southern Africa, the priority regions for Australian aid remain, as Mr Hayden has made perfectly clear, Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific and South East Asia. We are well aware of our special responsibilities towards our immediate neighbours. The aid program reflects our humanitarian concerns and our political, strategic and commercial interests. We are, and will remain, the largest donor in the South Pacific. Aid per capita is much higher in Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific than in southern Africa. I finish by making the point and putting it very starkly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so sensitive.

—That is not a compliment I would ever care to throw in Senator Stone's direction. It would be manifestly inappropriate. In 1987-88, Australian aid to Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific is estimated at $75 per capita compared with 32c to southern Africa. It is evident that we have a long way to go before we could be said to be misallocating priorities and resources, given the fundamental nature, scale and abhorrent quality of the situation in that part of the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting question. I was told by Stephen Loosley that he had found the letter and that he was going to conduct a Press conference to announce that.
