ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —That question is far too ludicrous to answer and I have no intention of doing so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I draw the Minister's attention to the debate late last year on the pesticide dichlorvos, a debate which was reported quite widely at the time in the Press. Is the Minister aware that the pesticide dichlorvos, widely used in Baygon, Shell pest strips and applications in domestic and other buildings, has been found by the United States National Toxicology Panel to cause cancer in two animal species? Is the Minister aware that the production of cancer in two species suggests a very high likelihood that such an agent will cause human cancer and is one criterion used by the International Agency for Research on Cancer to identify potential human carcinogens? Has the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) had this American report before it? Has the NHMRC considered this report? If so, what are the findings? If not, why is consideration taking so long, bearing in mind that this matter was reported in the Chemical Regulation Reporter of 17 July 1987? Will the Minister give the NHMRC a hurry-up?
—I counted six or seven parts to that long question from Senator Coulter, all of which require a fairly detailed answer; so I propose to take the question on notice to do just that.

—I ask the Minister for Home Affairs: How many members of the current Federal Parliament were born outside Australia? What steps have been taken by him, as Minister, or the Australian Electoral Office, to verify that all persons elected to the Parliament are Australian citizens? Have these inquiries also been made in relation to unsuccessful candidates? Is it not a fact that section D of form EF 059/4 requires candidates for the Senate to declare that they are qualified under the Australian Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth to be elected as a senator? Would the presence on the ballot paper of candidates who are not eligible to be elected nullify the conduct and outcome of that election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first part of Senator MacGibbon's question, I have not done an accurate count of how many successful candidates to this Parliament were born outside Australia. There is a very strong presumption, however, that for people who were not British subjects to get on the roll, they would have to be naturalised. The only way they could come to this Parliament, not being British subjects, would be to put in false enrolment cards as Australian citizens. That would usually be picked up in the enrolment process or by some other method. I ask honourable senators not to hold me to these figures but there are approximately 10 members of the Australian Labor Party who would come into that category of British subject and I believe there are three members on the Liberal side. I do not know whether there are any on the National side; they usually do not travel anywhere. The second part of the question--
—What steps have you taken?

—I have not taken any steps. It is not my responsibility to pursue this matter. It would be up to members of either chamber to pursue it if they thought someone was in error. I have absolutely no ministerial responsibility in this regard. Senator MacGibbon asked how many unsuccessful candidates there were. I made the point fairly clearly today but I shall repeat it for the honourable senator. The 1983 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act made it quite clear that it was not the responsibility of the Electoral Commission to investigate the qualifications of candidates to sit in this chamber or the House of Representatives. That was precisely put in the Electoral Act. It was not disputed in this chamber or the other chamber when those amendments were put through. We regarded divisional returning officers as not properly qualified to deal with matters such as the Senate basically is now referring to the High Court of Australia. Much as I like my divisional returning officers around the country I cannot claim that they are necessarily of the same intellectual calibre as High Court judges.

ANSWER.PARA: That protection was placed in the Act so that divisional returning officers did not have to investigate thousands of candidates who would have nominated in the last election to determine whether they were citizens. Candidates had to make declarations to that effect. Only three categories of persons would have been able to sneak through. The first category was British subjects who enrolled prior to 1984. The second category included people who were properly enrolled but who were continuing to be in an office of profit under the Crown. There may have been those in a third category, who would be very hard to detect, as honourable senators would imagine, with 10 million enrollees, who falsely enrolled and who did not have Australian citizenship.

The remedy in such cases is for any elector in the country to take a case to the Court of Disputed Returns by petition within 40 days of the return of the writ in order to challenge the election. The fundamental legal point that has not yet been determined, but which is suspected because of section 353 (1) of the Electoral Act, is that an election itself cannot be challenged outside the terms of division 1 of section 22 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The section provides that one cannot challenge an election 40 days after the return of the writs if one has not previously done so.

I suspect that if one were to put a microscope over every candidate and find that some were not qualified, there would be no remedy. There would be a remedy if they were successful candidates but there would be no remedy in terms of voiding an election in the past. Senator MacGibbon also asked how many of those candidates, to our knowledge, were not specifically qualified in terms of citizenship. Overall, we have knowledge of two, and one on the basis of citizenship. In one seat after the close of nominations in the last Federal election the candidate informed the Electoral Commission that he did not have Australian citizenship. The matter was referred to government solicitors to see whether he could be prosecuted for false declaration but the advice of the government solicitors was that unless he knowingly made a false declaration there was no remedy under the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Senator MacGibbon may want to ask a supplementary question to find out which electorate it is. It is a Liberal-held electorate which was held with a margin of 1.5 per cent at the last election. The electorate is situated in the bayside suburbs and it is held by the shadow Attorney-General. Can the honourable senator work it out from there? I do not want to give a bigger hint than that.

The case involving an office of profit under the Crown is a Labor seat held by a Minister in another place with probably even now a 65 per cent margin. I think Senator MacGibbon will be able to work out that one as well. I cannot give a legal opinion, but it is hard to see how any of those elections can be placed in jeopardy 40 days after the return of writs period has been exceeded.

In the case of a successful candidate we may have had to go through the unfortunate steps we had to go through today. But the remedy is not in changing the Act; the Act is perfectly good. The Government will, firstly, certainly be suggesting that the Electoral Commission, by way of regulation, change the nomination forms to give this requirement prominence. Secondly, we will fairly drastically increase the penalties, not only for knowingly making false declarations but also for the making of false declarations, to prevent those circumstances arising again.

It would be difficult for divisional returning officers when they are given five or six nominations for the House of Representatives to ask for citizenship papers. Honourable senators know what happens when the polls close. There is a draw for position, ballot papers are organised to allow people to cast absentee votes and it may take days to check all the details. The remedy must remain that already provided in the Court of Disputed Returns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. One of the most perturbing things confronting us over recent weeks has been the sight on television of Israeli troops following their Government's instructions for fierce and brutally forceful attention to Palestinian citizens in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Will the Minister indicate what the Government's attitude to that behaviour has been and what actions the Government has taken or will take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the events of the past few weeks have proved distressing for a great many people around the world, including those of us who have always had a deep affection and respect for Israel and who have been strongly supportive of it. What has been happening in recent times has made the situation extremely difficult. We have deplored, as a government, the loss of life and civil unrest occurring in Israeli-occupied Arab territories and we remain deeply concerned at the continuing unrest in Gaza and the West Bank.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hayden has stressed, during his current visit to the Middle East, that Israel has a responsibility under the fourth Geneva convention to ensure protection of the indigenous inhabitants of the occupied territories and that Israel's methods of dealing with Palestinian demonstrators in the West Bank and Gaza have damaged prospects of reaching an Arab-Israeli peace settlement.

The problems facing both Israel and the Arab population of the occupied territories cannot be separated from the need for a settlement to the Arab-Israeli dispute on the basis of Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries and the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination. Courageous political leadership by all parties to the dispute is necessary to secure the economic and social well-being and the political freedoms of all the peoples in the region.

On 28 January the Government announced that it would provide $200,000 for the emergency and relief activities of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) in the West Bank and Gaza. The funds will be used by UNRWA to meet the costs of distributing food and medical supplies, upgrading health care programs and other emergency needs in the affected areas. They are in addition to Australia's contribution of $1.2 million for UNRWA's general program for 1988.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have anything to say on Telecom time charging further to what has already been said by the official government spokespeople. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
—You got it right.

—Yes, I looked it up. My question refers particularly to the tourism section of his portfolio. Is the Minister aware that thousands of potential tourists keen to visit Australia during the bicentennial year will be unable to do so because insufficient airline flights are available to bring them here? Is the Minister aware that the Government's refusal to allow greater international airline access to Queensland will, in effect, deprive World Expo 88 of thousands of overseas visitors? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke- Petersen, I say that I too shall come and look at Expo 88 and I hope that there is a seat for me. The Government obviously recognises the importance of adequate capacity to facilitate inbound tourists coming to Australia and, of course, to Queensland. The unprecedented growth in tourism in Australia in recent years has been brought about, I might say, by the innovative Minister of previous days, John Brown, who in his five years tenure in the job managed to double tourism in this country, and he should be thanked by all of us for it. Due to that growth there have been some seat shortages. However, the Government has approved some 400 supplementary services to make sure that we can cope with peak demand. ANSWER.PARA: Agreement has recently been reached with Singapore and Thailand for increases in permanent capacity to commence soon. TALK.START.PARA: —I inform honourable senators that the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Alan Cumming Thom, retired yesterday, on his sixtieth birthday. Alan Cumming Thom was born in Scotland and came to Australia with his family as a boy. After graduating from Sydney University in arts and law, he was employed as a legal officer in the Attorney-General's Department between 1951 and 1955. He came to the Senate Department in 1955 after applying for the position of Clerk of Records. At that time the Department consisted of only a handful of people.

INTERJECT.PARA: Since then he has served in every important office in the Department with great distinction. For a long period he was the procedural adviser to the Ministry, at a time when the then Government lost its majority in the Senate, a situation which had not existed for some 10 years, and he became indispensable to a succession of Leaders of the Government in the Senate.

From 1970 to 1979 he was Clerk-Assistant and had administrative and advisory responsibility for the Senate committee system, which embarked upon its great expansion with the establishment of the standing committee system in 1970. The successful establishment of the committee system was in large part due to his sound advice and assistance. In this task he was assisted by his long experience as a secretary to committees, including major select committees such as that on medical and hospital costs. In 1972 he was awarded a Churchill Fellowship and travelled to Europe and North America to study legislative committee systems, and became an authority on the practical operations of parliamentary committees. He was appointed Clerk of the Senate in 1982.

During this long and distinguished career generations of senators have relied on his wisdom, experience and knowledge to assist and guide them in their parliamentary activities. I am sure that current senators are no exception. I would like to express my own personal appreciation of the assistance of Alan Cumming Thom, which has been of great help to me during my first year as President. I am sure that all senators will join me in wishing him and his wife a long and happy retirement.

I inform senators that, consequent upon the retirement of Mr Cumming Thom, I have recommended to His Excellency the Governor-General the appointment of the Deputy Clerk, Mr Harry Evans, as Clerk of the Senate.

I also inform honourable senators that Mr Tom Wharton, formerly Clerk-Assistant (Management), resigned from the Department of the Senate on 22 January 1988 to take up an appointment in private enterprise. Tom Wharton joined the Senate Department in 1966, and was a most valuable officer in the procedural and administrative areas of the Department. Honourable senators will be aware that it was largely due to his efforts that advanced information systems for use by senators in the new Parliament House were planned and implemented. I am sure that all senators will miss his helpful advice, always so cheerfully given, and I express my personal appreciation of his very valuable assistance over many years.

The senior positions, other than that of Clerk, which are vacant in the Department of the Senate have been filled by Senate officers on an acting basis pending the advertising of those positions in the near future.

The departures of Alan Cumming Thom and Tom Wharton follow soon after the retirement of Mr Bert Nicholls, former Deputy Clerk, and the resignation of Mr Peter Murdoch, who also left to go into private business, and to whom I referred at the end of the last period of sittings.

Senators will appreciate that the loss over a relatively short period of such valuable and experienced officers will mean that some of the senior positions in the Senate Department will be occupied by relatively new people. This may mean some temporary and small diminution in the high standard of service provided to senators, and I would ask senators to bear with the officers during their settling-down period. The Department and the whole Parliament is facing a period of great challenges, especially occasioned by the move to the new building. I would like to say that we are fortunate in having other officers of a high calibre in the service of the Senate, and I express my confidence in their ability to maintain the excellent advice to which senators are accustomed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

I personally valued what I would like to call the friendship of Alan Cumming Thom, and for that reason and for the reason that I have indicated, I wish him and his wife a long and happy retirement. I am sure that I speak for all senators in noting that his presence will be profoundly missed.

I would like also to congratulate Harry Evans on his pending appointment as Clerk to succeed Alan Cumming Thom. I am confident that he will bring qualities to the job that will enable him to meet the challenges of the job.

I would also like to be associated, Mr President, with the comments that you made about Tom Wharton. Tom Wharton has left the service of the Senate in the prime of life. The great respect with which Bob is held in my Party and in the community at large was demonstrated by his endorsement for this vacancy by the members of the ACT branch. I have no doubt that Bob McMullan will undertake his duties as a senator for the ACT with the same professionalism, dedication and enthusiasm as he brought to his work as National Secretary.

—Is there any further proposal of a person to hold the vacant place in the Senate?

—Mr Chairman, the Liberal and National parties will not be proposing a candidate to fill this vacancy. As the vacancy arises in terms of section 15 of the Constitution and the person whose vacancy is being filled was a member of the Australian Labor Party and the person proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is also a member of the Australian Labor Party, it is appropriate that that person be elected by this Joint Sitting to fill the vacancy left by the resignation of Senator Ryan.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take the opportunity to say one or two things about Mr McMullan, as he is the only nomination. I listened with great interest to what the Prime Minister said about the person who until recently was National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party. I think it is fair to say on behalf of everybody in this chamber that, whatever our political leanings may be, Mr McMullan brought very special professional skills to the job that he discharged. I was interested to hear the Prime Minister talk about the contribution that Mr McMullan has made to the Australian Labor Party and the views that he holds on a variety of subjects. I must say I was disappointed that the Prime Minister omitted reference to one or two of Mr McMullan's undoubted capacities. The first of those is his capacity to know the right account in which to put a campaign donation. There is no doubt that he would know the difference between a campaign donation and a maintenance donation. He would know that better than anybody else.

I was also very disappointed that the Prime Minister failed to make any reference at all to the very considerable contribution that Mr McMullan has made to the intellectual debate in Australian politics about the damage done to political parties by factionalism. He has made a very interesting contribution. We had a perfect example of this, an absolutely exquisite demonstration, in the Caucus room yesterday. We had a contest between the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) and Senator Bolkus. On every criterion, the person who now seeks to interject, the Prime Minister, should have been supporting the honourable member for Kingston. If he had been following the advice of the man whom he has now proposed to the Senate he would have supported the honourable member for Kingston, but instead of that he went ahead and supported somebody who has opposed just about every position the Prime Minister has taken on major foreign policy issues in his Government and he supported a person whom, according to the dictates of his own principles, he should have opposed. I think it is poetic justice indeed that the very warning that Mr McMullan sounded about factionalism in the Australian Labor Party was perfectly played out yesterday with the Prime Minister putting up his hand because of a factional deal for the left wing Senator Bolkus against the far more responsible and far more praiseworthy honourable member for Kingston, Mr Gordon Bilney. I say it is absolutely disgraceful that that is the case. We do welcome Mr McMullan and we hope that when he comes to this Parliament he will carry that same independence and fervour of conviction to the debates that he brings to the Caucus meetings.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Madam Speaker, senators and colleagues, those of us who sit within the conservative parties in the Parliament regard the Senate as the States House. We see within this chamber an opportunity for protecting and preserving the quality of administration that is necessary in governing a highly indebted country such as Australia. We see in this place an opportunity for the smaller States to be able to present their point of view and articulate their concerns. It is on the basis of our concern, therefore, for the traditions of the place and our intention to maintain the quality of the Parliament that neither the National Party of Australia nor the Liberal Party of Australia will be nominating for the vacancy which is about to be filled. However, I think it is worth while tonight, Mr President and Madam Speaker, to advise honourable members and senators that when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) first spoke to the House of Representatives on the changes to administrative arrangements he told it that he was intent upon increasing the responsiveness of the bureaucracy to the Government's wishes and upon increasing democratic accountability through Ministers to Parliament and the community. He then continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Portfolio Ministers are ultimately responsible for the administration of their entire portfolios and will be accountable to the Parliament for the overall operation of their portfolios.

Mr President and Madam Speaker, it concerns me that in the administration of the Parliament the Australian Labor Party-certainly under Bob Hawke-is no longer following those principles. We trust that with the appointment of an apparatchik such as Senator-to-be McMullan, who comes from the organisation, who has demonstrated a skill that I am quite sure would never have led the former member for Port Adelaide into the problems that have beset him, there might well be in this place henceforward a tendency to accept the responsibilities that there should be from a government that is no longer divided. We all recall the election policy pledge of the Prime Minister on 23 June. He said, `We come before you as one united team-the one united team in which there will be in the Ministry three Queenslanders, three women and a Tasmanian'. It was a united team in which the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) said, `I am not going to be shuffled aside just so they can dispense patronage to their mates'; within which the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) said, `There is a very simple flaw in the whole equation and that is that ability and accomplishment are just disregarded, in some cases almost totally disregarded'.

We need to remember, Mr President and Madam Speaker, that in the course of the last little while we have seen an acceleration of ministerial resignations. Senator Gietzelt, the former Senator Grimes, Mr Hurford, the honourable member for Robertson, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), the former Leader of the House and Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and member for Port Adelaide, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), Senator Ryan and, of course, the father of the House, Mr Tom Uren, the honourable member for Reid, have resigned from the Ministry. A number of other Ministers should have gone-Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Walsh, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the former Minister for Transport and Infrastructure Support and the former Minister for Transport. Of course, today the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) demonstrated that he no longer is entitled to hold a portfolio.

The point is that today's Labor Caucus is a constant grubby and greedy factional battleground. It is a contest of crude ambition, steeled by the knives of the Party piranhas. Government members fight amongst themselves to stay in power. Their policies are the figments of muzzled backroom deals and currying favour with the unions. There is no doubt that the currying for favour with the unions and their powerful mates is symptomatic of where the Government is today. Unfortunately, the losers are the Australian people. Within this chamber we wish the about-to-be senator well but we say to him that his responsibilities in this chamber will be onerous indeed in that little time Labor remains in government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, senators and members, I wish to strike a slightly discordant note in supporting my Leader, Mr Howard, and the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the House of Representatives, Mr Sinclair, by welcoming Bob McMullan to the Senate. I do that because he is a fellow Western Australian. Whilst to the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) he may be a carpetbagger, to me he is one of ours. As far as I am concerned, a good Western Australian is the best option if we have to have a Labor senator.

SPEECH.PARA: This induction of a new senator is taking place on a day when we woke up and listened to Mr Unsworth on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation making what sounded like a speech written by Barrie Unsworth rather than a speech written by somebody called Freudenberg. I am quite sure that many of the honourable senators and members opposite were listening to Mr Unsworth and his statements about the state of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the attitude that the New South Wales Labor Party will be taking in the lead-up to the election. This is a day on which the criticisms which have been made by the Opposition of the Hawke Labor Government are as nothing when compared with the criticisms which have been made by members of the Australian Labor Party and Mr Unsworth in particular. I remind honourable senators and members that Mr Unsworth last night-it was broadcast today-was saying that there was a clear message that the ALP had to work for the people again. I quote:

The Labor Party, at all levels, must be perceived not just as the true government of the people but the true voice of the people . . . And we can only be their voice if we . . . listen to their voice.

I think the significance of the nomination of Mr Bob McMullan to this Senate place for the ACT is that he is just the latest in a series of ALP bureaucrats who have been put into the Senate as if it is some form of retirement home. I have to say that when we copped Graham Richardson we thought that was pretty tough but then we got Michael Beahan and Senator Schacht. He actually wore a tie on television the other day before the selection of a Minister. I remind the chamber that we have had four Labor Party apparatchiks coming into this place to match the 27 trade union leaders who have been put into the Parliament over recent years. If the people of Australia are wondering why the Australian Labor Party is out of touch with them they should look at the composition of the Labor side of this Parliament, because it is made up of union bureaucrats and trade union leaders who, on recent surveys, are the least trusted people in Australia. That is the sad statistical fact that it must put up with. All I can say is that, whilst it continues to make this Parliament unrepresentative by filling it with such a disproportionate number of trade union and Labor Party apparatchiks, it will continue to lose touch with the men and women of Australia, who know that it does not represent their interests. It represents the interests of its own bureaucracies and its own narrow membership.

We have just had a by-election in South Australia. In that by-election Labor tried to put another trade unionist into Parliament. It was defeated in that by-election. That, I believe, is the pattern which demonstrates the unwisdom of the Labor Party closing off this Parliament from the people of Australia in the way that it has. Whilst I acknowledge the very considerable professional achievements of Mr McMullan and whilst I, as a Western Australian, welcome him to this place to represent the Australian Capital Territory, I also say that I think it is time that the Labor Party realised that its failure to do other than look after its own is one of the reasons why it is widely being despised by its own. There is no suggestion that these people are making Australia safer for democracy, but they are making it very safe for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—I speak as Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I cannot but follow the temptation of the theme that was put down by Senator Chaney, particularly as I see opposite, together, those two graphic blobs of protoplasm who are the functional operatives, to be joined in this House by yet another kneecapper. If Senator Chaney is right in striking the theme that these operators are being brought in to control the mendacious lot that sit opposite, I can also strike the theme that he struck before when he talked about Mick's by-election. SPEECH.PARA: The third theme that Senator Chaney struck was that of battling Barrie Unsworth in New South Wales. On the day that we see Senator-elect McMullan come into this chamber-to pick up Senator Chaney's theme of battling Barrie-I note that Unsworth actually asked, on this historic day, for a fair go. I thought we would meet him halfway: we will be fair to him and he can go. The reality is that the Opposition is not opposing Senator McMullan's nomination but it is pointing out, as Senator Chaney so correctly nailed, the increasing number of paid operators, the movers of the pawns in the chess game, who are coming into this chamber and, indeed, the trade union officials-for example, the one nominated in the Adelaide by-election.

I wish Senator McMullan well, but we are sworn and duty bound to seek his removal at the next election. That may well be sooner than many think. Where is Paul? Is he here? I will not go over what Kim Beazley Snr said, but a few members ought to look around to see the changing nature of this once great Party at the commencement of its demise.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I would like to offer its support of the motion which was moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I suppose that a retiring Clerk may well feel a bit like a retiring senator-that it requires departure to bring forth praise-but I very happily join in the thanks which were expressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate for what has been a near working lifetime of service to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Alan Cumming Thom had a very long apprenticeship under Mr Odgers, and one might have expected talent to stultify after such a long period of stable leadership, if you like; but I think it is a tribute to Mr Odgers that his succession was so smooth and that he left behind him a cadre of officers with equal devotion to the Senate and equally able to give it guidance. I believe that Mr Cumming Thom served the Senate particularly well. I would like to express my thanks for the qualities which I think were very adequately described by Senator Button in his speech-Mr Cumming Thom's consideration; his very great talent, which was always available to us; and, I believe, his utter impartiality in conducting his duties.

When Mr Cumming Thom told me that he was leaving-I must say it was a great surprise to me that he did choose to retire at the age of 60 because I found it hard to imagine him not working for the Senate-I expressed the view, which I would like to express publicly, that I thought an additional tribute to the effectiveness of his service to the Senate was that he was leaving behind him a person he was recommending for appointment who was very well suited for the task of Clerk of the Senate. Again I think that in mentioning the Opposition's strong support for the accession of Harry Evans to the position of Clerk of the Senate I should say that in a way I think that is a great compliment to Alan Cumming Thom. I think the established succession is a very healthy sign.

Having said that, I also mention the two other officers who left recently, one of whom was mentioned in a speech given by the Leader of the Government, and the other who left some time ago. If he was mentioned at the time, I am afraid I was not here to join in. I refer to Tom Wharton and Peter Murdoch, both of whom gave long and, I believe, very high quality service to the Senate, and both of whom left the Senate to undertake positions in private enterprise, one self-employed and the other employed. From the time that I arrived in the Senate in 1974 I must say that I found those then relatively junior officers both very good company and very good professional guides. I believe that both gave sterling service to the Senate and I very much regret from the Senate's point of view that they both saw fit to move on to what undoubtedly were greener pastures.

The maintenance of proper parliamentary standards and, indeed, the proper maintenance of our parliamentary institutions require a high degree of professional skill and devotion from the officials who serve the Senate. I believe that Mr Cumming Thom and the other officials I have mentioned have performed their tasks with very great distinction. I thank them for that and I wish each of them a very successful post-Senate life. In Mr Cumming Thom's case, I wish him a long and happy retirement with Mrs Cumming Thom, and in the case of Tom Wharton and Peter Murdoch I wish them very great success in their commercial life. I hope that they will visit us from time to time and explain to us that the grass is not always greener outside the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support the Government's motion of appreciation of Alan Cumming Thom's good services to the Senate, and good they were. Alan was affable and inevitably good humoured no matter what sorts of pressures we applied to him. He was even tempered, which is something fairly rare around this place, and he was a fountain of information for those of us who needed assistance from time to time.
—You are talking as though he were dead.

—No, he is not dead. In fact, he is probably more alive now that he has been for some time. It was said by a previous Clerk of this place, Jim Odgers, in Australian Senate Practice that the Clerk of the Senate is the permanent head of the Department of the Senate and, subject to the direction of the President, responsible for the administration and control of the Department. I would say that is a masterly piece of understatement, given the way in which in many ways the Clerk of the Senate controls this chamber. Certainly all the Clerks who have been here since I have been a member of this place-that is, for the last 10 years-have quietly, more or less unobtrusively but nonetheless definitely, kept their thumbs well and truly on the way the Senate operates.

SPEECH.PARA: A newspaper headline above an article that wrote up the retirement of Alan Cumming Thom read, `Parliament loses a staunch ally'. I think that more accurately that headline should have read that the Senate has lost a staunch ally, because Alan was a man who may well have been an impeccably professional public servant, but above all he was a passionate defender of the institution of the Senate that he has defended and served so loyally for so long. It is fortunate that his replacement, Harry Evans, is equally as fervent, not to say paranoid, about the role of the Senate and its independence in the parliamentary system.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a psychopath.

—Senator Sanders says, `He is a psychopath'. I do not think it is quite that bad, but certainly there is a dedication to the independence of the Senate which I think is very necessary, given the fact that we are on the receiving end of most of the slings and arrows that some people fling around, people who believe that the Senate is nothing more than an obstructive, tiresome place that gets in the way of the elected government being, in effect, a dictatorship. I think it is very important that we have people here on the staff in the Department of the Senate who remind us that we not only have a right to be here, but also that we have a duty to act as if this place is, indeed, the independent chamber that it is. Alan was very effective in his advisory role in the chamber. As a Temporary Chairman of Committees for many years, I was very grateful for the advice that he would give whenever members in this place got slightly out of order-although heaven knows they do not get as out of order as the House of Representatives members apparently do-or when somebody called a point of order. I was as grateful for his advice as I was for the help and assistance I got from an earlier Clerk, Jim Odgers, who was in this Parliament when I first arrived.

SPEECH.PARA: I approve heartily of the fact that apparently the Department as a farewell gift gave Alan a golf buggy with a seat. I am sure that as he sits and contemplates the quiet of the nineteenth hole he will remember his days here with fondness, but I suspect with very little regret that he is no longer limited to sips of water and a diet of very often tedious debate. We wish him well as I am sure do all senators in his retirement and I hope that he uses the golf buggy frequently. He should keep out of Mary's kitchen since there is nothing worse for many wives than a husband who has been used to a very busy, very active life suddenly intruding on her sphere of activity and I hope that he thinks of us occasionally, but only occasionally.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is sexist.

—It is true. It may sound sexist, but I assure the honourable senator that it is true. I would like to wish Tom Wharton and Peter Murdoch well, both of whom have also recently retired. I am sure we will see more of Tom when we move to the new and permanent Parliament House since the advanced information systems which the President mentioned earlier that Tom was responsible for guiding us into will, no doubt, prove more troublesome-or their operators will-than I suspect they are sometimes worth and that Tom, with his connection with the private sector firm that he is currently with, will be called on.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the replacements are temporary pending advertisements for the positions, but I would have to say that there are very competent people such as Anne Lynch in this place already who can take over the positions. I think it is unlikely that we will get a plethora of respondents to those advertisements who will be better suited to fill the positions of Tom and Peter, or anybody else who might leave, than those who have grown up with us in this place, who know our idiosyncrasies and who love us despite them, I think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). In doing so, I want to address my remarks almost exclusively to Alan Cumming Thom, although in doing so I take the opportunity, briefly, of congratulating his successor, Harry Evans. I wholly share the views already stated by earlier speakers as to his qualities and abilities. I want also simply to extend my good wishes to Tom Wharton and Mr Murdoch both of whom, however, were much less well known to me than Alan Cumming Thom.

SPEECH.PARA: I met Alan Cumming Thom 31 years ago when I first came to Canberra in 1956. In those days, Mr President, it may surprise you to know that I was interested not only in the Treasury but also in the game of hockey. I was looking for a hockey team to play for. In 1957 before returning to London and after my return from London in 1961 I played with a team which I think is still known today as the United Hockey Club. I think it is fair to say that at that time Alan Cumming Thom was a stalwart of that club.

For those who know anything about the game of hockey it may mean something to them if I say that I played in the position of right full-back. My goalkeeper, the man upon whom finally the responsibility falls if the full-backs are beaten in the last resort, was Alan Cumming Thom. Hockey goalkeepers are a special class of people. They require a blend of qualities and judgment on whether to rush out or to stay back on their goal lines; a cool head and a quick eye; tenacity, of course, the quality of never giving up; and, above all, in the end, courage. I inform the Senate that Alan Cumming Thom had all those qualities in abundance as a hockey goalkeeper. I believe that he maintained those qualities-judgment, a cool head and a quick eye for a coming storm, tenacity in his dealings with not merely the Senate but with those who, as Senator Haines quite rightly pointed out, would perhaps have been less appreciative of the Senate than in his quite proper judgment they should have been and, above all, in the end, courage.

As earlier speakers have said, a Clerk of the Senate follows in a famous line. One has only to mention the name of Odgers in connection with Australian Senate Practice to be aware of that. Senators and even Presidents come and go, but Clerks stay here for a long time-indeed, Alan Cumming Thom stayed here in the position of Clerk for only something over five years but, as has been said, his service to the Senate extended much longer than his time as Clerk. Partly for that reason, however-the longevity of service-Clerks become in some sense, and again I think Senator Haines put it very well, custodians for the traditions, the principles and the practices of this place and so it has certainly been for Alan Cumming Thom. I wish him and his wife Mary well in what I hope will be a long life and a very happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rarely write a reference for anyone. Come to think of it, I am rarely asked to write a reference for anyone.
—Why is that, Brian?

—It probably would not do him any good. But were I to do so for Alan Cumming Thom-it would be really the opposite way around-the first thing that would come to mind would be: Here is a man of the highest integrity. As a matter of fact, about the only time that I did not believe him was earlier this year when he contacted me and said that he was retiring at the age of 60. I asked him, `When is that?' He gave me a date in early February and that was when I frankly found it hard to believe that Alan Cumming Thom was 60 years of age. Not that 60 years of age is very old in any event, but he was a very young looking 60. That was quite extraordinary, given the enormous pressures that Alan Cumming Thom had to withstand over the last couple of years in working on the transfer of the Department of the Senate to the new Parliament House and also in making sure that what occurred in those transfers did not undermine the proper and independent role of the Senate, of the executive government, and of the other chamber of this Parliament, the House of Representatives. I am sure it was not those pressures that led to his retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Alan Cumming Thom would very much have desired to be Clerk of the House when we transferred to the place on the hill. What motivated him most was that, first and foremost, he is a family man. That is to his great credit. If those principles were adhered to by those of us remaining, the place would be better. I am not suggesting that if we all thought of our families first and resigned, the place might be better.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might help if some people did.

—That is possibly correct but I am talking about legislation and administrative action. Alan Cumming Thom has a great sense of humour. I agree with what has been said-he was unruffled. There have been a few crises around the place but he was always unruffled and always gave his advice in a well-considered and temperate manner. That was very much appreciated by me.
—He must have had the patience of a saint if he was like that with you.
—That is true; but we had something else in common-our Scottish background. He came from Scotland when he was nine years of age.
—Did he have an Australian passport?

—I do not know. But he displayed a tenaciousness that is characteristic of the Scots. I know that he was very well liked amongst the staff. He had contact with all the staff, not only his senior officials but the whole of the staff of the Department of the Senate. I know that it was one of his great disappointments when a number of the staff had to be located in East Block and he then did not have day to day contact with them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like also, as others have done, to mention Tom Wharton and Peter Murdoch. Peter has gone from this place, which is supposed to be making the news, to selling it in a newsagency. I wish him and his wife well in that enterprise. Tom Wharton had also been here for many years. Tom joked that his first job around the place was to clean the inkwells. From cleaning the inkwells to being largely responsible for guiding people in the right direction as to information systems and computer technology is really quite an outstanding performance. No doubt we will see a lot more of Tom, as Senator Haines has said, when we go up to the new Parliament House-and probably before then in his current position. I wish him well. It will be beneficial not only to him but to those of us who work closely with him.

Finally, I would like to join with all the Senate in wishing Alan and Mrs Cumming Thom a very successful retirement. Alan Cumming Thom has a great resource of information which should not be left to stagnate. Knowing Alan Cumming Thom, I am sure that it will not stagnate. It will surface somewhere, at some time, and maybe in the not too distant future, if and when consideration may be given to undermining the role of this Senate. I also take the opportunity to congratulate the new Clerk. I am sure that all honourable senators know of the work he has done in presenting written papers in academic and other journals on the role of the Senate, the Parliament, the executive government and so on. Mr President, I believe you made a very good choice in recommending to the Governor-General his appointment as the new Clerk. I see the probable Deputy sitting beside him. I do not know whether it is too soon to congratulate her. I wish Alan Cumming Thom a happy retirement. No doubt we will hear from him. I hope his expertise is made useful in the interests of this institution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Alan Cumming Thom has been a friend of mine for almost 40 years, since we played cricket together at Sydney University. That is a little longer than Senator Stone's hockey experiences with him. Alan has a very strong belief in the rights and status of the Senate in the parliamentary process. That strong belief has not always endeared him to every member of every government that has sat here. There have been people sitting in this place who have not been as enamoured of the role of the Senate as Alan Cumming Thom has been all his professional life in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said, Alan Cumming Thom certainly is a man of decency, fairness, integrity and, I might say, strong will, particularly in matters of principle to which he was committed. This was also reflected in his style as a cricketer as I knew him in the late 1940s at Sydney University when he was a very competent wicket keeper-a role that tends to keep batsmen honest. It was a role he played with senators with some success as well. As a hockey goalkeeper he was the last line of defence. It was a role he filled here as well in defence of the Senate and what it stands for.

I regret that Alan Cumming Thom has not stayed on to help guide us through the problems we face in going up to the new Parliament House, particularly in view of the prospect of some proposed reorganisations, that I hope we do not allow to diminish the status and independence of the Senate. I wish Alan and his wife well in retirement and I wish Harry Evans, his deputy for some period, every success in the job. Mr Evans, in his assistance to all of us, has demonstrated the outstanding ability to see clearly what, to many of us, have been problems that have clouded our vision. I hope that in his new role he will have a very long and successful career.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place a few words on the record about Alan Cumming Thom from a senator who is new. I suspect that I am speaking for other new senators. When I was duly elected to this place, as a very pleasant introduction, I attended an orientation seminar which was arranged by the Clerk, Mr Alan Cumming Thom, and which included the people we have now become familiar with, the people who now sit here and the people who have just left. It was the kindness, courtesy and information made available to us in every way possible that afforded us the opportunity of becoming effective members of this chamber. Even in the short time I have been a member of this chamber, I have found that the connection and the contact-I use the word `contact' as distinct from the word `acquaintanceship'-that have been established between me and other new senators and the people who serve this place with integrity and belief in its importance, have enabled those people to become more than simply acquaintances. Friendship is something that comes with greater understanding and knowledge of individuals. On this occasion I say to those people who extended those early introductions for new senators: Thank you very much; we are the wiser for having had the benefit of your counsel. I offer my congratulations to those people who are coming on to wear the mantle of that important office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always had trouble with the term `clerk' because I am a senator of foreign origin and the word reminds me of a person who sells shoes or writes with a quill pen. I am happy that people in my newly adopted country pronounce the word `clerk' differently from the way in which I am accustomed to its being pronounced.

SPEECH.PARA: Alan Cumming Thom was all the best things that a Clerk in the parliamentary system can be. I have served in State and Federal parliaments. The Clerks are important to the institution of parliament and Cumming Thom certainly cared about the institution of parliament. I have not known him for 31 years; I have never played hockey or rugby with him, but I have taken walks around the lake with him. We enjoyed a few reflective walks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we know why he quit!

—That was an unfair comment; I am being nice. As we walked around the lake I thought him a very interesting person, not only in the parliamentary sense but also as a man of wide interests. I enjoyed our walks. I hate to use the past tense because it sounds as though he is dead and, of course, he is not. He is very much alive and is probably enjoying himself far more than we are at the moment. It is correct to use the past tense in saying that we walked around the lake, and I hope we can do it again.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Bishop has said, he welcomed new senators into this Parliament. We were all a bit ill at ease about our roles as new senators. We were concerned about what we were meant to do, how we would do it and what official actions we should take. He gently led us through the procedures. He was an honest, friendly person and I appreciate that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Baume agrees with that. What is more important for us independents and Australian Democrats is that he was always available-I availed myself of his services-to answer any questions on parliamentary procedure. He always welcomed us and our questions and never made us feel as though we were stupid for not knowing the answers. He was genuinely helpful, as all the Clerks are. Senators who are members of the small parties and Independent senators rely on the Clerks more than senators of the bigger parties, and we are appreciative of what they do for us.

SPEECH.PARA: I also appreciated the fact that Alan Cumming Thom was always interested or tried to look interested in my speeches. He was often the only person in the whole chamber who was awake.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very difficult.

—A generous spirit.

—He was a generous spirit. He was often the only person who was obviously awake, other than the President. Either he developed a good countenance by which he could sleep with his eyes open, or he was interested. In either case, his attention was a source of great encouragement. I often felt that if he were not there and I were not talking to him I would probably not have talked at all because, as a former university lecturer, I like to talk to an audience. I like to gauge what I am saying in front of an audience. It is difficult to do so in Parliament where the audience is often hostile and one must plough on, which is not good oratory.

SPEECH.PARA: Alan Cumming Thom will be missed but he is not gone from these chambers and halls of Parliament. He has left an indelible mark through his activities. He has become part of the history of the Senate. He will be missed but he will still be with us. I welcome Harry Evans in his new position. Harry Evans suffered long and hard with the Australian Democrats, helping to draft our amendments and Bills. He served a hard apprenticeship. I am glad that he has been elevated and that his true worth has been recognised in his appointment as Clerk of the Senate. Congratulations to Harry Evans.

I am sorry to see Tom Wharton and Peter Murdoch go. I did not know them well but I found them helpful in the dealings I had with them. I hope Alan Cumming Thom has a good time with his new golf cart. I took objection to Senator Haines saying that he should not be allowed in the kitchen. Perhaps he likes to cook and, if so, he should be allowed in the kitchen, regardless of what Senator Haines says.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to say a few words of appreciation to Alan Cumming Thom who has just retired as Clerk of the Senate and to indicate how much I appreciated his help and guidance, particularly over the years that I have been one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees. He has always been helpful to me, as have the other Clerks. Quite often it is handy to have the help of the Clerks when one is sitting in the chair. It is even more handy when one can take shorthand, as I can, and write down what they say. So long as I can translate the shorthand correctly, I can deliver the words to the Senate.
—You will have to ask them to speak more slowly.

—Yes, I will have to ask them to speak more slowly sometimes. I was disappointed when I received Alan's letter telling honourable senators that he intended to retire on his 60th birthday. I took the opportunity of telephoning him when I was in my office in Brisbane to tell him that, from my point of view, 60 years of age was a young age at which to retire. He said, `Never mind, you look younger than I do'. That was a very nice compliment he paid me. I asked him what he intended to do and he told me that he would do voluntary work. He said there were lots of opportunities to help other people. I believe that is worth while. I suppose he will play golf and use his wonderful new golf buggy but it is nice to know that he will use some of his time to help others who are less fortunate than he is or we are. I compliment him on that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the new Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans. Harry Evans has always been very kind and helpful to me when I have needed assistance in the chair. I take this opportunity of wishing Alan and his wife all the very best in their retirement and I am sure they will have many happy years together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the debate on this motion and share some of Senator Bishop's comments about Alan Cumming Thom's shepherding us new boys and girls into the Senate. Alan Cumming Thom was always cheerful, supportive and helpful. Without the benefit of a party machine I have sometimes felt overwhelmed by parliamentary procedures and what to do next but Alan Cumming Thom was always more than willing to set me on the right course. On more than one occasion his advice has prevented me from sticking my foot where it should not go. Perhaps he should have been advising me when I was filling in my nomination form to be a candidate. When I first became a senator and was involved in the orientation courses in which you, Mr President, were also involved, the assistance of Mr Cumming Thom and others was probably the most significant help that I and other senators have had in their passage into this place. Mr Cumming Thom had and still has a good sense of humour but we will no longer have the benefit of it around the corridors of Parliament House. There was always a sparkling wit in his eyes, as if he knew of something that was going on which the rest of us did not know about. As Senator Sanders said, Alan Cumming Thom always seemed very interested in what senators were saying, and I appreciated that.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that I can also speak for Senator Vallentine, who always appreciated his friendship, friendliness and help. She joins me in wishing Alan and Mrs Cumming Thom a long and successful retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join previous speakers in their words of appreciation for the dedicated services to the Senate of Alan Cumming Thom. Alan certainly will be missed by all senators because he was able to bring to the Senate advice that was acceptable to all of us. I suppose, Mr President, only you would know how difficult is that feat.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight all senators who have spoken have stressed the assistance and help that Alan has given them over the years. To cap Senator Michael Baume, I first knew Alan 40 years ago before he went to university. My husband was in the college of which his father was principal. It was only when I came to the Senate that I recognised the ability Alan had of being able to put things succinctly, in a completely unbiased fashion and in a way that assisted us all so much. I just want to say thank you to him for all the help that he has given me in the past, and I wish him and his wife a very happy and long retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my words to all the other tributes that have been paid tonight to Alan Cumming Thom. I must admit that when I first came here, he did the same as he has done to every other senator in this place: he gave a very good briefing to new senators. One of the first questions he asked me was what football team I supported. He had an avid interest in all football, whether it be rugby league, rugby union or Australian rules, and he also had a big interest in cricket.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the good bits of advice he gave me when I first came here was that more people talk themselves out of this place than actually talk themselves into it. I do not know whether that is true of all parliamentarians but it was probably reasonable advice.

He also gave me the advice, which I suppose he gave to all parliamentarians, that Parliament House is a lonely place and, if one does not make friends on all sides of the House in all political faiths, it will not be the best place to be in for about 100 days of the year that we spend here. I appreciated those two pieces of advice that he gave me. I thank him for his help and direction in that regard. Others have spoken about his deep affection for the traditions of the Senate, and I believe he will be missed.

I think Tom Wharton will also be missed, as will Peter Murdoch. I congratulate Harry Evans on his appointment in taking over. The moment always makes the man, and I am sure that he will go on to get the same tributes as Alan Cumming Thom is getting tonight when he finishes in this job in about another 30 years. I join with others in wishing Alan and Mrs Cumming Thom all the happiness in a well-earned retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say thank you to Alan Cumming Thom for the years of service he gave to me, to the Senate and above all to the institution of the Parliament of Australia. At this stage of the night I do not propose to repeat the virtues of the former Clerk, but I can say that his hallmark was the supreme professional approach that he brought to the discharge of his duties here as Clerk.

SPEECH.PARA: He was absolutely devoted to the best interests of the Senate as an institution, and we saw that here. What we did not see in this chamber was his fearless defence of the place of the Senate within the Parliament in the subterranean but eternal war-as you, Mr President, would know very well-which we fight with the forces of darkness at the other end of the building when the House of Representatives continually tries to use its greater numbers to overwhelm and hammer the Senate into oblivion. Alan Cumming Thom was a great supporter of the place of the Senate as a place of parity with the House of Representatives. As a Deputy Chairman, I saw him in a closer light than perhaps as a senator. I always found his advice to be impartial, objective and meticulously correct.

In passing, I also note the great service of Tom Wharton and Peter Murdoch. I wish all three well in their future careers. I congratulate Harry Evans in his incoming role as the Clerk of the Senate. I am sure that he will carry on the fine traditions of impartiality and service to the institution that we have seen from his predecessors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly join the remarks of my colleagues from both sides of the chamber in thanking Peter Murdoch, Tom Wharton and particularly Alan Cumming Thom for their service to us all over a long number of years. If one adds those years of service together, they probably amount to not much less than three-quarters of a century.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to congratulate Harry Evans on his appointment as Clerk of the Senate. I thank him for all the work he has done on our behalf in the past few years, and in fact many years for the Senate as a whole, and to wish him well for the future.

I did not know Peter Murdoch very well, but in the short time that he and I have been here together, I noted that he was a very professional officer. He has decided to go into the world of the entrepreneur and has taken over a newsagency. I wish him well in that career.

Tom Wharton has been with the Senate for more than 20 years and he will be a very significant loss to us all. My association with Tom Wharton goes back to his father. I knew his father for many years in the Treasury before meeting Tom Wharton Junior. Tom Wharton Senior was a very fine officer of the Public Service-one of the old guard of the Public Service. He really regarded the traditions of the Public Service as very important not only for the Public Service itself but also for the whole of Australia. I think Tom Wharton Junior carried on those traditions and values. They are values that we all should take into account because I have a great fear that they are slipping rapidly in this country, and that will not do any of us any good.

Tom has also gone out into the world of business and computer machines. He was of great assistance to us here with his knowledge of computers, and the work that he did will significantly show itself when we move with the new information systems to the new Parliament House. I venture to suggest, having seen Tom Wharton Junior at first hand in some of the work that he was doing with computer contracts and so on in this chamber, that he did much to put us on the straight and narrow in terms of the right sorts of computer systems that we ought to have. There have been some major hiccups over the past two or three years and Tom was involved in sorting them out at the end.

I wish Alan Cumming Thom all the very best. He has made a great contribution to the Senate. My own personal knowledge of Alan does not go back as far as that of Senator Michael Baume or Senator Stone, but it goes back a fair way, to 1964 when I first came here and had an association with this building as private secretary to the late Harold Holt. In those days Harold Holt was the Treasurer and of course we had a great deal of tick-tacking between the two chambers because of ministerial representation in this place. Alan Cumming Thom's work in the Senate was very important even in those days although he was a much less senior officer than of course he ended up being. Our association goes back that far. It was with great satisfaction that I noted his progression through the ranks of the Department of the Senate to the head of that Department, and I admired the achievements that he made because he, like the Wharton family, was part and parcel of a very great tradition of public service which I wonder whether this country will ever see again. If we do not, we will all be the losers.
I envy Alan because of his opportunity now to get around the golf course with his new buggy, and I join other speakers tonight in wishing him a very happy not retirement but new phase in his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time in my 10 years here that I have spoken on the retirement of any of our Senate officers. It is with pleasure that I join with all my colleagues in commending the work of Alan Cumming Thom, Peter Murdoch and Tom Wharton. They were all here 10 years ago when I came on board and when Mr Odgers was Clerk. Alan Cumming Thom was the fourth Clerk of the Senate since then, and he has lived up to the best traditions and service of his predecessors.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel a special debt to Alan Cumming Thom because he gave so much advice to us and he was always cheerful. He was a human, friendly and clear assistant to all of us in the chamber. Not only did I, in particular, welcome his advice, in my role as a Deputy Chairman of Committees over the last six months, but we especially valued his work in the committee system. He served as a committee secretary more than 25 years ago, when the Senate had select committees but before the committee system was well established. Whenever we have sought to review the committee system his experience and his commitment to the opportunities we should provide for Senate committees has been most appreciated. I recall the same of Peter Murdoch and Tom Wharton. Not only have we received the benefit of their advice in the chamber and on the committee system but also we have received that advice in our offices, in the corridors and in their offices. We received background advice with regard to legislation and the procedures of the Senate. As I say, they were professional, clear and cheerful.

The sense of humour that all three of them had was infectious and added a great deal to the quality of relations that we had with each other here in this chamber. I should add that Peter Murdoch and Tom Wharton were both Aussie rules footballers here in the Australian Capital Territory and on a couple of occasions some years ago we organised Senate v. House of Representatives football matches for the Governor-General's Cup. I can remember being one of the players, and I was proud to see that two of the best of our players making up the numbers on the Senate side were Peter Murdoch and Tom Wharton. I would like to think that the qualities of the relationships they experienced in Australian football when they were young played a major part in the continuing cheerfulness and good humour they had and in the team approach that they took in the Senate.

I conclude by referring again to Alan Cumming Thom. It was with surprise that I learned of his resignation. I thought he would be with us for another 10 years, but that just shows how we can be taken by surprise here in the Senate. I wish him, Peter and Tom every success over the years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long but I wish to join with other senators who have spoken on the contributions made to the Senate by Alan Cumming Thom, Peter Murdoch and Tom Wharton. The resignation of the Clerk of the Senate at this particular time is certainly understandable. It seems to me that with our move to the new Parliament House a vast amount of work will have to be done in terms of policy decisions and so on, and fairly obviously the Clerk felt that it may well be better to have a new person take up that role so that the next three, four or five years of settling in that will be needed in the new Parliament House can be supervised by one person. I have operated in this chamber as a Whip for all the time I have been here, so I have had a close working relationship with the Clerks in the day to day business of the chamber. One of the things that strikes me most about the Clerks of the Senate is that one cannot call them typical public servants-a phrase often used outside the Parliament in denigration. The Clerks are expected to respond immediately to matters and put a new plan of action into place, or a new program, at the press of a button or at the whim of one of the parties. They have always to my knowledge done that with alacrity and good will, and I think that their operations as the bureaucracy, as it were, of the Parliament mean that we are able to function in what must seem to a lot of people outside to be a highly erratic fashion. I had many discussions with Alan Cumming Thom over the years about policy and his views about the Senate, and certainly I appreciated greatly the depth of understanding he had of the operation of the Senate as a chamber within the parliamentary structure.

SPEECH.PARA: Tom Wharton, of course, contributed greatly, certainly in the last two or three years, to the upgrading of members' functions in this Parliament House by being the person at the end of the line with regard to the computerisation of the parliamentary offices-a task he threw himself into wholeheartedly. He rapidly managed to learn the jargon and come to understand in detail the operations of the systems. That has been borne out by the fact that a very large computer company in Australia wants him to head up its operations in Canberra, which of course is so vitally important to all computer companies because of government contracts. I am sure we will be seeing Tom around in his new capacity, in business, and I think he will still be able to make a very worthwhile and significant contribution by assisting the Parliament in its day to day operations vis-a-vis the government of this country.

I worked with Peter Murdoch for quite some time when he was the Clerk Assistant (Table Office) and, as one needs to work very closely with that particular Clerk in the establishment of the day to day patterns of the program of this chamber, it always struck me how efficiently, effectively and conscientiously but, as it were, in an unflustered way he was able to do his work. I think everybody who came into contact with him struck that. One saw the very smooth operation of any task that he undertook.

The Senate has lost three very efficient and effective officers employed in the support of its work. We are thankful that we have with us still a core of very experienced officers, and hopefully those who will replace the people we have lost will come very rapidly to learn their job and be able to provide the type of top quality support that we have come to expect from officers of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, as is fitting because my acquaintance with Alan Cumming Thom and Tom Wharton was brief. I do feel that I ought to attach myself to the sentiments already expressed, for a number of reasons. I must say it is nice to be once again in the Senate that we all know and love after the exciting hour or so we spent earlier tonight. We have slipped back into our normal mode. Although I have been in Canberra for a very short time my acquaintanceship with the staff of the Senate predated my actually becoming a senator as the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly has been the beneficiary of two ex-members of the Senate staff. I must say that they have provided an extraordinary degree of professionalism. I think everyone in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly would agree with that. I refer to Ian McNeill and Guy Smith.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question of the strength of the old boys network which the Clerks at the table belong to. It is an international network but it works fairly well in Australia. As a result of the time that I spent with Guy Smith when I was Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory in the Legislative Assembly I got to know Alan Cumming Thom particularly prior to coming here. As others have said, being a member of staff of Parliament, particularly a senior member of staff, is not an easy job. Staff are often the subject of criticism from one side of the House or the other. Obviously some of it at times would be justified; a lot of it is not. I imagine that is the case in any parliament; it certainly was the case in the one that I came from. Clerks and senior members of staff particularly are expected to perform nevertheless with absolute impartiality.

Of course, it would be presumptuous of me, in view of my short time here, to speak other than of my experience with Tom Wharton and Alan Cumming Thom who were the only two people I knew of the three who resigned. Alan Cumming Thom was kind enough to write to me to tell me of his resignation. Tom Wharton also contacted me. I appreciated their doing so. I was not surprised when Tom Wharton contacted me because we share a common passion; that is, computers and information technology. I say that unblushingly. Tom Wharton was both a dedicated and a highly skilled person when he left here in terms of information systems that are available. He was the first one to admit that he did not know much about them when he arrived here but there is no question that one has to be interested in that sort of thing to be good at it and he was good at it. I have no doubt that Tom Wharton will be highly successful in his new profession and I certainly wish him well. Despite the short time that I have been here, I have had what I consider to be a valued relationship with both Alan Cumming Thom and Tom Wharton.

I heard Senator Teague say something about Alan Cumming Thom which is absolutely true: he was one of these dreadful people that are always cheerful, helpful and kind to others. In fact, everything I am not, he is. It was always helpful not only to be given good advice but also to be given it with the kind of friendly and open personality of Alan Cumming Thom. It was commented that a large influx of new senators-an unprecedented number in one hit-came to this chamber last year. I remember with gratitude-I am sure all the other new senators do too-the help that all the Senate staff were to us as new people. I refer particularly to the very personal welcome we got from Alan Cumming Thom. I have no doubt that Harry Evans, who has a solid reputation for being across the procedures of this chamber, will more than adequately fill the shoes of Alan Cumming Thom and will continue the proud tradition of Clerks at the table. As I said, it is not only a national institution; it is an international institution in all the parliaments that follow largely the British system. I join with others-I do not think it is too presumptuous-to say that as well as wishing both Alan and the other two members of staff who have resigned from the Senate staff all the best I wish Harry Evans all the best in his new role as Clerk of this chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE EDUCATION OF GIFTED AND TALENTED CHILDREN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the time for presentation of the report of the Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children be extended to 26 May 1988.

The Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children was established on 22 September last year to complete the inquiry on the education of gifted and talented children. That inquiry had been commenced by the former Standing Committee on Education and the Arts.

The Senate directed the Select Committee to report on or before the first day of sitting in 1988. The Committee met on 8 October to review the evidence that had been gathered and to consider the contents for the proposed report. After that meeting, work commenced on a draft report. Where necessary, evidence was updated and additional information was obtained. A chairman's draft report was forwarded to Committee members last week. I propose to call a meeting at an early date to consider this draft.

Because the Committee is unable to report today, I seek an extension of time for the Committee to report. Although I anticipate that the report will be completed before the end of the Autumn session, I have been advised that I should seek to have the reporting date extended to 26 May 1988.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
