SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In the brief five minutes allotted to me on this subject I would like to say several things. I believe this report and the activities of the Advance Australia Foundation raise a lot of wider issues that I believe this chamber ought to take account of in the future and I will certainly be trying to ensure that it does. The first is that whilst welcoming the report of the Advance Australia Foundation I therefore welcome the work that it is doing under its charter. The objectives of the Foundation are to heighten community awareness of Australia and Australian skills achievement and potential; secondly, to highlight the role of the individual in the economy; and, thirdly, to encourage improvements in quality, design, marketing and other characteristics of Australian industry. Whilst I agree with those objectives, I believe several points need to be made.

The first one is that the Foundation is a statutory body and therefore its financial activities are very relevant to this Parliament. Therefore, in that context it is very important to note that the report that has been tabled today which we are considering shows that the Advance Australia Foundation, which is a company limited by guarantee and incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory, in the year ending 30 June 1987 incurred a deficit of $339,594. That is a tenfold increase on the deficit for the previous year, the year ended 30 June 1986, when the deficit was $33,313. It should also be noted that the company is exempt from paying income tax. Again, that is normal for this sort of activity, but it does involve the use of taxpayers' money. The deficit has increased and there has been an exemption from paying income tax. Those are matters, I believe, that we need to consider further at an appropriate time. Paragraph 8 on page 5 of the report reads:

At the first birthday of the Australian Made campaign, the Prime Minister . . . announced that the Federal Government would financially underwrite the advertising of the Australian Made campaign in the 1987-88 financial year. In view of this undertaking it is expected that revenue generated from licensing will again increase in the forthcoming financial year.

If the Government uses taxpayers' funds to underwrite such a campaign, that is only to be expected. These are some financial matters that will need to be looked at, particularly in view of allegations that have been made that the Advance Australia Foundation has given a discriminatory, privileged position to John Singleton Advertising in relation to the advertising campaign that is associated with the Advance Australia Foundation. Time does not permit me to go into all the details of that matter tonight. Some very serious allegations have been made by bodies that have been disadvantaged by the privileged position of John Singleton Advertising. Those matters will have to be looked at and I will certainly raise them again in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

This report is an example of the manner in which this Government stands over and harasses independent statutory organisations which dare to challenge the Government's position and which dare to oppose the Government's policies. This body believed that the Government's policies were disastrous for the businesses that are under the aegis of the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board. Last year I pointed out to the Senate that this Board attacked the Government's capital gains tax policy. It stated:
The Board continues to hold a strong view that the development of a large and vital venture capital industry in Australia will be seriously jeopardised while such a high capital gains tax exists.
It continued:
The Board predicts that the proposed capital gains tax will favour investments in inflation-paced activities and seriously retard the growth of the venture capital industry.
Of course, that was proved to be absolutely right in the stock market boom which ended in the collapse in October. The Board stated:

Since an MIC's profit is incurred by realised capital gains, the very existence of the present capital gains tax mitigates strongly against the raising of additional funds outside the Program in its present immature state. The Board believes that the present capital gains tax is the most substantial factor mitigating against the success of the Program, as investment in venture capital aspires to compete for investment dollars.

That slamming attack on the Government's capital gains tax was contained in last year's annual report. What happened? This Government then announced a review of the program administered by this Board. An inquiry was held by the Bureau of Industry Economics at the instigation of this Government. Of course, that Bureau recommended that this program terminate on 30 June this year. The Board objected strongly to that finding and, as a result, the Government said that it would allow it to continue until June next year. This occurred in the face of the Board's request that the program should continue until at least 1991. In its 1986-87 report the Board stated:

It was and is the Board's view that a review in 1987 or even 1988 was premature because of the long term nature of the Program investments and that any study was likely to produce indeterminate results.

Of course, it is not surprising that the Board should believe that the Government's recently announced policy to continue the management and investment companies program until at least June 1989 is inadequate to meet the Government's objectives for venture capital. As I said, it is a clear piece of evidence of the standover tactics used by this Government if one of these independent bodies dares to disagree, as this Board did publicly, with a Government policy-on capital gains tax, in this case-which is basically to the disadvantage of companies in this developing venture capital area. This intrigues me, in particular, when I look at appendix E to this annual report, which states:
No directions were given by the Minister to the Board during the year.

I do not think that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) had to give directions to the Board for it not to repeat its criticism of the capital gains tax of last year. There is no repetition in this report of last year's criticism of the capital gains tax. I would not be at all surprised if the nod and wink was given to the Board that, `if you repeat that criticism there is no chance that you will get even an extension of time until June 1989'. This totally inadequate extension-if, in fact, these new venture capital projects are to be successfully backed by this Government-indicates that there is no doubt whatsoever that the nod and the wink was given that, `if you repeat your criticism you will not get an extension'.

These kinds of standover tactics are intolerable. I believe that there is every ground for a proper inquiry and I will certainly be seeking to raise this matter again when there is more time to discuss it. I believe that what has happened is absolutely scandalous. There is a clear determination by this Government to bring to an end the effectiveness of this Board simply because it dared to challenge this Government's crazy program on capital gains tax which cuts across the very objectives that this Board was set up by the Government to bring into effect.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is an important contribution to the ongoing debate about environmental matters in Australia. It gives the opportunity to raise a couple of matters which are of concern about the administration of the Authority and of the reef in general. The report that we have this year is a particularly good one. I pay tribute to Graeme Kelleher, the Chairman of the Marine Park Authority. I also note that Mr Kelleher will be starting a two-year term as president of the body in Australia which represents the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources which plays an important role in relation to the international obligations which Australia has under the World Heritage convention and a number of other related international arrangements.

The second point to make is that the report draws attention to some of the continuing problems, particularly in terms of the research program related to the crown of thorns starfish. At the ANZAAS conference, which took place in August 1987, a number of papers were presented dealing with the control of the crown of thorns starfish. A very important plea was made by Professor Endean regarding the control of spearfishing on the Great Barrier Reef, in the belief that the activities of spearfishermen are killing those native inhabitants of the reef which play a vital role in the biological control of the crown of thorns starfish. Professor Endean's comments were supported-although not entirely on the same basis-by Dr Leon Zann of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in a paper which he published in the Bulletin of Marine Science which deals with the way in which biological controls are the preferable method of dealing with the crown of thorns starfish, the continuing debate about the cyclical nature of the infestation and whether one is looking at a natural phenomenon or at a phenomenon which is substantially influenced by the way in which human activity on the reef prejudices the continued safety and security of the reef.

The other point I wish to raise and on which I believe the Government needs to provide some information to the Parliament is in relation to the proposal advanced, as I understand it, by interests associated with Mr Kerry Packer, one of this Government's closest big business supporters, for the development of the Magnetic Keys operation which may well intrude into the area which is designated as part of the marine park. The development which is proposed, as I understand it, would include work being undertaken within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. As a result there would be some obligation on the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, to make clear whether or not permission would be granted from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for the work to proceed. The involvement of the Commonwealth would include steps that ought to be taken to assess this proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. There may be a third element in terms of necessary approvals from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) under the Foreign Investment Review Board's powers to grant approvals to activities taking place which otherwise come within its jurisdiction.

As I said, the report raises many important matters. It raises the question of the future of the dugong populations and the research work which I know Dr Helen Marsh and others have done in relation to those populations. This is an important report. It draws attention to a number of matters to which the Parliament ought to direct its attention. I congratulate the Marine Park Authority on the production of this annual report and on raising a number of matters which ought to be of concern to those who have a genuine interest in issues of environmental management and control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks to the paper presently before us, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority annual report. I note also in the report that the Authority has been successful with the creation of its on-shore aquarium. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Again, the report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is a report of considerable significance. The report draws attention to a number of matters. In the few minutes which are available to me I wish to raise only one of them. The report deals in part with the work of the National Parks and Wildlife Service as it relates to the International Whaling Commission. I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the quite scandalous behaviour of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in attempting to lean on the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare to re-open its investigation on the question of the control of cetacea in captivity.

This is a matter on which the Senate Committee on Animal Welfare, under the chairmanship of the former Senator Georges, produced a report. That report was discussed in the Senate in March 1986. We still have no response from the Government on this matter. We have waited virtually two years for the Government to respond. As I have said on a previous occasion, the way in which this Government is behaving is scandalous. Just because it happens to be our bicentennial year the Government thinks that we are prepared to wait around for 200 years before it gives us a report on its response to this significant Senate inquiry.

What happened was that a major proponent of the extensive keeping of cetacea in captivity met with Senator Richardson in December 1987. Senator Richardson then tried to lean on the Select Committee on Animal Welfare to re-open its inquiry into the keeping of cetacea in captivity. I am glad to say that when the Committee met, I think last week, it unanimously rejected the attempt of the Minister to have the inquiry re-opened. It is a matter of some significance that the Senate Committee was prepared to take that stand. I congratulate it on doing so. It is certainly, within the purview of the Opposition, an important report. I have already stated a view on this matter. We have clearly indicated that we do not want this inquiry to be re-opened. What we want is a statement from the Government as to its intention.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What discretionary powers does the Minister for the Environment and the Arts or the department head have in refusing a Freedom of Information request.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 14 of the FOI Act makes it clear that the provisions of the Act are not intended to prevent or discourage Ministers or agencies from giving access to documents, including exempt documents, other than as required by the Act, where it is proper or required by law to do so. Section 14 preserves an existing discretion to release documents held by an agency or Minister.
(2) Subsection 20 (3) provides that access in a particular form may be refused and given in another form where the giving of access would:

(b) be detrimental to the preservation of a document or would not be appropriate given the physical nature of the document, or

(c) except for the FOI Act, involve an infringement of copyright (other than copyright owned by the Commonwealth, an agency or State) being matter that does not relate to the affairs of an agency or a Department of State.

(3) Section 24 provides that an agency or Minister may refuse access to a request which encompasses all documents containing information of a specified kind that would unreasonably divert the resources of an agency from its other operations, or would interfere substantially and unreasonably with the performance by the Minister of his or her functions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Commissioner of Taxation give leasehold land a zero value when leases are renewed, extended, or converted to freehold in calculating capital gains tax; if so, (a) would such an interpretation adversely affect thousands of farmers, particularly in northern Australia; and (b) will the Commissioner of Taxation examine this anomaly and issue a taxation ruling at an early opportunity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the capital gains tax legislation, the surrender, expiry or renewal of a lease, including a Crown lease, is treated as the disposal of an asset by the lessee and the issue of a new lease is treated as the acquisition of a new asset.

Where a lessee of a pastoral lease has a right, or an understanding with the lessor, that on or before its expiry the lease will be renewed, and in the event that it is not renewed that compensation is payable to the lessee, the market value of the original pastoral lease determined at the time of surrender, expiry or renewal, will be included in the cost base of the new pastoral lease for capital gains tax purposes.

Specific provisions deal with the situation where a lease of land is converted to freehold. If the lease was granted in perpetuity or for a term of not less than 99 years, the lessee is taken to have acquired the freehold at the time when the lessee acquired the lease. Therefore, if the lease was acquired before 20 September 1985, the freehold is also taken to have been acquired before that date. The consideration for the acquisition of the freehold is taken for tax purposes to be the sum of the premium paid for the grant or assignment of the lease and any amount paid to acquire the reversionary interest.

For other leases of land (that is, those not granted in perpetuity or for a term of less than 99 years) the capital gains treatment depends on when the lease was acquired. If the lease was acquired before 20 September 1985, the freehold in the land is taken to have been acquired when the reversionary interest was acquired and for the market value of the land. If the lease was acquired on or after 20 September 1985, the cost of the freehold for capital gains purposes includes the premium paid for the grant or assignment of the lease and any amount paid to acquire the reversionary interest.

The current treatment of Crown leases under the capital gains tax legislation is under consideration in the context of a review of the rollover provisions. The results of that will be announced as soon as practicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the annual cost to revenue of the $250 pensioner taxation rebate.
(2) Is the rebate available to any taxpayers whose sole source of income is superannuation payments; if not, what are the reasons for not paying the rebate to such persons.
(3) What would be the cost to revenue of extending the pensioner taxation rebate to persons receiving various small amounts of superannuation, for example, below $6,000, $7,000 and $10,000 per annum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The estimated cost to revenue of the $250 pensioner taxation rebate for the 1985-86 income year, the latest year for which data is available, is $170m.

(2) and (3) No. The purpose of the pensioner taxation rebate is to ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on Australian social security or repatriation pensions do not have to pay income tax on the pensions. A person receiving such a pension is entitled to the maximum $250 rebate where his or her taxable income does not exceed $5 914 in 1986-87 and $6 142 in 1987-88. The rebate is reduced by 12.5 cents for each dollar of taxable income above those levels and shades out completely where taxable income exceeds $7 913 in 1986-87 and $8 141 in 1987-88.

While a person whose sole source of income is a superannuation payment does not qualify for the pensioner rebate, he or she may, subject to the pension assets and income tests, qualify for a part age pension. Receipt of an age pension would, in turn, entitle the person to the pensioner rebate if his or her total taxable income were within the relevant income limits.

For example, a single person of pensionable age whose only other source of income in 1987-88 was a $6 000 superannuation payment would be entitled, subject to the pension assets test, to receive an age pension of approximately $4 080. However, there would be no benefit available under the pensioner rebate because the total taxable income of some $10 080 would exceed the upper shade out limit of $8 141 for the rebate. Persons with $7 000 or $10 000 superannuation payments would be in a similar situation.

The cost to revenue of extending the pensioner rebate to persons receiving superannuation payments below $6 000, $7 000 or $10 000 per annum, who for whatever reason are not also receiving a part social security or repatriation pension so as to be eligible for the rebate, is considered to be small because of the limited number of additional cases where the rebate would be of benefit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it the case that the present threshold for the payment of Provisional Personal Income Tax is $1,000 per annum or more in income from other than personal exertion.
(2) Are a number of social welfare pensioners and beneficiaries now required to pay provisional tax.
(3) Is it the case that for 1987-88, social welfare pensioners and beneficiaries can earn $40 weekly or $2,080 per annum before losing any social welfare payments.
(4) What would be the annual cost to revenue of raising the threshold for provisional tax payments to around $2,000 per annum for pensioners and beneficiaries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Provisional tax is generally payable by anyone whose taxable income is high enough for income tax to be payable and whose level of non-salary and wage or pension income, such as interest on savings, exceeds $999.

(2) On the basis of the present rate of social security pension, a single pensioner without dependants will be allowed to earn up to $14 153 in 1987-88 and still be entitled to a pension. In these circumstances, some pensioners are required to pay income tax and to pay provisional tax on their non-salary and wages income.
(3) For 1987-88 a single social security pensioner without dependants can earn up to $2 080 and still receive the maximum pension.

(4) The annual cost to revenue of raising the thresh hold for provisional tax liability to $2 000 per annum for social security pensioners and beneficiaries is estimated to be $20m. It should be noted, however, that increasing the present threshold would not reduce the amount of income tax payable by persons who would otherwise be subject to provisional tax but would simply defer the time for payment to the next financial year. Provisional tax is the non-salary and wages income counterpart to the pay-as-you-earn arrangements for deducting income tax instalments from salary and wages.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a Dr Hempel and a Dr Etheredge visit the Attorney-General's office in Canberra in June 1986 and try to present evidence of their ownership of the vessel S.V. Orionia which some Israeli businessmen had accused them of stealing and for which the state of Israel had requested their extradition.
(2) Did the Attorney-General say, with respect to the merits of their ownership of the vessel, that his Department was ``merely a Post Office''.

(3) Is the Commonwealth Attorney-General able to intervene in the extradition process; if not, was the delivery of the S.V. Orionia, without due process, to persons who were not in fact its owners in error.

(4) Have Dr Hempel and Dr Etheredge spent more than 16 months in a maximum security prison without ever having been charged, let alone convicted, of any crime in Australia and have they, in accordance with amendments to the Extradition (Foreign States) Act passed in 1985, been denied the right to present evidence of their lawful possession of the vessel they are purported to have stolen.

(5) Have they been denied bail by a Federal Court Judge in March 1987 on his interpretation of the Extradition Act that bail should only be allowed to persons in their position under exceptional circumstances, at which time he stated that circumstances in this case were not exceptional enough.
(6) Who is responsible for safeguarding the rights of Dr Hempel and Dr Etheredge in Australia.

(7) What does the Government intend to do to address the inadequacies in current Australian extradition law exposed by the Orionia case and canvassed by Justice French's conclusion to his judgement of 20 October 1987.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. On 27 June 1986 I met Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge in my Sydney office to discuss whether there was any evidence they wished to be put to the State of Israel which could lead to a reconsideration of the decision to request extradition.

2. Whilst I used the expression that my Department ``was merely a post office'', this statement did not relate to the merits of Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge's claim to ownership of the vessel, but to the actual documents placed before the Court in support of Israel's extradition request. Prior to those documents being forwarded to the court my Departmental officers and I had examined them for compliance with the requirements of both Australian extradition law and the Australia/Israel extradition treaty.

3. The role of the Attorney-General is set out in the relevant extradition legislation, in this case the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966. The Attorney-General, once satisfied that the request for extradition is prima facie in order, refers it to the courts for determination of liability to surrender. If the courts find the fugitive liable to surrender the Attorney-General can either order or refuse surrender.
The S.V. Orionia was handed to duly authorised representatives of the registered owners.

4. In accordance with s. 17 (6) (c) of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966, Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge were committed to custody on 1 August 1986 to await the issue of my warrant for their surrender. After they had exhausted the appellate process, and after I gave careful consideration to written submissions made on their behalf, my warrants issued on 19 June 1987. My decision to issue those warrants was challenged by them, and they are currently held in the Canning Vale Remand Centre in Western Australia pending hearing of their application for special leave to appeal to the High Court of Australia.

Section 17 (6A) of the Extradition (Foreign States) Act provides that a fugitive is not entitled to adduce evidence to controvert an allegation that the person has committed the act in respect of which surrender is sought. This provision reflects the pre-existing common law position. Its express inclusion in the Act in 1985 did not change the existing law. An extradition hearing is not a trial of fact. Facts are determined by the courts of the requesting state, in this case Israel.

6. The legislation vests this function in both the Attorney-General and the Australian courts. Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge have exercised their rights to make submissions to me and to appeal to, or seek review by, 6 different courts since August 1986 and have separately applied to the Federal Court of Australia for release on bail.

7. Mr Justice French stated that ``this case discloses deficiencies in the system of decision making and review that could affect public confidence in the law and in the administration of justice''. Prior to the delivering of His Honour's decision the Government had considered the problems created by multiple review procedures and on 28 October introduced into the Parliament the Extradition Bill 1987. That Bill, together with the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 will have the effect of streamlining the review and appeal processes.

(3) When will the referendum on constitutional change take place.
(4) Will it put each question relating to constitutional change separately, or will the changes be presented as a package, to be voted on ``in block''.
(5) What standing do recommendations of the Constitutional Commission have.

(6) Under what procedure does the Government decide whether to accept or reject the Commission's recommendations, and how does it determine which of the Commission's recommendations will be put in a referendum.

(2) The Constitutional Commission has throughout its life sought public comment on the issues it is considering. I understand that it has received more than 3,800 submissions so far and many of these were in response to the work of the various Advisory Committees.

(3) My preference is to conduct a referendum in the second half of 1988.
(4) The Government has not made decisions on the form that any referendum questions will take.
(5) Recommendations of the Constitutional Commission are only recommendations to the Federal Government.
(6) Upon receipt of the Commission's final report the Government will consider the recommendations in the usual manner and determine which should be put to referendum.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Wheat Board Sales to Egypt

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 November 1987 (Hansard, page 1779), Senator McGauran asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister confirm that the Government has almost doubled the insurance premium rate for Export Finance and Insurance Corporation cover for Australian Wheat Board sales to Egypt and also reduced the percentage cover from 85 per cent to 80 per cent for the next three years? Why is the Government discouraging desperately needed agricultural exports to our third largest wheat market, when there is a satisfactory repayment arrangement in place between the Wheat Board and Egypt and when our major competitors, Canada and the United States of America, provide 100 per cent grain export cover?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

As previously indicated to you in the response to a question addressed to Senator Evans on this subject, the Government reviews the level and conditions of insurance cover for credit sales of wheat under the National Interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act, prior to the Australian Wheat Board entering into sales contracts for each new season's crop.

This year's review was undertaken against a background of a difficult international debt situation with an increasing incidence of the rescheduling of trade debts. Australia participated in a Paris Club meeting on 21-22 May 1987, where creditor countries of Egypt agreed to reschedule certain officially insured or guaranteed debts. As a follow-up to the Paris Club meeting, Australia is involved in bilateral negotiations with Egypt to reschedule around $400 million in debts (predominantly wheat debts) relating to contracts signed prior to 31 October 1986 with debt servicing obligations falling due between 1 January 1987 and 30 June 1988. Repayment will be over ten years, including a 5 year grace period. There is also the very real prospect that further debt reschedulings will be required by Egypt. The first round of negotiations with Egypt was held in Cairo on 17-19 November 1987 and we are confident that a satisfactory rescheduling agreement will be reached. The rescheduling of this debt means that the AWB is entitled to and will claim under its insurance policies for the amounts involved.

In these circumstances, the Government's decision to continue to provide credit insurance cover to Egypt, albeit with some tightening of conditions, is a reflection of the importance of this market for Australian wheat, particularly at a time when we have a greatly reduced crop. It also reflects the value which we place on our broader relationship with Egypt.

The conditions to apply to new credit insurance cover for the AWB's credit sales to Egypt involve a reduction in the percentage of cover provided. The cover now provided will be 80% of the payment risk over the three year credit term applying to the sale, compared to the previous arrangement of 85% cover in the first year increasing to 95% cover with satisfactory payments performance in subsequent years. A surcharge of 50% will also apply to AUSTRADE-EFIC's standard premium rate for credit sales to Egypt. This tightening of credit insurance terms is a normal and, I believe, responsible reaction by the Government to the substantial claim payments which will result from the current rescheduling of debts by Egypt and to the higher risk attached to these exports.

I understand that the AWB has recently concluded a sale of 1.5 million tonnes of wheat to Egypt for shipment through 1988 on the basis of the revised credit insurance cover being provided by the Government through AUSTRADE-EFIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 November 1987 (Hansard, page 2198), Senator Walters asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction by the Australian Taxation Office of taxpayer self-assessment was intended to speed up the processing of tax returns. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the Australian Taxation Office has an overall objective of issuing assessments for all returns within nine weeks of lodgment. To the end of November 1987 this objective has been met in 95% of current year refund cases.

The majority of assessment resulting in an underpayment of tax (``debt assessments'') involve provisional tax for 1988. These assessments could not be issued until Royal Assent was given to all of the Rates Acts. A small number of debt assessments were also held up because of errors on returns and for other reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 November 1987 (Hansard, page 219I), Senator Chapman asked me a question without notice concerning funding for the Port Pirie Education Centre (Inc.). The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Recurrent funding under the Education Centres Program for nine of the 32 Education Centres, including the Port Pirie Education Centre, ceased in the 1986/87 Budget in the context of the need to reduce overall expenditure within the public sector. It should be understood that funding under this Program for the Port Pirie Centre ceased from the beginning of 1987, not 1988 as mentioned by the honourable senator.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission in its Report Commonwealth Programs and Policy Development for Schools 1988, which was presented to the Government in May 1987, recommended that funding be provided by the Commonwealth to support up to 26 Education Centres in Australia in 1988 at a total cost of $2.3 million. This represented an increase of some $600,000 over the amount provided in 1987. The Commission did not, however, specify which 26 Centres should be supported. The Government's response to this report was announced in the 1987/88 Budget which, in relation to the Education Centres Program, maintained funding at the same level in real terms to the 23 Centres which were supported in 1987.

The Port Pirie Education Centre has been assessed by the Department as a suitable provider of job search training courses and is contracted to deliver courses to 30 June 1988. The Centre was identified by the local Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) manager as having appropriately qualified staff, previous experience with Departmental programs and existing good relations with the CES. In addition, the Centre was considered to have the capacity to provide quality jobsearch training in outlying areas. There was no indication during this assessment process of the possibility of the closure of the Centre.

A grant of $45,841 was approved under the Community Employment Program (CEP) in June 1987 for a project sponsored by the Centre to employ 5 unemployed people for 17 weeks. The primary objective of the CEP is to create short-term jobs to provide employment and work experience for disadvantaged unemployed people, particularly the long-term unemployed, with the aim of improving their long-term employment prospects.

The project to upgrade the Centre's grounds met the CEP guidelines and objectives. Furthermore, in support of its application, the Centre advised that the premises are utilised by at least 43 local community organisations and this high level of utilisation was one of the main reasons for the project's approval. Rather than funds being wasted, the CEP project assisted five unemployed people and benefited the community through improvements to a well utilised local facility.

While Commonwealth funding under the Education Centres Program has been an important source of funding for Education Centres, they have also sought and received significant support from other sources. For example, a major source of funding for the Port Pirie Centre in 1987 was a grant under the Projects of National Significance Program, administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, to support a policy development project concerned with rural schooling, with particular focus on the needs of girls.

It is open to all Education Centres to seek additional funding from a variety of sources. The CEP grant and job search program funding are consistent with the wider community role of the Centre and will assist it to support and enhance its operations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1987 (Hansard, page 2387), Senator Tambling asked me, as Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health to the answer which the Minister for Community Services and Health gave to a question in the House of Representatives in which Dr Blewett condemned the Northern Territory Government over the establishment of a private hospital within a public hospital campus in Darwin. This was an interim measure pending the completion of a new building for a private hospital. Given the Health Minister's warning that this decision has major policy implications, does this warning also apply to all State governments and, in particular, the New South Wales Government regarding its proposals to introduce similar private hospitals within the St George hospital, the Lismore hospital and, possibly, the Campbelltown hospital? Does the Government intend also to close the private division already operating in the Calvary public hospital located in Canberra, which would be well known to Senator Ryan.
Senator Tambling also asked the following supplementary question:

Given the nature of the Minister's answer, very emphatically, to the latter part of my question relating to the Calvary public hospital in Canberra in which she indicated that there would be no intention to close the private division, will she please draw a comparison between that situation and the situation at Royal Darwin Hospital?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The issue of private hospitals being set up within the precincts of public hospitals is essentially a matter for State and Territory health authorities to decide.

The Government, however, is concerned to ensure that under Medicare, unrestricted access to free public hospital treatment is maintained and that the entitlement to opt for doctor of choice involving basic table insurance cover or an equivalent out-of-pocket expense for public hospital accommodation and services, is not curtailed in any way by such arrangements.

In the case of the Northern Territory agreement with the Darwin Private Hospital to lease part of the Royal Darwin (public) Hospital for private patients, there were reasons to believe that these rights were being contravened. It was, therefore, incumbent upon the Government to satisfy itself that the principles of Medicare, as embodied in the Commonwealth/Northern Territory Agreement in relation to the provision of hospital services, would not be violated.

The Government consequently sought and received the necessary assurances regarding free and unfettered access to Royal Darwin Hospital before declaring the Darwin Private Hospital for health fund benefits purposes.

The Government will be maintaining the same adherence to the principles of Medicare regarding access to public hospital services, in looking at any future proposals by all States and Territories for the establishment of private hospitals within the precincts of public hospitals.

In declaring the Calvary Private Hospital in the ACT for fund benefits purposes, there were no similar reasons to believe that patients' rights might have been under any threat as was the case in Darwin.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Waterside Workers Federation of Australia: Productivity Rate

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 December 1987 (Hansard, page 2884), Senator Hamer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial relations aware of the closure tomorrow of a shipping terminal in Rozelle, Sydney, as a result of inefficient work practices, mainly by members of the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia? Does the Minister agree that the productivity rate of between four and five containers a day is not only appalling in comparison with 10 to 12 in Melbourne, but even more appalling in comparison with terminals in other countries which have a productivity rate at least double that of the best terminal in Australia? Does the Minister consider that members of the Waterside Workers' Federation from the Rozelle terminal, who are to be returned to the waterside labour pool, are entitled to any part of the productivity-related wage rise which is being negotiated at present for the members of this union, considering that their productivity rate has caused the closure of the terminal and the loss of jobs for other workers?
In my reply, I undertook to find out about this matter and to ascertain the views of the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

The Consolidated Cargo Services (CCS) container depot at Rozelle, ceased operations on 11 December 1987. The depot closed because it had been losing money and its employees would not agree to the introduction of a productivity scheme as required by the depot's management.

The Government is concerned that the performance of all sectors of the Australian waterfront are improved to enhance our international competitiveness. The Government's Waterfront Strategy comprises an investigation of shore based shipping costs by the Inter-State Commission and its oversight of four industry panels which are reviewing particular areas of concern. This strategy is designed to address the Government's concerns that improvements be made across the whole of this area. The number of containers packed or unpacked per day in container depots is one facet of this much larger problem.

The Waterside Workers' Federation has agreed to a productivity scheme in two Melbourne depots which it is understood has improved performance to the levels indicated by Senator Hamer. No figures are held on the packing/unpacking rates in overseas container depots to enable an international comparison. It should be noted that the packing/unpacking of containers is not comparable with the loading/unloading of containers onto/from ships.

Members of the Waterside Workers' Federation had a package of second tier offsets and a 4% salary increase ratified by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 28 October 1987. This included offsets in the container depots which have been implemented. As the former employees of the CCS depot were a party to that agreement they would have been legally entitled to that increase.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: New Parliament House Site: Severance Pay

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 December 1987 (Hansard, page 3474), Senator Michael Baume asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations noted reports that the pace-setting severance pay agreement, now ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for approximately 1,000 building workers on the new Parliament House will add a further $1m to the cost of the project? Did the Government make any submission to the Arbitration Commission on this matter before the determination was handed down? If so, was it in support of or in opposition to the proposal, particularly in view of the fact that previous opposition had led to a 12 week strike over this issue, costing multi-millions of dollars? Does the determination ``conform to the Government's social security, taxation and wage-fixing principles'' which were stated by the Minister here on 7 October as a requirement for favourable consideration as a severance pay scheme and which at that time he said required substantial amendment if it was to either meet its intended objectives or satisfy Government wages policy or conciliation and arbitration principles? I ask the Minister: What substantial changes have taken place since 7 October to make this scheme acceptable, if it is now acceptable, and what will the costs and other consequences be of this decision being spread through the building industry?
In my reply I undertook to obtain an answer from the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:
The Government is aware that Commissioner Baird on 15 December 1987 ratified a consent agreement providing redundancy pay for certain employees on the Parliament House project.

This decision is site specific and is an extension of a matter previously before the Commission. Major union and employers put submissions before the Commission. Whilst Commissioner Baird has not yet published his reasons he has indicated that the agreement is consistent with the Commission's termination change and redundancy (TCR) guidelines. Having been decided we must assume the decision is consistent with the Commission's wage fixing principles.

The Government did not intervene in this matter. As the Commission has determined that the agreement complies with the TCR principles, the Government accepts that the agreement is a genuine redundancy scheme and previous concerns expressed to the parties would not apply to this scheme. Accordingly, I would not expect there to be any problems in regard to the requirements of social security or taxation legislation.
